climate. &nbsp;During his Monday meeting, President Obama warned of this: "If there is a significant challenge in terms of regulating Wall Street and regulating our financial sector it is primarily coming from certain members of Congress who are consistently pressuring independent regulators to back off.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br><span></span><br><span>It is not a bad time to be a SIFI in America \xe2\x80\x93 it\xe2\x80\x99s certainly much better to be one now than in 2010. &nbsp;While DFA has forced restructuring and streamlining to occur, events like the GE Capital sell-off may prove to be exceptions that prove the rule rather than the new normal for SIFIs, especially if MetLife wins its case against regulators. &nbsp;President Obama was right to point to Congress as the cause of regulatory gridlock; the political will seen after the economic collapse has largely evaporated, giving SIFIs far more breathing room and opening up opportunities to push through \xe2\x80\x9cregulatory reform\xe2\x80\x9d measures.</span><br><span></span><br><span>_____________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Thurs -- &nbsp;Financial Reg. Nominations</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Fri -- Update on Tax Bills</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Mon --</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;ERI/Housing</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;EU/US Derivatives Deal</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Crisis</span><br><span></span><br><span>Survey of the SIFI Landscape (Mar 8)</span><br><span>Michigan and the Meaning of Flint &nbsp;(Mar 8) Puerto Rico\'s Debt Crisis &nbsp;(Mar. 5)</span><br><span>Municipal Finance Caucus &nbsp;(Mar. 4) </span><br><span>Flint Bill: &nbsp;Provisions &amp; Prospects (Mar. 2) </span><br><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb.2)</span><br><span></span><br><span>___________________ </span><br><span></span><br><span>Mike &amp; Co. &nbsp;--</span><br><span></span><br><span>Tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s Michigan primary election may end up being "yugge" if it seriously opens up the possibility that Trump can put the state in play in November -- \xe2\x80\x9cA normal Republican cannot think of bringing in Michigan,\xe2\x80\x9d said Trump -- nothing any other GOP presidential candidate could do, now, or for the past 25 years. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Flint crystallizes so many of the issues that give rise to this new tectonic possibility. &nbsp;There had to be a debate in Flint because there had to be a debate about it... and the Secretary deserves far more credit than she\'s getting for making sure it happened. </span><br><span></span><br><span>In Washington, the Senate is readying to vote on a bipartisan package for drinking water aid. &nbsp;It\xe2\x80\x99s not a slam dunk, however, as Mike Lee has maintained a hold on the bill, saying political grandstanding is taking the place of policy. &nbsp;More on all this below. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Best,</span><br><span></span><br><span>Dana</span><br><span>______________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span></span><br><span>Flint -- Bills and Broad Strokes</span><br><span></span><br><span>The Michigan legislature approved in January a $28 million appropriation to provide immediate aid to Flint. &nbsp;Some critics maintain that the need to do so demonstrates the sorry condition of the state\xe2\x80\x99s tax policy. &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>The tax base in Flint was eroded significantly during the 1980\xe2\x80\x99s and 90\xe2\x80\x99s as industry jobs left and the population fell. &nbsp;To deal with the resulting fiscal imbalance the Flint city manager was instructed to cut costs \xe2\x80\x93 he did so partly by switching the source of Flint\xe2\x80\x99s drinking water. The broad and deep cuts to state and local budgets affected basic public services most profoundly. &nbsp;Now, as a direct cause of these cuts, the residents of Flint are grappling with an issue no American ever considered possible \xe2\x80\x93 they do not have access to fresh drinking water.</span><br><span></span><br><span>For all the talk of federal aid in infrastructure financing there must be a place made for regular tax payers. &nbsp;These people bear a significant portion of direct funding for infrastructure projects both in their states and municipalities. &nbsp;When those tax revenues are redirected, or when state spending is cut to the point that basic services can\xe2\x80\x99t be provided then taxpayers are right to question what, in fact, their taxes are paying for. &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>Congressional update:</span><br><span></span><br><span>At the insistence of Democrats, the Flint agreement has been attached to a Senate energy bill introduced by Sen. Murkowski, S. 2012, which is next in line in the Senate following the opioid addiction bill. &nbsp;The energy bill will be voted on soon, providing that things moves quickly (not a sure bet, since Dems may want to vote on certain amendments to the opioid bill). &nbsp;Despite these potential hang ups, Senate leadership hopes to wrap up the energy bill by the end of the week \xe2\x80\x93 giving them some breathing room before the Senate adjourns for Easter recess by March 21. </span><br><span></span><br><span>While Sen. Cruz lifted his hold on the bill last week, Mike Lee has continued to block movement on the legislation. &nbsp;Sen. Lee is claiming that federal aid is not necessary to deal with Flint: \xe2\x80\x9cThe state of Michigan has an enormous budget surplus this year and a large rainy-day fund, totaling hundreds of millions of dollars," the Senator said in a statement.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Flint agreement:</span><br><span></span><br><span>The bill provides $250 million to assist the residents of Flint, Michigan and other American cities experiencing critical problems with their water supplies by increasing funding for Drinking Water Act State Revolving Funds and provide start-up funding for the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act. &nbsp;It includes:</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xc2\xb7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$100 million for Drinking Water State Revolving Funds (SRFs) accessible by any state with a drinking water emergency. &nbsp;It requires states to submit plans explaining how the money will be spent to address the emergency before funding is provided. &nbsp;&nbsp;Funds that remain after 18 months will be distributed to all states under the existing SRF formula. </span><br><span></span><br><span>\xc2\xb7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$70 million in funding to back secured loans made under the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (WIFIA). &nbsp;A federal investment of $70 million could support secured loans of up to $4.2 billion to address water and wastewater infrastructure needs across the country, according to Sen. Inhofe\xe2\x80\x99s office. &nbsp;All states and all communities with clean water and drinking water infrastructure needs are eligible for this assistance. </span><br><span></span><br><span>\xc2\xb7 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$50 million for various in authorized health programs for national use to address and prevent impacts from exposure to lead. </span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\x9cFlint\xe2\x80\x9d is more than Flint</span><br><span></span><br><span>Flint is a crisis of governance \xe2\x80\x93 there is a disconnect in the relationship between citizens and government, and it bridges every demographic. &nbsp;Just as the poor drink water so do the wealthy, and when a service as basic and fundamental is undermined to the point that an entire town of nearly a hundred thousands is poisoned by its own government, voters will express themselves, given the chance. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Residents, customers, consumers, taxpayers \xe2\x80\x93- citizens at the end of the day &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x93- are seeing their government in a significantly different light and thus far are voting differently this year accordingly. Donald Trump would not likely be able to put Michigan in play without this new perspective animation politics in Michigan as much as anywhere. </span><br><span></span><br><span>_____________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Tues -- &nbsp;Financial Reg. Nominations</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Wed -- &nbsp;SIFIs and the Fed</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Thurs -- Update on Tax Bills</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;ERI/Housing</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Intl Tax Reform</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;EU/US Derivatives Deal</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Crisis</span><br><span></span><br><span>Michigan and the Meaning of Flint (Mar 8) Puerto Rico\'s Debt Crisis &nbsp;(Mar. 5)</span><br><span>Municipal Finance Caucus &nbsp;(Mar. 4) </span><br><span>Flint Bill: &nbsp;Provisions &amp; Prospects (Mar. 2) </span><br><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br><span></span><br><span>------</span><br><span></span><br><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br><span>The February jobs report came out this morning better than expected. &nbsp;&nbsp;Once again, the US economy maintained strong job growth without wage gains. &nbsp;Wages fell 0.1 percent in February, but 242,000 positions were added to the economy, marking 72 months of uninterrupted job gains \xe2\x80\x93 the longest streak on record. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Additionally, labor participation rose by 1.5 million Americans since November \xe2\x80\x93 making it the highest it has been in 16 years (62.9 percent of the overall share of Americans).</span><br><span></span><br><span>The report from Puerto Rico is not as sunny. &nbsp;The territory is still waiting on a Congressional bill designed to handle the ongoing debt crisis on the island. &nbsp;More &nbsp;below.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Best,</span><br><span></span><br><span>Dana</span><br><span></span><br><span>______________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s Time Bomb</span><br><span></span><br><span>The Puerto Rican debt crisis has been an ongoing concern for both Congress, Wall Street and the Obama administration for some years now \xe2\x80\x93 the territory\xe2\x80\x99s bond ratings have been steadily dropping into the junk category and fell from A- in 2005 to CCC+ last April. &nbsp;At the heart of the matter is $70 billion in bonds that Puerto Rico owes and says it cannot pay on. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Because Puerto Rican bonds are tax exempt in all 50 states and the District of Columbia, making them incredibly popular investments for mutual funds, pensioners, and big banks. &nbsp;Over 20 percent of mutual funds in the United States hold at least some Puerto Rican bonds, with $11.3 billion in portfolio, with a further $15 billion in bonds held by hedge funds. &nbsp;Now that the territory\xe2\x80\x99s bonds are in the \xe2\x80\x9cjunk\xe2\x80\x9d category, pension funds and insurance firms are unable to hold them any longer.</span><br><span></span><br><span>The diverse list of bond holders has thrown a wrench into the plans of those who would rather allow Puerto Rico to default on its obligations \xe2\x80\x93 something which would require legislative action (the territory doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have that luxury, unlike states). &nbsp;If Puerto Rico is allowed to renege on its contractual agreements, the argument goes, then it creates a moral hazard for other entities to do the same rather than make the tough choices necessary to honor their obligations. &nbsp;The fact that many of these bonds are essentially held by ordinary Americans (through mutual funds and pensions) makes the argument all that stronger for many representatives. &nbsp;A state hasn\xe2\x80\x99t declared bankruptcy since Arkansas did so in 1933.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Moral hazard is inherent in a debt restructuring deal; here, the path for Puerto Rico toward capital markets after anything of the sort would still be an especially painful one (see: Argentina). &nbsp;Additionally, there are few serious proposals to grant the island full Chapter 9 status. &nbsp;Most opt instead for some form of negotiated haircut agreement combined with extending maturities on the bonds; these proposals are likely to succeed, considering Puerto Rico is almost certainly unable to maintain its bond payment schedule without a restructuring agreement.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Administration Position</span><br><span></span><br><span>Testifying before the House Committee on Natural Resources on Feb 25, Treasury official Antonio Weiss warned lawmakers that Puerto Rico needs \xe2\x80\x9can immediate solution\xe2\x80\x9d if it\xe2\x80\x99s to survive past May 1, when a $470 million bond payment is due. &nbsp;Soon after that, on July 1, a $1.9 billion bond payment will come due as well \xe2\x80\x93 Puerto Rican representatives have already declared they cannot meet those payments without assistance.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Weiss laid out the administration\xe2\x80\x99s two-part plan: first the territory must be allowed to restructure its debt obligations, second a fiscal oversight board should be established to assist the island with managing its finances. &nbsp;Importantly, Weiss stopped short of advocating for bankruptcy protection for Puerto Rico and told the committee that \xe2\x80\x9can advisory board is not adequate to do the job\xe2\x80\x9d alone. &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>House Democrats voiced concern over the financial oversight board, Rep. Luis Guti\xc3\xa9rrez: \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re saying that there\xe2\x80\x99s a joint responsibility, but it seems to me that all of the responsibility is being weighed on the people of Puerto Rico.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>Meanwhile Republicans claimed that any plan to restructure Puerto Rican debt was a non-starter; a few hours after the hearing the Republican Study Committee announced it would oppose any plan including such a provision. &nbsp;"Changing the rules mid-game would be unfair to Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s creditors who entered into these arrangements with agreed upon terms and would delegitimize future transactions," said RSC Chairman Bill Flores.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Policy Options</span><br><span></span><br><span>Until recently the two parties have maintained starkly contrasting views on how to best deal with Puerto Rico\xe2\x80\x99s debt crisis \xe2\x80\x93 Democrats have pushed for a forced debt restructuring, with some calling for the island to be granted Chapter 9 bankruptcy protections, meanwhile Republicans called for a financial oversight council to make the tough fiscal decisions necessary for Puerto Rico to maintain its debt obligations without reneging on its agreements.</span><br><span></span><br><span>The administration, through Weiss, has advocated a middle of the road approach. By adopting both proposals and avoiding the further edges of each (no bankruptcy, and no unaccountable board staffed by Wall Streeters), the administration hopes to find compromise between each group. &nbsp;And it seems like it might work.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Finding Compromise</span><br><span></span><br><span>Recently, however, the conservative stance against debt restructuring has lessened \xe2\x80\x93 with some Republicans saying that they could support a PR bill as long as it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t include Chapter 9 bankruptcy. &nbsp;House Natural Resources chair Bob Bishop has been working on a bill for Puerto Rico that does include some element of debt restructuring, and recently said \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure RSC will be satisfied with what we do \xe2\x80\xa6 to say that some element of [debt restructuring] could be in there, yeah.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br><span>The House is still sticking to its end of March deadline set by Speaker Ryan for putting forward a final bill on Puerto Rico on the floor for a vote. </span><br><span></span><br><span>_____________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Thurs -- Municipal Finance Caucus</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Fri -- Puerto Rico</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Mon -- FY17</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Tues -- 13 D Regs</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Wed -- &nbsp;TBD</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;SBC Nominations</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;ERI/Housing</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Intl Tax Reform</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;EU/US Derivatives Deal</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Crisis</span><br><span></span><br><span>Michigan and the Meaning of Flint (Mar 8) Puerto Rico\'s Debt Crisis &nbsp;(Mar. 5)</span><br><span>Municipal Finance Caucus &nbsp;(Mar. 4) </span><br><span>Flint Bill: &nbsp;Provisions &amp; Prospects (Mar. 2) </span><br><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br><span></span><br><span>________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br><span></span><br><span>In half an hour, the BLS jobs report for February is due to be released. &nbsp;If you\'d like an update or have any questions, please let me know. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Meanwhile, amid the most fractious campaign in recent history comes an initiative in Congress that sounds, well, incongruous with the cacophany. &nbsp;A broad and bipartisan group of House members is behind the official launch of a caucus this week dedicated to protecting and expanding the tax exemption enjoyed by municipal debt. </span><br><span></span><br><span>You have to start somewhere and why not with incentives to address the nation\'s long-neglected infrastructure with tax breaks -- about the only kind of stimulus and jobs measure that can garner bipartisan support? &nbsp;&nbsp;More on the new Municipal Finance Caucus below. &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>Best,</span><br><span></span><br><span>Dana</span><br><span></span><br><span>_____________________________________</span><br><span>A New Caucus</span><br><span></span><br><span>On Tuesday, Reps. Randy Hultgren and Dutch Ruppersberger announced that they have formed the Municipal Finance Caucus to protect the tax-exempt status of municipal debt and reexamine the way it is treated in financial regulations. &nbsp;In 2015, Hultgren and Ruppersberger sent a letter (reprinted below) to House leadership opposing the President\xe2\x80\x99s proposed 28 percent cap on tax deductions for municipal bonds, signed by over 120 of their colleagues. &nbsp;</span><br><span></span><br><span>Their announcement coincided with the National Association of State Treasurers\xe2\x80\x99 legislative conference in D.C. The same group drafted another letter, signed by more than 600 state and local officials, which urges the leaders of the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee to reject curbs to the muni exemption. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Who\xe2\x80\x99s in it?</span><br><span></span><br><span>Right now just the founding representatives have declared their official membership, but it\xe2\x80\x99s foreseeable that some of the 120 representatives that signed the letter to House leadership in 2015 will join as well. &nbsp;It\xe2\x80\x99s also seen a s likely that some Senators will want to join the caucus, but the founders haven\'t made clear if bicameral membership is a priority.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Is it Bipartisan?</span><br><span></span><br><span>Since 2013 Hultgren and Ruppersberger have led bipartisan efforts to draft letters of support for municipal bonds. &nbsp;The signatories to these letters include members from both sides of the aisle. &nbsp;Rep. Ruppersberger focuses mostly on local government and is pretty moderate. Rep. Hultgren is a more orthodox conservative Republican. </span><br><span></span><br><span>What\xe2\x80\x99s the Purpose?</span><br><span></span><br><span>The Caucus plans to defend municipal bonds\xe2\x80\x99 tax exempt status and advocate for regulatory changes which favor those bonds. &nbsp;Proposals to limit the tax-exempt status of these bonds have been floated in recent years. </span><br><span></span><br><span>In addition to calling for the bonds to maintain their tax preferred status, the Caucus will push for the passage of HR 2209, legislation considering municipal bonds as a High Quality Liquid Asset (HQLA) \xe2\x80\x93 a particularly contentious issue because of the disagreement over how flexible these liquidity rules should be from a systemic risk perspective. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Positions Taken to Date</span><br><span></span><br><span>The Caucus founders have opposed Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 2015 proposal to cap municipal bond tax exemption at 28 percent. Rep. Hultgren is also a co-sponsor of HR 2209 \xe2\x80\x93 the bill to set the liquidity for municipal bond assets at Level 2A (see Update, Feb. 18). &nbsp;Hultgren said the liquidity rules are an example of how regulators misunderstand municipal bonds, specifically the frequent serial structure of the their issuances.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Many investors flock to municipal bonds for security. But some federal regulators trying to shore up the banking system aren\'t convinced the bonds would be easy to sell in a crisis. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Division of Opinion</span><br><span></span><br><span>Division of opinion on HR 2099 falls along unusual lines, with Wall Street, Congress and municipal officials challenging bank regulators\' skepticism toward municipal debt. &nbsp;&nbsp;At issue are new rules aimed at ensuring banks can raise enough cash during a financial-market meltdown to fund their operations for 30 days. The requirements mean banks have to hold more cash or securities that are easily sellable. </span><br><span></span><br><span>Regulators don\'t think it is the place of Congress to second guess how they size up securities. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, at a congressional hearing Feb. 11, said legislation would "interfere with our supervisory judgments." </span><br><span></span><br><span>Big banks such as Citigroup Inc. and Wells Fargo &amp; Co. have sprung into action in lobbying Congress, along with municipal leaders who fret the rules will diminish bank bond-buying which could raise borrowing costs on infrastructure projects.</span><br><span></span><br><span>Hultgren also said the caucus will work to update the number of projects that could be financed by qualified small issue manufacturing bonds, a type of private-activity bond whose proceeds can be used to finance manufacturing facilities for small- and mid-sized manufacturers. The tax code provisions on small industrial development bonds have not been changed since the 1980s, he said. Hultgren sponsored a bill last year entitled \xe2\x80\x9cThe Modernizing American Manufacturing Bonds Act,\xe2\x80\x9d which was focused on expanding opportunities for qualified small issue manufacturing bonds, particularly by changing the national volume cap set by Congress. </span><br><span></span><br><span>What can be achieved?</span><br><span></span><br><span>Caucuses such as this one don\'t have the best reputation when it comes to getting things done. &nbsp;But rules relating to the liquidity value of capital is one of the few policy &nbsp;areas of any kind where there is bipartisan agreement. &nbsp;Municipal bonds, in particular, have a universal appeal because of their direct link to local and state infrastructure projects. &nbsp;At the very least, the caucus will spark some discussion about the best way to both reform existing methods for funding infrastructure investment and find new ways to fund it. </span><br><span></span><br><span>_________________________________</span><br><span></span><br><span>Recent/Planned Updates</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Thurs -- Municipal Finance Caucus</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Fri -- Puerto Rico</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Mon -- FY17</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Tues -- 13 D Regs</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Wed -- &nbsp;TBD</span><br><span></span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;SBC Nominations</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;ERI/Housing</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Intl Tax Reform</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;EU/US Derivatives Deal</span><br><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Crisis</span><br><span></span><br><span>Municipal Finance Caucus &nbsp;(Mar. 4) </span><br><span>Flint Bill: &nbsp;Provisions &amp; Prospects (Mar. 2) </span><br><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29</span><br><span></span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Mar 2, 2016, at 9:39 PM, Dana &lt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&gt; wrote:</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>I hope everyone\'s had a chance to reflect on the magnitude of yesterday\'s hard fought primary wins -- with gratitude to those who toiled in the field. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Saturday night, the campaign debate turns to Flint, Michigan -- to the town and the issues it has come to symbolize. &nbsp;&nbsp;The town\'s water contamination and related problems finally move center stage. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Congress has moved with uncommon alacrity and bipartisanship in recent weeks on legislation to direct funding to address the water issue in Flint and elsewhere. &nbsp;&nbsp;Here, we look at the bill\'s provisions, its funding steam, and its prospects. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Flint Bill -- Provisions &amp; Prospects</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>A bipartisan deal has been reached in the Senate last week to aid the beleaguered city of Flint, Michigan as it tries to remedy its drinking water issues. &nbsp;Sen. Inhofe, the lead GOP Senator on the bill, called it \xe2\x80\x9ccommon-sense," and noted that the spending is already programmed and involves no supplemental appropriation. &nbsp;&nbsp;The bill may be ready to move forward after Sen. Cruz lifted a hold he had placed on the bill last week. &nbsp;Sen. Mike Lee is still a hold-out. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The bill provides $250 million to assist the residents of Flint, Michigan and other American cities experiencing critical problems with their water supplies by increasing funding for Drinking Water Act State Revolving Funds and provide start-up funding for the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act. &nbsp;It also provides:</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;$100 million for Drinking Water State Revolving Funds (SRFs) accessible by any state with a drinking water emergency. &nbsp;It requires states to submit plans explaining how the money will be spent to address the emergency before funding is provided. &nbsp;&nbsp;Funds that remain after 18 months will be distributed to all states under the existing SRF formula. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;$70 million in funding to back secured loans made under the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (WIFIA). &nbsp;A federal investment of $70 million could support secured loans of up to $4.2 billion to address water and wastewater infrastructure needs across the country, according to Sen. Inhofe\xe2\x80\x99s office. &nbsp;All states and all communities with clean water and drinking water infrastructure needs are eligible for this assistance. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;$50 million for various in authorized health programs for national use to address and prevent impacts from exposure to lead. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Where will the money come from? &nbsp;&nbsp;The package has been fully paid for -- it redirects appropriations by taking funds from the Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (ATVM) Fund, which offers loans for auto companies. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does that matter? &nbsp;&nbsp;Per Sen. Inhofe \xe2\x80\x9c[the ATVM is] a failed program that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been used in more than a year and has only issued five loans since 2008."</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>More on ATVM: The ATVM program is authorized to award up to $25 billion in loans; there is no deadline for completing such loan commitments. Congress funded the program in 2009, when it appropriated $7.5 billion to cover the subsidy cost for the $25 billion in loans, as well as $10 million for program implementation. Since the start of the program, DOE has awarded $8.4 billion in loans to five companies. As of January 2015, ATVM has $16.6 billion in remaining loan authority. No new loans have been made since 2011. Two companies \xe2\x80\x94 Fisker and the Vehicle Production Group \xe2\x80\x94 were unable to make payments on their loans, and DOE auctioned the loans off in the fall of 2013. Tesla paid off all of its loan in 2013, nine years ahead of schedule. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Criticisms of ATVM: The unobligated funds remaining for the program have been a point of contention in recent appropriations debates. The House has voted several times to transfer some of the unused appropriation for the ATVM subsidy costs to other purposes. None of these transfers were enacted. Other legislators have sought to expand the program. Two recent federal reports call for rescinding the program\xe2\x80\x99s unobligated balance: the FY2015 budget resolution reported by the House Budget Committee calls for outright rescission, and an April 2014 GAO report recommends Congress consider taking the same step unless DOE can generate new demand for the program.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Legislative Strategy: &nbsp;&nbsp;Architects of the bipartisan deal put out a hotline request to see if anyone would object to a series of procedural moves that would split Flint aid off the energy bill (S. 2012), attach it to a House bill (H.R. 4470) sponsored by Reps. Dan Kildee and Fred Upton, allow voice votes on 30 amendments to the energy bill, and allow roll call votes on eight additional amendments. Michigan Sens. Debbie Stabenow and Gary Peters said Democrats are on board, but in order to achieve unanimous consent, Republicans need to sign on. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Will it pass? &nbsp;The Flint package and the energy bill amendments would come to a vote only after the Senate gets unanimous consent to some procedural maneuvers. Lee\'s hold went unnoticed earlier when GOP presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz had a hold of his own, which he has now lifted. The Senate had hoped to hold votes on Flint and end debate on the energy bill as early as next week. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>What\xe2\x80\x99s Next? &nbsp;&nbsp;Sen. Stabenow, a key leader on the bill, predicted that \xe2\x80\x9cone way or another\xe2\x80\x9d the package would be voted on in the Senate this week. &nbsp;And while the House hasn\'t decided what it will do if the Flint bill clears the Senate, Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton said it would move quickly.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Obama administration, which declared Flint a federal emergency in January freeing up much-needed funds for the distressed city, has not issued an official stance on the Flint deal. &nbsp;Early in the year the President also made available to the state of Michigan $80 million from a revolving fund for infrastructure repair and improvement. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>A number of important events are scheduled for the month of March, listed below.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;March 3 -- Flint is supposed to begin its lead service line replacement project.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;March 6 -- The 7th Democratic debate will take place in the city of Flint, MI. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;March 15 -- &nbsp;House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform will hold its next hearing on the Flint crisis. &nbsp;On schedule is testimony on the Safe Drinking Water Act (SDWA) by various policy professionals.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;March 17 -- &nbsp;Hearings resume on SDWA oversight, with Michigan Governor Rick Snyder and EPA Administrator Gina McCarthy scheduled to testify.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Wed -- Flint </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Thurs -- Municipal Finance Caucus</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Fri -- Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Budget Irresolution</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;13 D Regs</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;ERI/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Intl Tax Reform</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;EU/US Derivatives Deal</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Pension Crisis</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Flint Bill: &nbsp;Provisions &amp; Prospects (Mar. 2) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>This has been a busy week in Washington especially on the tax front, with more to follow. &nbsp;We\'ve already seen a number of hearings and developments on the most salient current tax bills and related proposals in the last two days, which are &nbsp;itemized and vetted for viability below.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tomorrow, an assessment of which of these, as well as "must-pass" tax items such as the expiring extenders, will make it to Obama\'s desk by year-end and a review of Brookings\' panel discussion, "Tax policy in 2016: What\'s new and what\'s next," with Ways and Means Chair Kevin Brady and Senate Finance ranking member Ron Wyden. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>______________________________________</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 International Tax Reform --</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Probably the most likely tax legislation to pass in 2016, even though it\'s still called unlikely by key policymakers. &nbsp;The two parties will have difficulty coming to an agreement on first what to do and then how to do it. &nbsp;Narrower legislation is more likely to succeed than comprehensive reform. &nbsp;Most viable bills in this area:</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Earnings Stripping -- &nbsp;On the eve of today\xe2\x80\x99s Ways and Means hearing regarding international tax reform, &nbsp;ranking member Chris Van Hollen and senior member Sander Levin offered bills to constrain the practice whereby foreign parent companies extend large loans to their newly acquired U.S. partners and take advantage of the tax-deductible status of interest payment arrangement. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2. Exit Tax Bills -- &nbsp;Bills seeking to reduce corporate inversions by making them too expensive to make business sense are likely to be introduced before next recess. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Repatriation -- &nbsp;Ryan and Schumer have talked up the idea of introducing legislation to repatriate U.S. multinational profits that are held abroad. &nbsp;A compromise will have to be struck between Democrats seeking reduced tax levels for this purpose and Republicans who cite moral hazard. &nbsp;The Obama budget for FY2017 includes a proposal to allow overseas profits to come home at a special 14 percent trate, and all overseas profits thereafter be taxed at 19 percent. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Broader Corporate Tax Reform &nbsp;-- &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Any successful across the board corporate tax reform would almost have to lower the nominal corporate tax rate of 35 percent. &nbsp;-- the highest in the world. &nbsp;Republicans are adamant that the high rate yields corporate inversions. &nbsp;Ways and Means chair Brady has pointed to the corporate rate repeatedly as a sign that the U.S. has a \xe2\x80\x9cbroken tax code that discourages investment and growth.\xe2\x80\x9d </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brady has not yet released his own reform bill, but an op-ed of his published this morning gives an indication of what it will include: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cWe must address the real root of the problem \xe2\x80\x93 our broken tax code that discourages investment and growth \xe2\x80\xa6 Our sky-high 35 percent corporate tax rate bears much of the blame \xe2\x80\xa6 We cannot allow American taxpayers to foot the bill for tax revenue grabs in Europe and elsewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Provisions to look for: a lower overall corporate tax rate, language to address European investigations on U.S. businesses dodging taxes abroad. &nbsp;The bill likely won\xe2\x80\x99t include language restricting inversions. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Senate Finance chair Hatch has suggested writing legislation to make dividends tax deductible for corporations, eliminating the so-called \xe2\x80\x9cdouble taxation\xe2\x80\x9d of hitting corporate earnings as well as dividend incomes from investors. &nbsp;The proposal faces long odds. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Earned-Income Tax Credit (EITC) -- </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>One tax provisions in the Obama FY17 budget that has been muted if not mooted this week is his proposal to expand the EITC for childless workers and create a $500 \xe2\x80\x9csecond earner\xe2\x80\x9d tax credit. &nbsp;The cost would be $150 billion over ten years. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>During his SOTU, Obama expressed his desire to work with Speaker Ryan on the issue: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cI also know Speaker Ryan has talked about his interest in tackling poverty. America is about giving everybody willing to work a chance, a hand up. And I\xe2\x80\x99d welcome a serious discussion about strategies we can all support, like expanding tax cuts for low-income workers who don\'t have children.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The credit is a long-standing darling of both progressives and the GOP establishment. Ryan and President Obama support extending it to childless workers. &nbsp;But they face resistance from not just the hard right but from Sen. Hatch, who say it\xe2\x80\x99s not \xe2\x80\x9cnecessary\xe2\x80\x9d to expand the break. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. EU</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Budget (Ir)Resolution</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Econ. Revitalization/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Top Tax Bills Handicapped &nbsp;(Feb. 24)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Bigger than the Budget Battle &nbsp;(Feb. 23)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>----</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike and Co. --</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The soap opera that is the federal budget making process saw sone minor prima donna pratfalls this week. &nbsp;Nothing remotely on the scale of blocking the confirmation of a Supreme Justice. &nbsp;But as Senate Budget\'s ranking member Sen. Cardin warned at a breakfast today, you can forget regular order on the budget -- after the President submits a nomination, all comity in the Senate will be gone until Election Day. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Details and the latest below. &nbsp;Taxes tomorrow (be still your heart, right?). </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Story in the Senate</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>At the same DSCC &nbsp;breakfast one month ago, Sen. Merkley announced that, to his surprise, Senate Budget Chair Mike Enzi was going to put out a manager\'s mark for an FY17 budget resolution for Committee markup, for February. &nbsp;Today, Enzi withdrew his markup plans, without announcing a reschedule date.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>To add to the growing problems within the GOP, the party, led by Senator Mitch McConnell, has declared all-out war on Obama\xe2\x80\x99s impending Supreme Court nomination -- an "nomination abomination" -- making it even more difficult to predict how these budget deliberations will end. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Histrionics of the House </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Even before Obama released his FY2017 budget proposal earlier this month, House Republicans made it a point to emphasize that it was DOA. &nbsp;Now, GOP is running into some dead ends of its own. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Speaker Ryan announced early on that he intended to pass the budget through regular order this year -- a process that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t been successfully completed in a generation. &nbsp;Due to internal dicisions and outside pressures, House Republicans have changed their tune. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yesterday, House Budget announced plans for a proposal next month to stick with the spending levels set by last fall\xe2\x80\x99s deal with the White House while also giving members the chance to vote on other bills that would slash government spending. The compromise is meant to appease hard-right GOP members who vehemently opposed the Obama-Boehner budget agreement. &nbsp;Per Ryan\'s office: \xe2\x80\x9cThis proposal enjoys the overwhelming support of the committee members, and the chairman looks forward to sharing it with the broader Conference as we continue moving this process forward.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The conservative Freedom Caucus so far has supported Speaker Ryan\xe2\x80\x99s overtures for cooperation on the budget. &nbsp;But the GOP\'s hard-right wing may not remain so understanding of the Speaker\xe2\x80\x99s position, especially if their credentials are called into question by outside groups with sway over their base of support. &nbsp;&nbsp;Heritage Action said Monday that the group would oppose any budget blueprint that sticks to the Obama-Boehner deal, which increases spending by about $30 billion.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Going Forward </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>It won\'t be an easy road ahead on the budget. &nbsp;&nbsp;The conservative caucus has several dozen members, which gives it the power to torpedo any budget proposal that lacks at least some Democratic support. &nbsp;If it decides to back the new proposal put forth by Chair Tom Price of House Budget, it would be likely for GOP leaders to be able to move forward. &nbsp;Some members have voiced their willingness to cooperate, but the pull of outside right-wing groups may prove to be too strong.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Meanwhile, Minority Whip Steny Hoyer said today that any Republican budget strategy that strays from the Obama-Boehner deal would be opposed by House Democrats. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The House Budget plan is to submit the proposal honoring the spending limits agreed to last year, while allowing the hard-right GOP wing to vote on other bills which would slash spending, mollifying the more hawkish members. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dearth of Legislative Days</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Lengthening the odds against Ryan, the House Budget is now working on a delayed schedule. &nbsp;In mid-January, the House Budget Committee announced that it would be releasing its markup of the White House budget proposal early -\xe2\x80\x93 on February 25. However, that has also changed. Yesterday, The Committee announced that it was now delaying its markup till sometime in March. &nbsp;The change is curious for a few reasons. &nbsp;It raises the question of why the House Budget Committee said it would have the markup done so early in the first place. Moreover, it goes against the House Republicans message of \xe2\x80\x9cgetting things done\xe2\x80\x9d during this Congress. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Democrats are jumping on this delay already. &nbsp;Nancy Pelosi said: \xe2\x80\x9cYet again, it\xe2\x80\x99s the Speaker\xe2\x80\x99s own broken promises \xe2\x80\x93 and his own rhetoric \xe2\x80\x93 that are coming back to bite him. &nbsp;Because while the Speaker pledged an end to dysfunctional House-Republican leadership, all the American people are seeing is more of the same.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>One thing is looks increasingly likely: that the nomination will exert a tidal force on at least the budget deliberations and everything else, through the election. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Tax Talk</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. EU</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Econ. Revitalization/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>One week ago, the House passed a bill that could alter and perhaps ease the way state and local infrastructure is financed in the capital markets, when HR.2209, a bill to "require the appropriate Federal banking agencies to treat certain municipal obligations as level 2A liquid assets, and for other purposes" was adopted by the House with a voice vote. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Thought the bill has flown below the media radar, it is significant. &nbsp;Municipal obligations, including bonds, are at the heart of infrastructure investment in America. &nbsp;And infrastructure investment has been a large focus of this primary. &nbsp;Both Democratic candidates have proposed multi-hundred billion dollar infrastructure investment proposals.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Details below...</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure is mostly funded at the state or local level through the use of municipal bonds. &nbsp;Between 2003 and 2012, counties, states, and other localities invested $3.2 trillion in infrastructure through long-term tax-exempt municipal bonds, 2.5 times more than the federal investment. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Bill</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HR 2209 requires federal banking regulators to include municipal bonds under the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR). &nbsp;The LCR is designed to ensure that financial institutions have the necessary assets available to handle a liquidity disruption. &nbsp;Local officials have said that if the new rules aren\xe2\x80\x99t changed, it will saddle them with higher borrowing costs by eliminating incentives banks have to purchase their bonds. Without bonds, these governments will lose a significant source of their funding. &nbsp;Per Indiana State Treasurer Kelly Mitchell: \xe2\x80\x9cThis bill helps ensure cash-strapped school districts and municipalities will continue to have access to bonds to finance projects they think are best for their communities.\xe2\x80\x9d </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Rep. Luke Messer, an Indiana Republican who wrote the bill: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cPut simply, our bill requires the federal government to recognize the obvious, that our municipal bonds are some of the safest investments in the world and that we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have rules that give preferential treatment to corporate bonds or other countries\xe2\x80\x99 bonds over our own.\xe2\x80\x9d </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>After passing the House with unanimous bipartisan support, a companion bill is expected to be introduced in the Senate this year. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Municipal Bond Issue</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>After the crisis of 2008, federal regulators adopted international banking standards that require banks to have enough "High-Quality Liquid Assets" to cover their cash outflows for 30 days in case of a future financial meltdown. &nbsp;Now, municipal bonds are not considered liquid assets and therefore cannot be included under the &nbsp;LCR. &nbsp;&nbsp;As a result, financial institutions have been discouraged from holding municipal debt, which means that cash strapped municipalities and school districts may eventually be forced to reduce or even stop work on projects &nbsp;financed with municipal bonds. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure Financing -- Alternative Financing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Tax-exempt bonds: &nbsp;Exemption from federal taxes and many state and local taxes is possible through the use of municipal bonds. &nbsp;&nbsp;In recent years, with the increasing use of PPPs, barriers to this tax exemption have arisen. &nbsp;Treasury has reviewed relevant tax rules and based on their findings and have put forth a proposal for an expanded and permanent America Fast Forward Bond Program as an alternative to tax-exempt bonds. &nbsp;Based on the successful Build America Bond program, \xe2\x80\x9cwould provide an efficient borrowing subsidy to state and local governments while appealing to a broader investor base than traditional tax-exempt bonds [and] would cover a broad range of projects for which tax-exempt bonds can be used.\xe2\x80\x9d </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Obama\xe2\x80\x99s budget proposal: &nbsp;Obama has also put forth a plan to strengthen local and state government infrastructure projects. His plan relies on a new Federal credit program to support public-private partnerships within the Department of the Treasury. It will provide direct loans to US infrastructure projects developed through PPPs. The Obama Administration believes that private investment is crucial for infrastructure development moving forward, so there should be more flexibility in regards to what PPP is subject to. In addition to that, President Obama has proposed the taxable, direct-pay America Fast Forward bond program to help finance infrastructure. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>State Infrastructure Banks</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Local governments receive financing in a number of ways. &nbsp;Traditional sources such as tax revenues have been dwindling and local authorities have been relying on federal government loan programs, public-private partnerships, and State Revolving Funds (SRFs). &nbsp;State Infrastructure Banks (SIBs) are a subset of SRFs -- the funds act like a bank, because they don\xe2\x80\x99t own the infrastructure asset, but act as a lender or guarantor to the project sponsor. Per Brookings: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cSRFs rely on principal repayments, bonds, interest and fees to re-capitalize and replenish the fund as a perpetual source of debt financing.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>SIBs generate more investment per dollar than traditional federal and state grant programs. &nbsp;They only exist in 33 states and 10 of those SIBs are currently inactive. A large problem may be compliance with federal regulations. &nbsp;Brookings again: </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\x9cWe found that many SIB officials cite compliance with federal regulations as slowing down the investment process either because of environmental and contractual requirements or due to the lack of flexibility in projects that are not Title 23 or 49 eligible. For states with smaller projects, this may be prohibitively costly compared to the advantage of using the low-cost SIB financing.\xe2\x80\x9d </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Just being called a bank subjects SIBs to regulations that commercial banks are subject to. &nbsp;SIBs are non-for-profit organizations with a goal of increasing infrastructure investment, so they don\xe2\x80\x99t quite fit into the category of the average bank. &nbsp;SIBs may be more successful outside this classification. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>For or Against Dodd-Frank</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Before Dodd-Frank, particularly in the case of relatively small municipalities, many underwriters forged long-term relationships with municipalities and would provide financial advice before and after a bond issuance. &nbsp;With Dodd-Frank, that relationship changed, with a new \xe2\x80\x9cmunicipal adviser\xe2\x80\x9d category that must register with the SEC and be regulated by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSR). &nbsp;Now, it is widely illegal to provide advice to governmental entities concerning the issuance of municipal bonds, the use of financial derivatives, and the investment of the proceeds of a bond issue to, or on behalf, of a municipal entity or an obligated person unless the adviser is registered with the SEC. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HR 2209 appears to address a problem within Dodd-Frank, but it is unclear if it vitiates the law materially. &nbsp;At face value, it appears to be more a technical fix. Dodd-Frank expanded regulations for banking institutions, but the entities that fund state and local governments are far unlike the TBTF institutions that Dodd-Frank was meant to regulate. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Groups like Americans for Financial Reform oppose HR 2209: \xe2\x80\x9cWhile we sympathize with the belief that municipal debt was incorrectly treated under the initial LCR rule, we believe that it is inappropriate to classify such debt as a Level 2A asset. AFR therefore opposes this bill unless a more appropriate liquidity classification is used.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;AFR has previously said it supports treating municipal bonds as more liquid and does not approve the type of classification used in HR 2209, because it goes too far in its treatment of municipal debt as level 2A liquid assets and specifically with micromanaging regulators with this kind of detail and they prefer a Level 2B classification. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The bill could provide relief for smaller institutions, so that they can fund infrastructure investment more easily. In terms of Dodd-Frank, it is yet to be decided if it is simply a necessary tweak or a criticism. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Looking Ahead</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HR 2209 could end up being an important issue in the national infrastructure discussion. &nbsp;It brings up questions about how far a state or local government can go before its activities begin to resemble an actual bank. &nbsp;With the growth of PPPs, the private sector is being even more integrated into the process \xe2\x80\x93 should those companies be given tax exemptions, as well? </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. EU</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Budget (Ir)Resolution</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Econ. Revitalization/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Infrastructure Finance Update &nbsp;(Feb. 18) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>----</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. &nbsp;--</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The newly-installed the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank and former Special Investigator overseeing the TARP program came to town yesterday advocating drastic action to head off a financial sector systemic risk crisis, calling for the nation\'s biggest banks to be broken up. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>His speech, delivered at Brookings, got noticed, with lengthy coverage in the NYT, WSJ, and WaPo. &nbsp;And perhaps with reason -- the TBTF (too big to fail) issue has dogged
