Congress and the administration for years and is one of the central ones in the Democratic presidential campaign this far. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Or maybe it was just a slow news day. &nbsp;You decide...</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best, </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>A Peculiar Package of Proposals</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Kashkari argued in the alternative that Dodd-Frank needs to be used and/or needs to be reformed. &nbsp;He says the law as written does not solve the TBTF problem. &nbsp;He also wants regulators to use the yet-untried tools at their disposal under the law. &nbsp;&nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cWhile significant progress has been made to strengthen our financial system, I believe the [Dodd-Frank] Act did not go far enough." &nbsp;He then laid out three ideas meant to end TBTF once and for all. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;break up large banks into smaller, less connected, less important entities;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;turn what remains of the large banks into public utilities by forcing them to hold so much capital that they can\xe2\x80\x99t fail; and</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;tax leverage throughout the financial system "to reduce systemic risks wherever they lie."</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Break up the Banks</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>From the perspective of current laws, breaking up big banks is already a policy avenue available to regulators. &nbsp;The Federal Reserve, through the Financial Stability Oversight Council, can elect to take a number of actions to deal with banks that it feels are both systemically important and organized in an unstable way. &nbsp;Section 121 of the Dodd-Frank Act gives the Board of Governors these powers. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>So this first proposal \xe2\x80\x93 break up big banks - has been covered here before but just for the sake of argument... which banks need to be broken up most urgently? &nbsp;Few commentators believe there is an imminent threat demanding action. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Unsurprisingly, the Fed doesn\xe2\x80\x99t believe that banks are so hopeless that they need to be dissolved. &nbsp;That doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it\xe2\x80\x99s not a possibility under current legislation, however.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Make Banks \xe2\x80\x9cUtilities\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The second proposal is to push capital requirements for banks so high that they \xe2\x80\x9cessentially turn into public utilities.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;Kashkari never explains how exactly high capital reserves turn banks into utilities, but that\xe2\x80\x99s for another time. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>He is voicing his support for one of the oldest forms of banking regulations that we still use and use far more now in the Dodd-Frank era \xe2\x80\x93 he wants banks to hold more capital. &nbsp;Supporters of the law may be heartened by his full-throated endorsement of the law on this score. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Cribbing from Clinton?</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The third proposal was just about lifted out of Secretary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s plan to regulate Wall Street \xe2\x80\x93- though the reporting on the speech doesn\xe2\x80\x99t much mention it much. &nbsp;It is reasonable both from a policy and a political perspective. But he doesn\'t provide further details about his proposal after first outlining it.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Kashkari contra Yellen</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fed Chair Yellen has been an outspoken proponent of existing banking regulations, making it known that while the job of regulators is not done yet. we\xe2\x80\x99re in a much better situation now than we were before DFA. &nbsp;During her testimony before House Financial Services, Yellen fielded a question about why she had not yet broken up big banks, saying: \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6we [at the Fed]vare using our powers to make sure that a systemically important institution could fail, and it would not be -- have systemic consequences for the country. We\'re doing that in a whole variety of ways.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The ways Yellen is referring to include enforcing Liquidity Coverage Ratios, capital reserve requirements, and a rule passed last November forcing the biggest banks to issue long-term debt equal to 18 percent of risk-weighted assets. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Evidently it\'s not enough. &nbsp;But it is nonetheless uncommon for a newly minted Federal Reserve Bank President to taking to task the Chair of the Federal Reserve\xe2\x80\x99s Board of Governors.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Municipal Bond Rule</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Budget (Ir)Resolution</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. EU</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Econ. Revitalization/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Does DFA Fail on Too Big to Fail? (Feb. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. &nbsp;--</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>A national holiday, a snowstorm, and a congressional recess stilled DC yesterday and a quiet week is expected. &nbsp;It gives us a chance to have a look at some developments thus far this year that have flown below the radar.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Today\'s item is the one bill on its way to the President\xe2\x80\x99s desk -- the Customs bill -- and the caboose attached to it that extends the internet tax moratorium permanently &nbsp;and may be the bill\'s important title... at least until the TPP comes up on the Senate floor. </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Customs Bill: &nbsp;Comity on the Hill</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Senate cleared the first overhaul of the Customs and Border Protection (CBP) agency in more than a decade in a 75-20 vote last Thursday, sending the bill to the President and ending months of wrangling over the measure. &nbsp;The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 (H.R. 644) retools CBP to increase its focus on blocking illegal trade and ensuring that legal trade moves smoothly.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The major facets of this legislation are:</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;new protections on intellectual property rights</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;new tools to fight currency manipulation</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2. a permanent extension of the Internet Tax Freedom Act</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Said Senate Finance ranking member Ron Wyden: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cThis bill is about coming down hard on the trade cheats who are ripping off American jobs, and the truth is past trade policies were often too old, too slow or too weak for our country to fight back."</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Wyden was perhaps the most outspoken Democrat in support of the bill, continuing his role as a strong backer of free trade legislation. &nbsp;He was a key factor in getting Trade Promotion Authority legislation passed through Congress last summer, splitting from some of his colleagues in voicing support for that act.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Unusual Coalition</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>27 Democrats, 47 Republicans, and 1 Independent voted affirmatively. &nbsp;Industry groups including the National Retail Federation, as well as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce were supportive of the legislation. &nbsp;National Association of Manufacturers\xe2\x80\x99 president Jay Timmons said \xe2\x80\x9cif senators want to grow manufacturing in the United States, then they should pass this bill immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Notable \xe2\x80\x9cNay\xe2\x80\x9d votes include Sens. Durbin and Reid, who both expressed disappointment that the legislation was a \xe2\x80\x9cwatered down\xe2\x80\x9d version of a bill previously passed by the Senate. &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9dI like that [Senate] version, and that strong language on currency manipulation,\xe2\x80\x9d Durbin said \xe2\x80\x93 that language required Commerce to consider \xe2\x80\x9cundervalued\xe2\x80\x9d currencies to be equivalent to countervailable subsidies. &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cThe conference report that\xe2\x80\x99s back to us now and before the Senate at this moment is a much different bill."</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Purpose and Provisions</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>House and Senate negotiators agreed on a final customs bill in December. &nbsp;&nbsp;The House passed the measure 256-158 but the legislation stalled in the Senate over a provision added in conference that permanently extends a moratorium on Internet access taxes.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>That provision is perhaps the most reported on section in the bill \xe2\x80\x93 it\xe2\x80\x99s almost certainly the most popular - it applies to localities, states, and the federal government itself. &nbsp;&nbsp;Sen. Lamar Alexander cited it though as explanation for his \xe2\x80\x9cnay\xe2\x80\x9d vote: "the federal government shouldn\'t be telling the states what their tax structure should be."</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Another important provision, known as the ENFORCE Act, would require the CBP to more aggressively investigate complaints that companies are evading anti-dumping or countervailing duties on imports by mislabeling or disguising the shipments.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The bill includes a new Trade Enforcement Fund to bring trade cases through the WTO, to investigate the implementation of trade requirements by other countries, and to respond to complaints of trade violations. &nbsp;It also creates a nine-member Advisory Committee on International Exchange Rate Policy, whose members must be comprised of individuals from the private sector who are selected by both chambers of Congress and the President (three members each).</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Currency Manipulation</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Currency manipulation has been a long-standing concern of American policy-makers and a particularly contentious issue in global trade relations; claims that China has been chronically undervaluing its currency have made the news for a number of years. &nbsp;Advocates for stricter enforcement of currency manipulation provisions claim that undervalued currencies operate similarly to export subsidies \xe2\x80\x93 a prohibited practice within the World Trade Organization.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The final bill dropped a Senate provision that would have required the Commerce Department to treat undervalued currency as an illegal subsidy under U.S. countervailing duty law. &nbsp;This provision would have opened the door for compensatory tariffs to be levied against goods which originate from countries which are found to purposely undervalue their currency in order to boost their exports. The bill does, however, include other measures that give the Treasury Department new tools to fight currency manipulation:</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;creates a special fund for the CBP to ensure trading partners follow the rules and to bring disputes before the WTO</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;increases funding to the National Intellectual Property Rights Coordination Center</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;establishes the Commercial Customs Operations Advisory Committee jointly between CBP and Treasury</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;requires CBP to investigate claims from other agencies of evasion of anti-dumping or countervailing duties.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Relation to TPP</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sen. Majority Leader McConnell has said that the Senate will not vote on the Trans-Pacific Partnership before the November elections, so it may come as a surprise to see a bill which deals with enforcing trade deals like TPP pass both houses of Congress. &nbsp;However this bill\xe2\x80\x99s provisions for protecting IP rights, toughening countervailing duties, and tackling currency manipulation are a necessary prerequisite for agreements like TPP (or the far more nebulous TTIP). &nbsp;The new age of trade agreements &nbsp;will deal extensively in issues like intellectual property protection, trade in services, and high-tech product trading; types of commerce which are far more difficult to regulate compared to the trade of physical goods.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>So, despite the fact that TPP won\xe2\x80\x99t get a vote until after November (and perhaps not in 2016 at all), and may not pass even then, the protections set forward in the customs bill are necessary to allow American companies to continue to compete in the global marketplace.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Price of Passage</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>In order to include the permanent extension of the Internet Tax Freedom Act, McConnell had to promise that a vote would be held this year on the Marketplace Fairness Act. &nbsp;That legislation grants states greater authority to collect sales taxes from online businesses who sell products within their borders. &nbsp;While McConnell himself opposes the bill, it was the only way to get the customs bill (with the tax amendment attached) unstuck.</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Just because McConnell has promised it will be brought to a vote doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean it will be a smooth process - the Senate passed the Marketplace Fairness Act in 2013 with 69 votes, and most of the lawmakers who voted for it are still in the chamber. &nbsp;Some lawmakers like Kelly Ayotte, who is facing a tough reelection campaign this year, have vowed to fight tooth-and-nail against it. &nbsp;Despite these detractors in the Senate, the real battle may occur in the House, where two competing proposals have been brought forward. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Municipal Bond Rule</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Budget (Ir)Resolution</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Puerto Rico</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. EU</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Econ. Revitalization/Housing</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below the Radar/Customs Bill &nbsp;(Feb. 16) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>----</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Feb 11, 2016, at 7:47 PM, Dana &lt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&gt; wrote:</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. &nbsp;--</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>One thing the two parties agree is that international tax reform is a fiscally necessary issue to take up -- that Uncle Sam is leaving hundreds of billions of dollars on the table overseas annually. &nbsp;&nbsp;But they would also generally agree that it is not going to get done this year. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Under current law, those profits are subject only to federal taxes if they are returned, or repatriated, to the U.S. where they face a top rate of 35 percent. &nbsp;Many companies avoid U.S. taxes on those earnings by simply leaving them overseas.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>There is bipartisan activity on the issue in both houses of Congress. Obama has a major reform proposal on the table. &nbsp;So is this the year, in the year of surprises?</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Reforms in the area of international tax deal with both the repatriation of foreign-derived profits and the issue of corporate inversions. &nbsp;Testifying today, Treasury Secretary Jack Lew encouraged the parties in Congress to overcome their differences on both, which he believes surmountable: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cI just want to underscore the urgency of dealing with inversions \xe2\x80\xa6 We can\xe2\x80\x99t wait a year to deal with this,\xe2\x80\x9d Lew said during a Senate Finance hearing on the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s budget. Congress could pass narrow legislation on inversions, he said, even if broader reform of the international system is preferable. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Stirrings in the Senate</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sen. Schumer also announced today that he is in contact with Speaker Ryan about coming to an agreement on repatriating corporate profits. &nbsp;They were unable to come to an agreement last year on a similar measure put forth as part of a larger reform effort. &nbsp;Schumer said today: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re trying to bridge over, of course, the divide between existing proposals. &nbsp;I remain at the table ready to work.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>One of the key differences between the parties concerns whether the money raised from tax reform should be turn into government revenue for more spending, or used to pay down the debt or pass tax cuts. &nbsp;After the Senate Finance hearing yesterday, Chair Hatch said: &nbsp;\xe2\x80\x9cI\'m actually working on international, but I just don\'t think it\'s going to get done this year, because, you know, let\'s face it, the Democrats are going to want to raise revenue. &nbsp;They want money to spend.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>At that same hearing, Sen. Shelby pushed a corporate integration plan he is developing to eliminate the double taxation of corporate income by providing corporations a dividend deduction. &nbsp;He\'s awaiting a score by the Joint Committee on Taxation. &nbsp;Dividend deductions are usually quite expensive and regressive, so it will a feat to attract any Democratic support, especially for him. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brady\'s Push </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Meanwhile, Ways and Means Chair Kevin Brady has said that he wants a vote this year on moving the United States into a territorial tax system, which would permanently exempt US-based businesses from paying taxes on income earned abroad. &nbsp;He also wants to lower the corporate rate to 20 percent. &nbsp;In the face of these proposals it is difficult to see what sort of compromise can be found between Democrats and Republicans, as the former may be more preoccupied just keeping alive the idea that foreign profits should be taxed at all. \xe2\x80\x9cThe goal of these reforms are not to generate more spending,\xe2\x80\x9d Brady said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s to bring back real dollars to be reinvested in the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brady has been advocating for international tax reform since he took over Ways and Means. &nbsp;Last month, he spoke with Sen. Hatch and they were both committed to getting something done. &nbsp;Senior Republicans believe the country\xe2\x80\x99s international tax problems \xe2\x80\x94 inversions and Europe going after revenues from U.S. companies among them \xe2\x80\x94 are urgent. &nbsp;But Brady strongly hinted that all that work would be aimed at setting things up for 2017, when Republicans want \xe2\x80\x9cpro-growth tax reform under a Republican president.\xe2\x80\x9d Perhaps that\xe2\x80\x99s no huge shock, but it does seem to set up something of a disconnect, given all the talk of urgency.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brady and his supporters have been pushing the idea that American money is either being taxed by other countries or being taken over by foreign competitors in an inversion -- typically, when an American company incorporates abroad so its earnings are no longer subject to American taxes. &nbsp;Brady says the result is an erosion of our tax base and a lock-out effect of American capital being \xe2\x80\x9ctrapped\xe2\x80\x9d abroad that can be solved by fixing our uncompetitive tax code.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Presidential Proposal</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The President\xe2\x80\x99s FY 2017 budget contains a surprising source of new revenue to pay for its spending programs \xe2\x80\x93 a major piece of international tax policy reform: a six-year, $478 billion public-works program for highway, bridge and transit upgrades, half of it to be financed with a one-time, 14 percent tax on U.S. companies\xe2\x80\x99 overseas profits and a 19 percent rate thereafter. &nbsp;The issue of companies holding foreign profits at locations abroad, where they are exempt from taxation until repatriated, has vexed policy makers on both sides for some time. &nbsp;It\xe2\x80\x99s estimated that these profits add up to nearly $2 trillion. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The issue of companies holding foreign profits at locations abroad, thereby exempt from taxation unless those profits are brought home, has vexed policy makers on both sides for some time. &nbsp;Microsoft Corp., Apple Inc., Google Inc. and five other tech firms now account for more than a fifth of the $2.10 trillion in profits that U.S. companies are holding overseas. &nbsp;In keeping with the idea that Obama\xe2\x80\x99s final budget is \xe2\x80\x9cmore politics than policy,\xe2\x80\x9d these revenue-gaining proposals are meant to spark discussion more so than be a model for laws going forward. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Upcoming/Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Customs Bill</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Municipal Bond Rule</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Budget Irresolution </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>International Tax Status &nbsp;(Feb. 11)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) </span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Feb 10, 2016, at 7:41 PM, Dana &lt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&gt; wrote:</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Chair of the Federal Reserve went before House Financial Services to provide a report on the nation\'s economic condition, a kind of bi-annual checkup. No news was made, no fireworks went off and no market mood swings occurred. &nbsp;As for the Fed\'s next move, it\'s wait-and-see a little while longer. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>We thought it might happen in March, signs pointed to it. &nbsp;Now, the guess is June (sound familiar?) &nbsp;For details, don\'t wait, see below.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best, </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>----------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Economic Checkup</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fed Chair Yellen testified before House Financial Services this morning for the Federal Reserve\xe2\x80\x99s bi-annual Monetary Policy Report. &nbsp;These appearances allow Yellen to explain the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s, actually the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC)\xe2\x80\x99s, analysis and projections regarding America\'s economic performance as well as to signal the factors underlying its actions in the months ahead. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The rate change in December 2015 was the first time the Fed raised rates since 2006 -- some worry that even a modest increase in rates at this juncture would further slow already limited economic growth after years of uncertainty.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Basics</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The bottom line: the FOMC won\xe2\x80\x99t rollback rates in March and it\xe2\x80\x99s not likely to raise them either. &nbsp;The Fed likes what it sees in the labor market, wage growth looks strong, and emerging market missteps continue to be a threat to the US economy but perhaps not an immediate one. &nbsp;The next rate move is almost certain to be an increase but it could wait until June or later. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yellen reiterated much of the FOMC statement from last month: &nbsp;the labor market remains strong, but shows some signs of remaining slack, that the low inflation we have seen is caused by \xe2\x80\x9ctransitory\xe2\x80\x9d effects (low energy prices), and that global market uncertainty creates some level of risk for slow growth at home and abroad. &nbsp;Though Yellen did not make a prediction on how long these transitory market effects would last, a number of forecasts for oil prices show the dip lasting through 2016.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Expanding on global growth issues, Yellen said "These developments, if they prove persistent, could weigh on the outlook for economic activity and the labor market, although declines in longer-term interest rates and oil prices could provide some offset," she added: "Foreign economic developments, in particular, pose risks to US economic growth." </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Partisan Review</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The GOP is generally critical of "accommodative" (lower) Fed rates. &nbsp;&nbsp;High-net-worth individuals benefit the most from high rates through dividends and interest from savings. &nbsp;Low rates allow more growth for the middle- and lower-classes at the risk of inflation, tacitly supporting Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 progressive fiscal policy goals. &nbsp;Some conservative economists have gone so far as to blame low interest rates pushed by the Fed in the 1990\xe2\x80\x99s for the market meltdown in 2007, claiming that cheap credit was the cause of the overheated housing market.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Strong Labor Market</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Discussing the labor market in greater detail, Yellen pointed to the cumulative increase in employment since 2010 of 13 million jobs. &nbsp;The rate in January fell to 4.9 percent, 0.8 points below its level one year ago; measures of labor market conditions such as the number of people who are working part-time but want to move to full-time positions and the number of individuals who want to work but haven\xe2\x80\x99t searched recently are also decreasing steadily. &nbsp;Regarding these broader labor market indicators Yellen testified that \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6 these measures remain above the levels seen prior to the recession, suggesting that some slack in labor markets remains. Thus, while labor market conditions have improved substantially, there is still room for further sustainable improvement."</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Forward Guidance</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>As always, Yellen was careful not to give hints on what the Fed is planning to do in future meetings; speaking on the path forward for the Fed Funds rate Yellen said \xe2\x80\x9cOf course, monetary policy is by no means on a preset course. The actual path of the federal funds rate will depend on what incoming data tell us about the economic outlook, and we will regularly reassess what level of the federal funds rate is consistent with achieving and maintaining maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yellen was asked about the chances of the FOMC rolling back the rate hike it announced in December: &nbsp;"I do not expect the FOMC is going to be soon in the situation where it\'s necessary to cut rates If the FOMC delayed the start of policy normalization for too long, it might have to tighten policy relatively abruptly in the future to keep the economy from overheating and inflation from significantly overshooting its objective. Such an abrupt tightening could increase the risk of pushing the economy into recession." </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Comment on Dodd-Frank</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>During the Q&amp;A portion of her testimony, Yellen was asked about financial regulation, both in terms of breaking up the banks and enforcing the regulations brought on by Dodd-Frank. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>In response to being asked if the Fed is trying to break up the banks, she responded: "We are using our powers to make sure that a systemically important institution could fail, and it would not have systemic consequences for the country." Her answer was interesting, because she\'s not outright saying the banks will be broken up or reduced, just that the Fed is trying to ensure that even if they did fail, it wouldn\'t negatively effect the economy.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yellen was also asked about the burden of new Dodd-Frank regulations on banks. She responded: "For our part, we\'re focused on doing everything that we conceivably can to minimize and reduce the burden on these banking organizations. We\'ve been conducting an EGRPRA review to identify potential burdens that our regulations impose." An EGRPRA review is connected to the Economic Growth and Regulatory Paperwork Reduction Act, which requires regulations imposed on financial institutions to be reviewed by the agencies at least once every 10 years. The purpose is to prevent burdensome regulations that could hinder a bank\'s ability to serve its customers. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Bottom Line</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fed watchers make their living by trying to predict what the FOMC will or won\xe2\x80\x99t do at their meetings, and on days when Yellen is scheduled to testify before Congress you can bet that they\xe2\x80\x99re listening intently. &nbsp;While Yellen was careful not to project the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s moves, the general sentiment in the markets is that FOMC won\xe2\x80\x99t be raising rates at its March meeting. &nbsp;The CME Group FedWatch tool, which estimates FOMC rate hikes based on its futures prices, predicts a 95% probability that the Fed will maintain its current rate target in March. &nbsp;Some forecasters go even further -- expecting that the funds rate won\xe2\x80\x99t be raised all year. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Traders see the ongoing economic struggles of emerging economies, particularly in China, as evidence that the Fed won\xe2\x80\x99t continue with its scheduled 4 rate hikes this year. &nbsp;Certainly, considering the testimony today that 1) continued emerging market uncertainty can weigh down the US economy and 2) that poor performance in the US economy would cause the Fed to change course on its rate hike schedule, a link between poor emerging market performance and fewer Fed rate hikes seems plausible. &nbsp;Certainly the trading on Fed fund futures indicates that the markets believe this is the case.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>-------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Steady &nbsp;(Feb. 10)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Fin Reg Proposals &nbsp;(Jan. 5)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Year-End Review: Fiscal Policy (Jan. 1) &nbsp;Year-End Review: Fin. Reg. &nbsp;(Dec. 29) &nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec. 15)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Omnibus Situation &nbsp;(Dec. 14)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>FY 2016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Customs Bill &nbsp;(Dec. 8)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Extender Negotiations &nbsp;(Dec. 6) o</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Brown on HFT &nbsp;(Dec. 4)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Shelby 2.0 Update &nbsp;(Dec. 3)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>----</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Feb 9, 2016, at 7:42 PM, Dana &lt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&gt; wrote:</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Mike &amp; Co. --</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Today, President Obama submitted his eighth and final budget proposal to Congress. &nbsp;It tops the $4 trillion mark for the first time. &nbsp;&nbsp;Despite the historical tendency for lame duck presidential budgets to be treated as scrap paper -- this one won\'t even be accorded the courtesy of a hearing in House Budget -- there are a few noteworthy proposals and initiatives which, if nothing else, are likely to generate discussion on the Hill and off. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>That\xe2\x80\x99s the real purpose of this budget -- to help frame the debate in 2016 about where America is headed what the nation\'s priorities should be. &nbsp;A number of the proposals in this budget resonate with issues and themes already being debated. &nbsp;Candidates in particular seeking to emphasize support for or opposition to the President have a new set of proposals at their disposal. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>What is new and noteworthy in the White House budget and what\'s next for it? &nbsp;Detail below. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Special thanks to those of you in NH tonight. &nbsp;Fingers crossed and stay tuned this way: &nbsp;&nbsp;<a href="http://politi.co/20n5W2w">http://politi.co/20n5W2w</a> </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>---------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Obama Administration put forth a myriad of budget proposals revolving around a variety of issues. &nbsp;Below are thoughts on some of the most significant of these from a fiscal and financial regulatory perspective: </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;$10/Barrel Transportation Tax</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>A perennial favorite of Democrats has made a return in the Obama budget: &nbsp;a $10.25 per barrel tax on oil, $319 billion in revenue from which will go toward funding \xe2\x80\x9ca 21st Century Clean Transportation Plan to upgrade the nation\xe2\x80\x99s transportation system, improve resilience and reduce emissions." &nbsp;The proposed tax is a simplified version of \xe2\x80\x9ccarbon taxation\xe2\x80\x9d policies, which aim to tax energy producers and oil companies based on the level of pollution they produce; \xe2\x80\x9ccap and trade\xe2\x80\x9d was a similar policy idea but with more complicated implementation. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The tax will be phased in over five years and levied against oil companies, with the revenue to help fund clean energy initiatives like expanding high-speed rail systems and also to increase national infrastructure spending. &nbsp;The appeal of this flat-tax on oil is its simplicity \xe2\x80\x93- there is nothing complicated about charging oil companies $10.25 per barrel of oil, meaning there\xe2\x80\x99s no way for them to shirk the charge. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Supporting the tax would lend candidates some environmental bonafides, but might be seen as a backdoor &nbsp;tax on the middle-class. Though paid for by oil companies, the &nbsp;price is expected to be passed along to consumers through higher prices. &nbsp;The tax is expected to increase the price of gasoline by 25 cents per gallon.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Funding Fin. Reg. Like it Matters </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama proposes to double the budget for Wall Street regulators SEC and CFTC over ten years, beginning with an 11 percent increase for SEC and 32 percent for CFTC in 2017. &nbsp;Clinton has a lot to like in this particular section \xe2\x80\x93 she\xe2\x80\x99s the only candidate who has defended Dodd-Frank and is campaigning on proposals to strengthen current regulations, including through greater budgets for regulatory agencies. &nbsp;Leaders for both regulators have complained that their responsibilities far outstrip their budget. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The proposal is more realistic than the oil tax, although not necessarily something that will definitely be enacted. &nbsp;The SEC has called for increased funding recently. &nbsp;SEC chairman Mary Jo White asked at a House Financial Services Committee hearing in November for $1.8 billion in funding for fiscal 2017. &nbsp;In a time when Republicans are looking to reduce regulatory burdens against banks, an increase in regulators\xe2\x80\x99 budgets highlights the difference in priorities on Wall Street. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;Boosting R and D</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The budget increases R&amp;D funding by four percent for a total of $152 billion in 2017; among changes are a doubling of clean energy research and funding a $1 billion cancer \xe2\x80\x9cMoonshot\xe2\x80\x9d research program aimed at eliminating the disease. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>\xe2\x80\xa2 &nbsp;&nbsp;Apprenticeship Training Fund</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The budget establishes a $2 billion mandatory Apprenticeship Training Fund \xe2\x80\x93 meant to double the number of apprenticeships across the United States. &nbsp;Only HRC has talked about the need for increasing the number of apprenticeships in the country during the election, favoring a tax-credit policy rather than direct funding. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Congressional Prospects</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\xe2\x80\x99s proposal is not only a prelude to battle. &nbsp;Lawmakers and the administration will have to strike some sort of deal to keep the government running when the current fiscal year ends on Sept. 30 \xe2\x80\x94 most likely a continuing resolution to keep the lights on through the election and early into 2017. &nbsp;In a sign that Obama isn\xe2\x80\x99t looking for a knock-down spending fight this year, the president\xe2\x80\x99s proposal abides by the discretionary caps for fiscal 2017 set by last year\xe2\x80\x99s bipartisan budget deal. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Congressional leadership may have a fight on its hands even without Obama making waves \xe2\x80\x93 if the Freedom Caucus membership decides to make its displeasure on the budget known then it could cause rancor amongst the GOP. &nbsp;In a year when the party is desperate to project an image of capable leadership, in part by passing a complete budget for the first time since 1997, a blow-up between Ryan and the back-benchers would amount to nothing less than catastrophe.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>At a more granular level, Obama\xe2\x80\x99s blueprint is a grab-bag of Democratic priorities. &nbsp;The administration is once again calling for expanding early education in his 2017 budget, asking for more pre-K grants, a child care expansion and a small boost to Head Start. &nbsp;The budget boosts spending for Obamacare Medicaid expansion by $2.6 billion over a decade, designed to be an enticement to the 19 holdout states that have yet to take effect.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Republicans and the Budget</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Republicans have a different plan for the budget this year, naturally. &nbsp;Speaker Ryan has stated that he intends to pass the budget and all 12 appropriations through the house -- a feat that hasn\'t been accomplished in two decades.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Republicans have a different plan for the budget this year, naturally. &nbsp;Speaker Ryan has stated that he intends to pass the budget and all 12 appropriations through the house - a feat that hasn\'t been accomplished since 1997. &nbsp;Although Ryan and the GOP House leadership hope to gain the faith of the American people back by bringing about the return of regular order, they face a tight calendar and the political implications of an election year -- not to mention internal opposition in the form of the Freedom Caucus. &nbsp;Should the back-benchers feel their concerns aren\xe2\x80\x99t being adequately addressed, they may try to disrupt the passage of appropriations bills. &nbsp;The care and feeding of these members on budget matters may be turn out to be one of the toughest challenges Ryan will face this year.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>-----------------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Obama\'s FY17 Budget &nbsp;(Feb. 9) </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Tax Talk of the Town &nbsp;(Feb. 3)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Defending Dodd-Frank &nbsp;(Feb. 2)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fiscal Pol: Deficit/Debt Dormancy (Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>HRC\'s Tax Policy &nbsp;(Jan. 17)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Agenda on the Hill &nbsp;(Jan. 16)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Glass-Steagall, Take 2 &nbsp;(Jan. 13)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>2016 Tax Policy Issues &nbsp;(Jan. 8)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders Proposals/GS &amp; TBTF (Jan. 7)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote
