type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>On Jan 28, 2016, at 10:12 AM, Dana &lt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&gt; wrote:</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dear Mike &amp; Co.,</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Pre-primary endorsements from Party leaders in tight contests are rare and sometimes understated. &nbsp;To wit, President Obama remarks this week that HRC is as prepared to be president as any non-Vice President as anyone: \xe2\x80\x9cI think that what Hillary presents is a recognition that translating values into governance and delivering the goods is ultimately the job of politics, making a real-life difference to people in their day-to-day lives.\xe2\x80\x9d</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yesterday, House Democratic leader Nancy starting doing precisely that, assessing the centerpiece of Sanders\' platform: &nbsp;"He\'s talking about a single-payer, and that\'s not going to happen. I mean, does anybody in this room think that we\'re going to be discussing a single-payer? ... We\'re not running on any platform of raising taxes." </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Far from the cauldron of Congress and the icy campaign trail was an announcement by the Fed with implications for the overall economy and for the election year ahead. &nbsp;More on the Fed\'s statement and its implications below. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Please let me know if you have any questions or issue coverage requests. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Best,</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Dana</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>-----------------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed\'s Statement</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) of the Federal Reserve decided yesterday not to raise rates in January. &nbsp;Last month, the Fed voted to raise interest rates for the first time in nine years, setting its rate target between 0.25 and 0.5 percent. &nbsp;Today\'s statement reaffirmed this decision, noting that recent market turbulence had not stayed the Fed from its plan to continue \xe2\x80\x9conly gradual increases in the federal funds rate.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;Speculation and hope are rife that the FOMC will hold off raising rates in March and wait until June. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>But the statement today indicated no change in the Fed\xe2\x80\x99s plan for previously outlined &nbsp;rate increases, four 0.25 percent increases this year, with total increases of one percent this year and next. &nbsp;However, the FOMC is largely comprised of dovish voters, who may change tack if current market corrections continue. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Market Reaction</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Dow Jones Industrial average is down from 17.759 on December 16 to 15,951 today; the S&amp;P 500 has declined from 2,073 to 1,879 over the same period. &nbsp;The </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fed however expressed confidence in continuing economic growth, calling low inflation and the decline in energy prices \xe2\x80\x9ctransitory\xe2\x80\x9d and predicting 2 percent inflation in the medium-term as energy prices rise again. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>In a nod to beleaguered investors, the Committee wrote that it \xe2\x80\x9c... is closely monitoring global economic and financial developments and is assessing their implications for the labor market and inflation, and for the balance of risks to the outlook.\xe2\x80\x9d &nbsp;So the Fed has, unusually, acknowledged the global scope of its deliberations. &nbsp;FOMC also indicated a focus on \xe2\x80\x9clabor market indicators [which] will continue to strengthen."</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>For now, though inflation is running just 0.4 percent, well below its two percent target, the Fed has not disavowed its plan to raise rates four times this year. &nbsp;&nbsp;This cannot be welcome to global equine markets. &nbsp;Domestic and global capital markets have already lost roughly ten percent since the December rate hike. &nbsp;Fed policy may be having a decelerating effect on growth and so could be a marginal drag on Democratic prospects. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>New FOMC Members</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The FOMC is made up of rotating board of seven voting members taken from Board of Governors members as well as regional bank officials; these members rotate on an annual basis at the first meeting of each year. &nbsp;The 2016 committee members are listed below (identified as"hawks," those favoring tight monetary policy or "doves," supporting more accommodative policy). </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Janet L. Yellen, Board of Governors, Chair (dove)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>William C. Dudley, New York, Vice Chair (dove)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Lael Brainard, Board of Governors (dove)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>James Bullard, St. Louis (hawk)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Stanley Fischer, Board of Governors (hawk)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Esther L. George, Kansas City (hawk)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Loretta J. Mester, Cleveland (hawk)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Jerome H. Powell, Board of Governors (swing)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Eric Rosengren, Boston (dove)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Daniel K. Tarullo, Board of Governors (dove)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>New members this year are James Bullard, Esther George, Loretta Mester, and Eric Rosengren. &nbsp;The FOMC consists of 12 voting members, with two nominees awaiting Senate confirmation. &nbsp;A shift in the balance of power between hawks and doves may occur but the doves hold a slim majority for now.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Code Breaking</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Fed watchers have made an art form out of reading between the lines of these policy releases, even the most benign of which can cause huge swings in markets (the Dow dropped over 200 points in the wake of today\xe2\x80\x99s release). &nbsp;Fed statements are famously difficult to parse but one point was unmistakable: the Fed is keeping a close eye on the labor market -- employment and participation rates, wages, etc. -- as a leading indicator for inflation and overall growth perhaps more than any other variable. &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Campaign Consequences</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>None of the candidates has commented on today\xe2\x80\x99s release, not surprisingly, but the policy may draw ire from some on the right, who oppose fiat rate-targeting (though it took no action today) and the left, where lowering rather than raising rate is preferred (except for holders of fixed income securities). &nbsp;</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sen. &nbsp;Sanders, true to his reputation of standing far outside the Democratic fold, has long opposed the Fed for being too involved with the bankers they are meant to be regulating. &nbsp;Sanders has called for reform measures at the Fed, including prohibiting people serving on bank boards from serving on the Fed at the same time. </span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed was confident that economic growth would continue on its steady pace, indicating strength in labor markets and downplaying both financial market reactions and diving commodities prices. &nbsp;The FOMC sets monetary policy on a long-term basis; the full ramifications of their decisions aren\xe2\x80\x99t felt until months or years out, so any contention that the economy is strong enough to handle higher interest rates is essentially an endorsement of macroeconomic policy in the last few years. Democratic candidates will need to hammer this point home - but it is yet to be seen if voters will understand the message that Democratic policies are responsible for the sunny outlook for the American economy, especially compared to Western Europe, Latin America, and Asia.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Below is the first sentence of the FOMC statement from yesterday, edited to reflect changes from last month\'s statement:</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>For immediate releaserelease at 2:00 p.m. EST</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Information received since the Federal Open Market Committee met in OctoDecember suggests that economic activity has been expanding at a moderate pacelabor market conditions improved further even as economic growth slowed late last year. Household spending and business fixed investment have been increasing at solidmoderate rates in recent months, and the housing sector has improved further; however, net exports have been soft and inventory investment slowed. A range of recent labor market indicators, including ongoistrong job gains and declining unemployment, shows further improvement and confirms that underutilization of labor resources has diminished appreciably since early this year, points to some additional decline in underutilization of labor resources. Inflation has continued to run below the Committee\'s 2 percent longer-run objective, partly reflecting declines in energy prices and in prices of non-energy imports. Market-based measures of inflation compensation remain low; somedeclined further; survey-based measures of longer-term inflation expectations have edged downare little changed, on balance, in recent months.</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>--------------------</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Recent Updates</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span></span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Fed Holds Rates, for Now &nbsp;(Jan. 28)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Debate Myths Challenged &nbsp;(Jan. 25)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Regulating the Regulators &nbsp;(Jan. 21)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><span>Sanders\' Tax/Healthcare Policy &nbsp;(Jan 20)</span><br></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote type="cite"><blockquote those who would rather see it ramped up. &amp;nbsp;Sen.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D=</span><br><span>"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;Shelby, Senate Banking Cha=</span><br><span>ir, introduced the Financial Regulatory Improvement Act of 2015, a grab-bag o=</span><br><span>f exceptions and exemptions from regulations, mostly for banks with between $=</span><br><span>50 and $500 billion in assets.&amp;nbsp; In a similar vein, Sens Warner, Portman=</span><br><span>, and Collins introduced the Independent Agency Regulatory Analysis Act&amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;to require that regulators undertake a cost-benefit analysis of any rules t=</span><br><span>hey wish to implement.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 0in=</span><br><span>0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;On the=</span><br><span>flip side, Sens. McCain and Warren=E2=80=99s 21&lt;span style=3D"font-size: 12=</span><br><span>px;"&gt;st&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;Century Glass-Steagall Act proposes to split commercial a=</span><br><span>nd investment banks in a bid to finally kill off the TBTF problem.&amp;nbsp; Sen=</span><br><span>s. Warren and Vitter teamed up early in 2015 to introduce a package of amend=</span><br><span>ments to the Federal Reserve Act =E2=80=93- that bill notably would set forw=</span><br><span>ard stricter regulations when an entity is considered insolvent, and therefo=</span><br><span>re ineligible for Federal Reserve loans, as well as require that the Fed len=</span><br><span>d money to distressed institutions at market rates.&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p c=</span><br><span>lass=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-co=</span><br><span>lor: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The Regulators\' Agenda&amp;nbsp;&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backg=</span><br></blockquote><span>round-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Under Basel III requirements for large=</span><br><span>banks to satisfy Liquidity Coverage Ratios (LCR) were adopted by a number o=</span><br><span>f national regulators, including the Federal Reserve.&amp;nbsp; While the Fed ha=</span><br><span>s floated a rule change allowing some municipal bonds to count as High Quali=</span><br><span>ty Liquid Assets (HQLA), that hasn=E2=80=99t stopped Rep. Luke Messer from p=</span><br><span>roposing HR 2209 to force regulators allow a greater share of munis to count=</span><br><span>as HQLA (see Update, Feb. 18).&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" s=</span><br><span>tyle=3D"margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 25=</span><br><span>5, 255, 0);"&gt;The Fed is also working on implementing a rule on Single-Counte=</span><br><span>rparty Credit Limits (SCCL), setting boundaries on credit exposure between l=</span><br><span>arge banks or major counterparties.&amp;nbsp; The rule is meant to prevent banks=</span><br><span>from becoming overexposed to other financial institutions, preventing them f=</span><br><span>rom taking overly large losses in the event that the counterparty fails.&amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p; Analysts suspect that firms are nearly $100 billion over the limits impos=</span><br><span>ed by this rule, but Yellen says it is necessary to set a =E2=80=9Cbright li=</span><br><span>ne=E2=80=9D on credit exposure.&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" s=</span><br><span>tyle=3D"margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 0);"&gt;SIFIs Moving Forward&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=</span><br><span>=3D"margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 0);"&gt;There is no doubt that the upcoming MetLife ruling will be a critic=</span><br><span>al pivot point for how regulators interact with SIFIs.&amp;nbsp; If the FSOC is r=</span><br><span>equired to retract the firm=E2=80=99s SIFI status it will open the regulator=</span><br><span>up for a whole slew of challenges from other banks and institutions.&amp;nbsp; T=</span><br><span>he fate of Congressional proposals to restrict regulator=E2=80=99s efforts, e=</span><br><span>ither by determining rules for them or by burdening them with regulations of=</span><br><span>their own, should be seen as the start of a potential sea change in the reg=</span><br><span>ulatory climate.&amp;nbsp; During his Monday meeting, President Obama warned of t=</span><br><span>his: "If there is a significant challenge in terms of regulating Wall Street=</span><br><span>and regulating our financial sector it is primarily coming from certain mem=</span><br><span>bers of Congress who are consistently pressuring independent regulators to b=</span><br><span>ack off.=E2=80=9D&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margi=</span><br><span>n: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=</span><br><span>It is not a bad time to be a SIFI in America =E2=80=93 it=E2=80=99s certainl=</span><br><span>y much better to be one now than in 2010.&amp;nbsp; While DFA has forced restruc=</span><br><span>turing and streamlining to occur, events like the GE Capital sell-off may pr=</span><br><span>ove to be exceptions that prove the rule rather than the new normal for SIFI=</span><br><span>s, especially if MetLife wins its case against regulators.&amp;nbsp; President O=</span><br><span>bama was right to point to Congress as the cause of regulatory gridlock; the=</span><br><span>political will seen after the economic collapse has largely evaporated, giv=</span><br><span>ing SIFIs far more breathing room and opening up opportunities to push throu=</span><br><span>gh =E2=80=9Cregulatory reform=E2=80=9D measures.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D=</span><br><span>"color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.701961); -webkit-composition-fil=</span><br><span>l-color: rgba(130, 98, 83, 0.0980392); text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;=</span><br><span>margin: 0in 0in 12pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255,=</span><br><span>0);"&gt;The bill provides $250 million to assist the residents of&amp;nbsp;Flint, M=</span><br><span>ichigan and other American cities experiencing critical problems with their w=</span><br><span>ater supplies by&amp;nbsp;increasing funding for Drinking Water Act State Revolv=</span><br><span>ing Funds and provide start-up funding for the new Water Infrastructure Fina=</span><br><span>nce and Innovation Act.&amp;nbsp; text-decoration: -webk=</span><br><span>it-letterpress; margin: 0in 0in 12pt 0.5in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color=</span><br><span>: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=C2=B7&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$=</span><br><span>100 million for Drinking Water State Revolving Funds (SRFs) accessible by an=</span><br><span>y state with a drinking water emergency.&amp;nbsp; It requires states to submit p=</span><br><span>lans explaining how the money will be spent to address the emergency before f=</span><br><span>unding is provided. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Funds that remain after 18 months will be di=</span><br><span>stributed to all states under the existing SRF formula.&amp;nbsp;&lt;o:p&gt;&lt;/o:p&gt;&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoListParagraphCxSpMiddle" style=3D"color: rgba(0, 0, 0,=</span><br><span>0.701961); 255, 0);"&gt;Puerto Rico=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s Time Bomb&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The Puerto Rican d=</span><br><span>ebt crisis has been an ongoing concern for both Congress, Wall Street and th=</span><br><span>e Obama administration for some years now =E2=80=93 the territory=E2=80=99s b=</span><br><span>ond ratings have been steadily dropping into the junk category and fell from=</span><br><span>A- in 2005 to CCC+ last April.&amp;nbsp; At the heart of the matter is $70 bill=</span><br><span>ion in bonds that Puerto Rico owes and says it cannot pay on.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgrou=</span><br><span>nd-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Because Puerto Rican bonds are tax exempt=</span><br><span>in all 50 states and the District of Columbia, making them incredibly popul=</span><br><span>ar investments for mutual funds, pensioners, and big banks.&amp;nbsp; Over 20 pe=</span><br><span>rcent of mutual funds in the United States hold at least some Puerto Rican b=</span><br><span>onds, with $11.3 billion in portfolio, with a further $15 billion in bonds h=</span><br><span>eld by hedge funds.&amp;nbsp; Now that the territory=E2=80=99s bonds are in the =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9Cjunk=E2=80=9D category, pension funds and insurance firms are unable t=</span><br><span>o hold them any longer.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12=</span><br><span>pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The diver=</span><br><span>se list of bond holders has thrown a wrench into the plans of those who woul=</span><br><span>d rather allow Puerto Rico to default on its obligations =E2=80=93 something=</span><br><span>which would require legislative action (the territory doesn=E2=80=99t have t=</span><br><span>hat luxury, unlike states).&amp;nbsp; If Puerto Rico is allowed to renege on its=</span><br><span>contractual agreements, the argument goes, then it creates a moral hazard f=</span><br><span>or other entities to do the same rather than make the tough choices necessar=</span><br><span>y to honor their obligations.&amp;nbsp; The fact that many of these bonds are es=</span><br><span>sentially held by ordinary Americans (through mutual funds and pensions) mak=</span><br><span>es the argument all that stronger for many representatives.&amp;nbsp; A state ha=</span><br><span>sn=E2=80=99t declared bankruptcy since Arkansas did so in 1933.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p=</span><br><span>class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-c=</span><br><span>olor: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Moral hazard is inherent in a debt restructur=</span><br><span>ing deal; here, the path for Puerto Rico toward capital markets after anythi=</span><br><span>ng of the sort would still be an especially painful one (see: Argentina).&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp; Additionally, there are few serious proposals to grant the island full C=</span><br><span>hapter 9 status. &amp;nbsp;Most opt instead for some form of negotiated haircut a=</span><br><span>greement combined with extending maturities on the bonds; these proposals ar=</span><br><span>e likely to succeed, considering Puerto Rico is almost certainly unable to m=</span><br><span>aintain its bond payment schedule without a restructuring agreement.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgro=</span><br><span>und-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Administration Position&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"ba=</span><br><span>ckground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Testifying before the House Committ=</span><br><span>ee on Natural Resources on Feb 25, Treasury official Antonio Weiss warned la=</span><br><span>wmakers that Puerto Rico needs =E2=80=9Can immediate solution=E2=80=9D if it=</span><br><span>=E2=80=99s to survive past&amp;nbsp;May 1, when a $470 million bond payment is d=</span><br><span>ue.&amp;nbsp; Soon after that,&amp;nbsp;on&amp;nbsp;July 1, a $1.9 billion bond payment w=</span><br><span>ill come due as well =E2=80=93 Puerto Rican representatives have already dec=</span><br><span>lared they cannot meet those payments without assistance.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=</span><br><span>=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: r=</span><br><span>gba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Weiss laid out the administration=E2=80=99s two-part=</span><br><span>plan: first the territory must be allowed to restructure its debt obligatio=</span><br><span>ns, second a fiscal oversight board should be established to assist the isla=</span><br><span>nd with managing its finances.&amp;nbsp; Importantly, Weiss stopped short of adv=</span><br><span>ocating for bankruptcy protection for Puerto Rico and told the committee tha=</span><br><span>t =E2=80=9Can advisory board is not adequate to do the job=E2=80=9D alone.&amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;House Democrats voiced=</span><br><span>concern over the financial oversight board, Rep. Luis Guti=C3=A9rrez: =E2=80=</span><br><span>=9CThey=E2=80=99re saying that there=E2=80=99s a joint responsibility, but i=</span><br><span>t seems to me that all of the responsibility is being weighed on the people o=</span><br><span>f Puerto Rico.=E2=80=9D&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D=</span><br><span>"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);=</span><br><span>"&gt;Meanwhile Republicans claimed that any plan to restructure Puerto Rican de=</span><br><span>bt was a non-starter; a few hours after the hearing the Republican Study Com=</span><br><span>mittee announced it would oppose any plan including such a provision.&amp;nbsp;&amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;"Changing the rules mid-game would be unfair to Puerto Rico=E2=80=99s c=</span><br><span>reditors who entered into these arrangements with agreed upon terms and woul=</span><br><span>d delegitimize future transactions," said RSC Chairman&amp;nbsp;Bill Flores.&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"backgr=</span><br><span>ound-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Policy Options&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNo=</span><br><span>rmal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255,=</span><br><span>255, 255, 0);"&gt;Until recently the two parties have maintained starkly contr=</span><br><span>asting views on how to best deal with Puerto Rico=E2=80=99s debt crisis =E2=80=</span><br><span>=93 Democrats have pushed for a forced debt restructuring, with some calling=</span><br><span>for the island to be granted Chapter 9 bankruptcy protections, meanwhile Re=</span><br><span>publicans called for a financial oversight council to make the tough fiscal d=</span><br><span>ecisions necessary for Puerto Rico to maintain its debt obligations without r=</span><br><span>eneging on its agreements.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin:=</span><br><span>12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The ad=</span><br><span>ministration, through Weiss, has advocated a middle of the road approach. By=</span><br><span>adopting both proposals and avoiding the further edges of each (no bankrupt=</span><br><span>cy, and no unaccountable board staffed by Wall Streeters), the administratio=</span><br><span>n hopes to find compromise between each group.&amp;nbsp; And it seems like it mi=</span><br><span>ght work.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b st=</span><br><span>yle=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Finding Compromise&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"bac=</span><br><span>kground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Recently, however, the conservative s=</span><br><span>tance against debt restructuring has lessened =E2=80=93 with some Republican=</span><br><span>s saying that they could support a PR bill as long as it doesn=E2=80=99t inc=</span><br><span>lude Chapter 9 bankruptcy.&amp;nbsp; House Natural Resources chair Bob Bishop ha=</span><br><span>s been working on a bill for Puerto Rico that does include some element of d=</span><br><span>ebt restructuring, and recently said =E2=80=9C=E2=80=9CI=E2=80=99m sure RSC w=</span><br><span>ill be satisfied with what we do =E2=80=A6 to say that some element of [debt=</span><br><span>restructuring] could be in there, yeah.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 17.25pt;"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The House is still=</span><br><span>sticking to its end of March deadline set by Speaker Ryan&amp;nbsp;for putting f=</span><br><span>orward a final bill on Puerto Rico on the floor for a vote.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 17.25pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"back=</span><br><span>ground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;_____________________________________=</span><br><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u style=3D"background-color: rgb=</span><br><span>a(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Upcoming/Recent Updates&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>div style=3D"color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.701961); text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;___=</span><br><span>__________________________________&lt;br&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"m=</span><br><span>argin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;font style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;b&gt;A New Caucus&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0=</span><br><span>in;"&gt;&lt;font style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;On Tuesday, R=</span><br><span>eps. Randy Hultgren and Dutch Ruppersberger announced that they have formed t=</span><br><span>he Municipal Finance Caucus to protect the tax-exempt status of municipal de=</span><br><span>bt and reexamine the way it is treated in financial regulations. &amp;nbsp;In 20=</span><br><span>15, Hultgren and Ruppersberger sent a letter (reprinted below) to House lead=</span><br><span>ership&amp;nbsp;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>opposing&amp;nbsp;the President=E2=80=99s proposed 28 percent cap on tax deduct=</span><br></blockquote><span>ions for municipal bonds,&amp;nbsp;signed by over 120 of their colleagues. &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D=</span><br><span>"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Their announcement coincided wit=</span><br><span>h the National Association of State Treasurers=E2=80=99 legislative conferen=</span><br><span>ce in D.C. The same group drafted another letter, signed by more than 600 st=</span><br><span>ate and local officials, which urges the leaders of the House Ways and Means=</span><br><span>Committee and the Senate Finance Committee to reject curbs to the muni exem=</span><br><span>ption.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Who=E2=80=99s in it?&lt;/b=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backg=</span><br></blockquote><span>round-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Right now just the founding representa=</span><br><span>tives have declared their official membership, but it=E2=80=99s foreseeable t=</span><br><span>hat some of the 120 representatives that signed the letter to House leadersh=</span><br><span>ip in 2015 will join as well.&amp;nbsp; It=E2=80=99s also seen a s likely that s=</span><br><span>ome Senators will want to join the caucus, but the founders haven\'t made cle=</span><br><span>ar if bicameral membership is a priority.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" s=</span><br><span>tyle=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255,=</span><br><span>0);"&gt;Is it Bipartisan?&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0=</span><br><span>in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Since 2013 Hu=</span><br><span>ltgren and Ruppersberger have led bipartisan efforts to draft letters of sup=</span><br><span>port for municipal bonds. &amp;nbsp;The signatories to these letters include mem=</span><br><span>bers from both sides of the aisle. &amp;nbsp;Rep. Ruppersberger focuses mostly o=</span><br><span>n local government and is pretty moderate. Rep. Hultgren is a more orthodox c=</span><br><span>onservative Republican.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"marg=</span><br><span>in: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;What=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s the Purpose?&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in=</span><br><span>;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The Caucus plan=</span><br><span>s to defend municipal bonds=E2=80=99 tax exempt status and advocate for regu=</span><br><span>latory changes which favor those bonds.&amp;nbsp; Proposals to limit the tax-exe=</span><br><span>mpt status of these bonds have been floated in recent years.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgroun=</span><br></blockquote><span>d-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;In addition to calling for the bonds to ma=</span><br><span>intain their tax preferred status, the Caucus will push for the passage of H=</span><br><span>R 2209, legislation considering municipal bonds as a&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"ba=</span><br><span>ckground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;High Quality Liquid Asset (&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;HQLA) =E2=80=93=</span><br><span>a particularly contentious issue because of the disagreement over how flexi=</span><br><span>ble these liquidity rules should be from a systemic risk perspective.&amp;nbsp;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"bac=</span><br><span>kground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Positions Taken to Date&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p cl=</span><br><span>ass=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-colo=</span><br><span>r: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The Caucus founders have opposed Obama=E2=80=99s=</span><br><span>2015 proposal to cap municipal bond tax exemption at 28 percent. Rep. Hultg=</span><br><span>ren is also a co-sponsor of HR 2209 =E2=80=93 the bill to set the liquidity f=</span><br><span>or municipal bond assets at Level 2A (see Update, Feb. 18).&amp;nbsp; Hultgren s=</span><br><span>aid the liquidity rules are an example of how regulators misunderstand munic=</span><br><span>ipal bonds, specifically the frequent serial structure of the their issuance=</span><br><span>s.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p xml:lang=3D"en-us" style=3D"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 1=</span><br><span>em 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; word-wrap: brea=</span><br><span>k-word; word-break: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255,=</span><br><span>255, 0);"&gt;Many investors flock to municipal bonds for security. But some fe=</span><br><span>deral regulators trying to shore up the banking system aren\'t convinced the b=</span><br><span>onds would be easy to sell in a crisis.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p xml:lang=3D"en-us=</span><br><span>" style=3D"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 1em 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0p=</span><br><span>x; vertical-align: baseline; word-wrap: break-word; word-break: normal;"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Division of Opinio=</span><br><span>n&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p xml:lang=3D"en-us" style=3D"box-sizing: border-box; margi=</span><br><span>n: 1em 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-align: baseline; word-wrap: b=</span><br><span>reak-word; word-break: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 255, 0);"&gt;Division of opinion on HR 2099 falls along unusual lines, with=</span><br><span>Wall Street, Congress and municipal officials challenging bank regulators\' s=</span><br><span>kepticism toward municipal debt. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgroun=</span><br><span>d-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;At issue are new rules aimed at ensuring b=</span><br><span>anks can raise enough cash during a financial-market meltdown to fund their o=</span><br><span>perations for 30 days. The requirements mean banks have to hold more cash or=</span><br><span>securities that are easily sellable.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color:=</span><br><span>rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p xml:lang=3D"en-us" style=3D"bo=</span><br><span>x-sizing: border-box; margin: 1em 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; vertical-a=</span><br><span>lign: baseline; word-wrap: break-word; word-break: normal;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"b=</span><br><span>ackground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Regulators don\'t think it is the p=</span><br><span>lace of Congress to second guess how they size up securities. Fed Chairwoman=</span><br><span>Janet Yellen, at a congressional hearing Feb. 11, said legislation would "i=</span><br><span>nterfere with our supervisory judgments."&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNor=</span><br><span>mal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 255, 0);"&gt;Big banks such as Citigroup Inc. and Wells Fargo &amp;amp; Co. hav=</span><br><span>e sprung into action in lobbying Congress, along with municipal leaders who f=</span><br><span>ret the rules will diminish bank bond-buying which could raise borrowing cos=</span><br><span>ts on infrastructure projects.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"mar=</span><br><span>gin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Hu=</span><br><span>ltgren also said the caucus will work to update the number of projects that c=</span><br><span>ould be financed by qualified small issue manufacturing bonds, a type of pri=</span><br><span>vate-activity bond whose proceeds can be used to finance manufacturing facil=</span><br><span>ities for small- and mid-sized manufacturers. The tax code provisions on sma=</span><br><span>ll industrial development bonds have not been changed since the 1980s, he sa=</span><br><span>id. Hultgren sponsored a bill last year entitled =E2=80=9CThe Modernizing Am=</span><br><span>erican Manufacturing Bonds Act,=E2=80=9D which was focused on expanding oppo=</span><br><span>rtunities for qualified small issue manufacturing bonds, particularly by cha=</span><br><span>nging the national volume cap set by Congress.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"M=</span><br><span>soNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255=</span><br><span>, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;What can be achieved?&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span s=</span><br><span>tyle=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Caucuses such as this one=</span><br><span>don\'t have the best reputation when it comes to getting things done. &amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>But rules relating to the liquidity value of capital is one of the few polic=</span><br><span>y &amp;nbsp;areas of any kind where there is bipartisan agreement. &amp;nbsp;Municip=</span><br><span>al bonds, in particular, have a universal appeal because of their direct lin=</span><br><span>k to local and state infrastructure projects. &amp;nbsp;At the very least, the c=</span><br><span>aucus will spark some discussion about the best way to both reform existing m=</span><br><span>ethods for funding infrastructure investment and find new ways to fund it.&amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(=</span><br><span>255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;_________________________________&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;div style=3D"color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.701961); -webkit-composition-fill-color=</span><br><span>: rgba(130, 98, 83, 0.0980392); text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;div d=</span><br><span>ir=3D"ltr"&gt;&lt;div dir=3D"ltr"&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u style=3D"background=</span><br><span>-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Recent/Planned Updates&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/d=</span><br><span>iv&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"color: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.701961); Intl Tax Reform&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=</span><br><span>=A2 &amp;nbsp; EU/US Derivatives Deal&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background=</span><br><span>-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp; -webkit-compositio=</span><br><span>n-fill-color: rgba(130, 98, 83, 0.0980392);"&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=3D"text-d=</span><br><span>ecoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;Mike &amp;amp; Co. --&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div sty=</span><br><span>le=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-de=</span><br><span>coration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;I hope everyone\'s had a chance to reflect on=</span><br><span>the magnitude of yesterday\'s hard fought primary wins -- with gratitude to t=</span><br><span>hose who toiled in the field.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -web=</span><br><span>kit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpre=</span><br><span>ss;"&gt;On Saturday night, the campaign debate turns to Flint, Michigan -- to t=</span><br><span>he town and the issues it has come to symbolize. &amp;nbsp; The town\'s water con=</span><br><span>tamination and related problems finally move center stage.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div s=</span><br><span>tyle=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-=</span><br><span>decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;Congress has moved with uncommon alacrity a=</span><br><span>nd bipartisanship in recent weeks on legislation to direct funding to addres=</span><br><span>s the water issue in Flint and elsewhere. &amp;nbsp; Here, we look at the bill\'s=</span><br><span>provisions, its funding steam, and its prospects. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D=</span><br><span>"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decorat=</span><br><span>ion: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;Best,&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit=</span><br><span>-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;=</span><br><span>"&gt;Dana&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-letterpress;"&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;hr style=</span><br><span>=3D"box-sizing: content-box; border-style: solid; border-color: gray; height=</span><br><span>: 0px;"&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div style=3D"text-decoration: -webkit-lette=</span><br><span>rpress;"&gt;&lt;div dir=3D"ltr"&gt;&lt;div dir=3D"ltr"&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"m=</span><br><span>argin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;u style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255=</span><br><span>, 0);"&gt;The Flint Bill -- Provisions &amp;amp; Prospects&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"M=</span><br><span>soNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color=</span><br><span>: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;A bipartisan deal has been reached in the Senate l=</span><br><span>ast week to aid the beleaguered city of Flint, Michigan as it tries to remed=</span><br><span>y its drinking water issues.&amp;nbsp; Sen. Inhofe, the lead GOP Senator on the b=</span><br><span>ill, called it =E2=80=9Ccommon-sense," and noted that the spending is alread=</span><br><span>y programmed and involves no supplemental appropriation. &amp;nbsp; The bill may=</span><br><span>be ready to move forward after Sen. Cruz lifted a hold he had placed on the=</span><br><span>bill last week. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Mike Lee is still a hold-out.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p=</span><br><span>class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backg=</span><br><span>round-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The bill provides $250 million to assi=</span><br><span>st the residents of Flint, Michigan and other American cities experiencing c=</span><br><span>ritical problems with their water supplies by&amp;nbsp;increasing funding for Dr=</span><br><span>inking Water Act State Revolving Funds and provide start-up funding for the n=</span><br><span>ew Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act. &amp;nbsp;It also provides:&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span st=</span><br><span>yle=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp; $100 mill=</span><br><span>ion for Drinking Water State Revolving Funds (SRFs) accessible by any state w=</span><br><span>ith a drinking water emergency.&amp;nbsp; It requires states to submit plans exp=</span><br><span>laining how the money will be spent to address the emergency before funding i=</span><br><span>s provided. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Funds that remain after 18 months will be distribute=</span><br><span>d to all states under the existing SRF formula.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=</span><br><span>=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-=</span><br><span>color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp; $70 million in funding to b=</span><br><span>ack secured loans made under the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innova=</span><br><span>tion Act (WIFIA).&amp;nbsp; A federal investment of $70 million could support se=</span><br><span>cured loans of up to $4.2 billion to address water and wastewater infrastruc=</span><br><span>ture needs across the country, according to Sen. Inhofe=E2=80=99s office.&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp; All states and all communities with clean water and drinking water infra=</span><br><span>structure needs are eligible for this assistance.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p cla=</span><br><span>ss=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgroun=</span><br><span>d-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp; $50 million for various i=</span><br><span>n authorized health programs for national use to address and prevent impacts=</span><br><span>from exposure to lead.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"marg=</span><br><span>in-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0=</span><br><span>);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Where will the money come from? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;The package has been f=</span><br><span>ully paid for -- it redirects appropriations by taking funds from the Advanc=</span><br><span>ed Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (ATVM) Fund, which offers loans for aut=</span><br><span>o companies.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0=</span><br><span>.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Does t=</span><br><span>hat matter?&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Per Sen. Inhofe =E2=80=9C[the ATVM is] a failed p=</span><br><span>rogram that hasn=E2=80=99t been used in more than a year and has only issued=</span><br><span>five loans since 2008."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bo=</span><br><span>ttom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>b&gt;More on ATVM&lt;/b&gt;: The ATVM program is authorized to award up to $25 billio=</span><br><span>n in loans; there is no deadline for completing such loan commitments. Congr=</span><br><span>ess funded the program in 2009, when it appropriated $7.5 billion to cover t=</span><br><span>he subsidy cost for the $25 billion in loans, as well as $10 million for pro=</span><br><span>gram implementation. Since the start of the program, DOE has awarded $8.4 bi=</span><br><span>llion in loans to five companies. As of January 2015, ATVM has $16.6 billion=</span><br><span>in remaining loan authority. No new loans have been made since 2011. Two co=</span><br><span>mpanies =E2=80=94 Fisker and the Vehicle Production Group =E2=80=94 were una=</span><br><span>ble to make payments on their loans, and DOE auctioned the loans off in the f=</span><br><span>all of 2013. Tesla paid off all of its loan in 2013, nine years ahead of sch=</span><br><span>edule.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001=</span><br><span>pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Criticisms=</span><br><span>of ATVM:&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;The unobligated funds remaining for the program have been=</span><br><span>a point of contention in recent appropriations debates. The House has voted=</span><br><span>several times to transfer some of the unused appropriation for the ATVM sub=</span><br><span>sidy costs to other purposes. None of these transfers were enacted. Other le=</span><br><span>gislators have sought to expand the program. Two recent federal reports call=</span><br><span>for rescinding the program=E2=80=99s unobligated balance: the FY2015 budget=</span><br><span>resolution reported by the House Budget Committee calls for outright rescis=</span><br><span>sion, and an April 2014 GAO report recommends Congress consider taking&lt;b&gt;&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&lt;/b&gt;the same step unless DOE can generate new demand for the program.&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D=</span><br><span>"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Legislative Strategy: &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Architects o=</span><br><span>f the bipartisan deal put out a hotline request to see if anyone would objec=</span><br><span>t to a series of procedural moves that would split Flint aid off the energy b=</span><br><span>ill (S. 2012), attach it to a House bill (H.R. 4470) sponsored by Reps. Dan K=</span><br><span>ildee and Fred Upton, allow voice votes on 30 amendments to the energy bill,=</span><br><span>and allow roll call votes on eight additional amendments. Michigan Sens. De=</span><br><span>bbie Stabenow and Gary Peters said Democrats are on board, but in order to a=</span><br><span>chieve unanimous consent, Republicans need to sign on.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p cl=</span><br><span>ass=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin-bottom: 0.0001pt;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgrou=</span><br><span>nd-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Will it pass?&lt;/b&gt;&amp;nbsp; The Flint pack=</span><br><span>age and the energy bill amendments would come to a vote only after the Senat=</span><br><span>e gets unanimous consent to some procedural maneuvers. Lee\'s hold went unnot=</span><br><span>iced earlier when GOP presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz had a hold of his=</span><br><span>own, which he has now lifted. The Senate had hoped to hold votes on Flint a=</span><br><span>nd end debate on the energy bill as early as next week.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><span>style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p cla=</span><br><span>ss=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>b&gt;What=E2=80=99s Next?&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;Sen. Stabenow, a key leader on t=</span><br><span>he bill, predicted that =E2=80=9Cone way or another=E2=80=9D the package wou=</span><br><span>ld be voted on in the Senate this week.&amp;nbsp; And while&amp;nbsp;the House hasn\'=</span><br><span>t decided what it will do if the Flint bill clears the Senate, Energy and Co=</span><br><span>mmerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton said it would move quickly.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0=</span><br><span>);"&gt;The Obama administration, which declared Flint a federal emergency in Ja=</span><br><span>nuary freeing up much-needed funds for the distressed city, has not issued a=</span><br><span>n official stance on the Flint deal.&amp;nbsp; Early in the year the President a=</span><br><span>lso made available to the state of Michigan $80 million from a revolving fun=</span><br><span>d for infrastructure repair and improvement.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D=</span><br><span>"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;A numb=</span><br><span>er of important events are scheduled for the month of March, listed below.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp; In mid=</span><br><span>-January, the House Budget Committee announced that it would be releasing it=</span><br><span>s markup of the White House budget proposal early -=E2=80=93&amp;nbsp;&lt;a&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a h=</span><br><span>ref=3D"x-apple-data-detectors://2" x-apple-data-detectors=3D"true" x-apple-d=</span><br><span>ata-detectors-type=3D"calendar-event" x-apple-data-detectors-result=3D"2"&gt;on=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span class=3D""&gt;&lt;span class=3D""&gt;&lt;a href=3D"x-apple-data-detector=</span><br><span>s://2" x-apple-data-detectors=3D"true" x-apple-data-detectors-type=3D"calend=</span><br><span>ar-event" x-apple-data-detectors-result=3D"2"&gt;February 25&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>a href=3D"x-apple-data-detectors://2" x-apple-data-detectors=3D"true" x-appl=</span><br><span>e-data-detectors-type=3D"calendar-event" x-apple-data-detectors-result=3D"2"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>.&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;However, that has also changed&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;Yesterday&lt;b&gt;&lt;=</span><br></blockquote><span>i&gt;,&amp;nbsp;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;The Committee announced that it was now delaying its markup=</span><br><span>till sometime in March.&amp;nbsp;
