&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;More on th=</span><br><span>e new Municipal Finance Caucus below. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;Best,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;_____________________________________&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;A New Caucus&lt;/span&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;On Tuesday, Reps. Randy Hultgren and Dutch Rupper=</span><br><span>sberger announced that they have formed the Municipal Finance Caucus to prot=</span><br><span>ect the tax-exempt status of municipal debt and reexamine the way it is trea=</span><br><span>ted in financial regulations. &amp;nbsp;In 2015, Hultgren and Ruppersberger sent=</span><br><span>a letter (reprinted below) to House leadership opposing the President=E2=80=</span><br><span>=99s proposed 28 percent cap on tax deductions for municipal bonds, signed b=</span><br><span>y over 120 of their colleagues. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Thei=</span><br><span>r announcement coincided with the National Association of State Treasurers=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99 legislative conference in D.C. The same group drafted another letter,=</span><br><span>signed by more than 600 state and local officials, which urges the leaders o=</span><br><span>f the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee to rej=</span><br><span>ect curbs to the muni exemption. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Who=E2=80=</span><br><span>=99s in it?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Right now just the founding rep=</span><br><span>resentatives have declared their official membership, but it=E2=80=99s fores=</span><br><span>eeable that some of the 120 representatives that signed the letter to House l=</span><br><span>eadership in 2015 will join as well. &amp;nbsp;It=E2=80=99s also seen a s likely=</span><br><span>that some Senators will want to join the caucus, but the founders haven\'t m=</span><br><span>ade clear if bicameral membership is a priority.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;Is it Bipartisan?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Since 2013 Hultgren=</span><br><span>and Ruppersberger have led bipartisan efforts to draft letters of support f=</span><br><span>or municipal bonds. &amp;nbsp;The signatories to these letters include members f=</span><br><span>rom both sides of the aisle. &amp;nbsp;Rep. Ruppersberger focuses mostly on loca=</span><br><span>l government and is pretty moderate. Rep. Hultgren is a more orthodox conser=</span><br><span>vative Republican. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;What=E2=80=99s the Purp=</span><br><span>ose?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Caucus plans to defend municipal b=</span><br><span>onds=E2=80=99 tax exempt status and advocate for regulatory changes which fa=</span><br><span>vor those bonds. &amp;nbsp;Proposals to limit the tax-exempt status of these bon=</span><br><span>ds have been floated in recent years. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;In a=</span><br><span>ddition to calling for the bonds to maintain their tax preferred status, the=</span><br><span>Caucus will push for the passage of HR 2209, legislation considering munici=</span><br><span>pal bonds as a High Quality Liquid Asset (HQLA) =E2=80=93 a particularly con=</span><br><span>tentious issue because of the disagreement over how flexible these liquidity=</span><br><span>rules should be from a systemic risk perspective. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Positions Taken to Date&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Caucus=</span><br><span>founders have opposed Obama=E2=80=99s 2015 proposal to cap municipal bond t=</span><br><span>ax exemption at 28 percent. Rep. Hultgren is also a co-sponsor of HR 2209 =E2=</span><br><span>=80=93 the bill to set the liquidity for municipal bond assets at Level 2A (=</span><br><span>see Update, Feb. 18). &amp;nbsp;Hultgren said the liquidity rules are an example=</span><br><span>of how regulators misunderstand municipal bonds, specifically the frequent s=</span><br><span>erial structure of the their issuances.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Man=</span><br><span>y investors flock to municipal bonds for security. But some federal regulato=</span><br><span>rs trying to shore up the banking system aren\'t convinced the bonds would be=</span><br><span>easy to sell in a crisis. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Division of Opi=</span><br><span>nion&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Division of opinion on HR 2099 falls a=</span><br><span>long unusual lines, with Wall Street, Congress and municipal officials chall=</span><br><span>enging bank regulators\' skepticism toward municipal debt. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;At iss=</span><br><span>ue are new rules aimed at ensuring banks can raise enough cash during a fina=</span><br><span>ncial-market meltdown to fund their operations for 30 days. The requirements=</span><br><span>mean banks have to hold more cash or securities that are easily sellable. &lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Regulators don\'t think it is the place of C=</span><br><span>ongress to second guess how they size up securities. Fed Chairwoman Janet Ye=</span><br><span>llen, at a congressional hearing Feb. 11, said legislation would "interfere w=</span><br><span>ith our supervisory judgments." &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Big banks s=</span><br><span>uch as Citigroup Inc. and Wells Fargo &amp;amp; Co. have sprung into action in l=</span><br><span>obbying Congress, along with municipal leaders who fret the rules will dimin=</span><br><span>ish bank bond-buying which could raise borrowing costs on infrastructure pro=</span><br><span>jects.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Hultgren also said the caucus will w=</span><br><span>ork to update the number of projects that could be financed by qualified sma=</span><br><span>ll issue manufacturing bonds, a type of private-activity bond whose proceeds=</span><br><span>can be used to finance manufacturing facilities for small- and mid-sized ma=</span><br><span>nufacturers. The tax code provisions on small industrial development bonds h=</span><br><span>ave not been changed since the 1980s, he said. Hultgren sponsored a bill las=</span><br><span>t year entitled =E2=80=9CThe Modernizing American Manufacturing Bonds Act,=E2=</span><br><span>=80=9D which was focused on expanding opportunities for qualified small issu=</span><br><span>e manufacturing bonds, particularly by changing the national volume cap set b=</span><br><span>y Congress. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;What can be achieved?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Caucuses such as this one don\'t have the best reput=</span><br><span>ation when it comes to getting things done. &amp;nbsp;But rules relating to the l=</span><br><span>iquidity value of capital is one of the few policy &amp;nbsp;areas of any kind w=</span><br><span>here there is bipartisan agreement. &amp;nbsp;Municipal bonds, in particular, ha=</span><br><span>ve a universal appeal because of their direct link to local and state infras=</span><br><span>tructure projects. &amp;nbsp;At the very least, the caucus will spark some discu=</span><br><span>ssion about the best way to both reform existing methods for funding infrast=</span><br><span>ructure investment and find new ways to fund it. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;I hope everyone\'s had a chance to reflect on t=</span><br><span>he magnitude of yesterday\'s hard fought primary wins -- with gratitude to th=</span><br><span>ose who toiled in the field. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br><span>e"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;On Saturday=</span><br><span>night, the campaign debate turns to Flint, Michigan -- to the town and the i=</span><br><span>ssues it has come to symbolize. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The town\'s water contamination a=</span><br><span>nd related problems finally move center stage. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;Congress has moved with uncommon alacrity and bipartisanship in recen=</span><br></blockquote><span>t weeks on legislation to direct funding to address the water issue in Flint=</span><br><span>and elsewhere. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Here, we look at the bill\'s provisions, its fund=</span><br><span>ing steam, and its prospects. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=</span><br><span>=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Best=</span><br><span>,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>The Flint Bill -- Provisions &amp;amp; Prospects&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br></blockquote><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;A bipartisan deal has been reached in the Senate la=</span><br><span>st week to aid the beleaguered city of Flint, Michigan as it tries to remedy=</span><br><span>its drinking water issues. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Inhofe, the lead GOP Senator on the b=</span><br><span>ill, called it =E2=80=9Ccommon-sense," and noted that the spending is alread=</span><br><span>y programmed and involves no supplemental appropriation. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The bil=</span><br><span>l may be ready to move forward after Sen. Cruz lifted a hold he had placed o=</span><br><span>n the bill last week. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Mike Lee is still a hold-out. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bill provides $250 million to=</span><br><span>assist the residents of Flint, Michigan and other American cities experienc=</span><br><span>ing critical problems with their water supplies by increasing funding for Dr=</span><br><span>inking Water Act State Revolving Funds and provide start-up funding for the n=</span><br><span>ew Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act. &amp;nbsp;It also provides:&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;$100 million for Drinking Water State Revolving Funds (SRFs) accessible by a=</span><br><span>ny state with a drinking water emergency. &amp;nbsp;It requires states to submit=</span><br><span>plans explaining how the money will be spent to address the emergency befor=</span><br><span>e funding is provided. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Funds that remain after 18 months will be=</span><br><span>distributed to all states under the existing SRF formula. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/bloc=</span><br><span>kquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$70 million in f=</span><br><span>unding to back secured loans made under the new Water Infrastructure Finance=</span><br><span>and Innovation Act (WIFIA). &amp;nbsp;A federal investment of $70 million could=</span><br><span>support secured loans of up to $4.2 billion to address water and wastewater=</span><br><span>infrastructure needs across the country, according to Sen. Inhofe=E2=80=99s=</span><br><span>office. &amp;nbsp;All states and all communities with clean water and drinking w=</span><br><span>ater infrastructure needs are eligible for this assistance. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$50 million fo=</span><br><span>r various in authorized health programs for national use to address and prev=</span><br><span>ent impacts from exposure to lead. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Where will the money come from? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The package has bee=</span><br><span>n fully paid for -- it redirects appropriations by taking funds from the Adv=</span><br><span>anced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (ATVM) Fund, which offers loans for a=</span><br><span>uto companies. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Does t=</span><br><span>hat matter? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Per Sen. Inhofe =E2=80=9C[the ATVM is] a failed prog=</span><br><span>ram that hasn=E2=80=99t been used in more than a year and has only issued fi=</span><br><span>ve loans since 2008."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>More on ATVM: The ATVM program is authorized to award up to $25 billion in l=</span><br></blockquote><span>oans; there is no deadline for completing such loan commitments. Congress fu=</span><br><span>nded the program in 2009, when it appropriated $7.5 billion to cover the sub=</span><br><span>sidy cost for the $25 billion in loans, as well as $10 million for program i=</span><br><span>mplementation. Since the start of the program, DOE has awarded $8.4 billion i=</span><br><span>n loans to five companies. As of January 2015, ATVM has $16.6 billion in rem=</span><br><span>aining loan authority. No new loans have been made since 2011. Two companies=</span><br><span>=E2=80=94 Fisker and the Vehicle Production Group =E2=80=94 were unable to m=</span><br><span>ake payments on their loans, and DOE auctioned the loans off in the fall of 2=</span><br><span>013. Tesla paid off all of its loan in 2013, nine years ahead of schedule. &lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Criticisms of ATVM: T=</span><br><span>he unobligated funds remaining for the program have been a point of contenti=</span><br><span>on in recent appropriations debates. The House has voted several times to tr=</span><br><span>ansfer some of the unused appropriation for the ATVM subsidy costs to other p=</span><br><span>urposes. None of these transfers were enacted. Other legislators have sought=</span><br><span>to expand the program. Two recent federal reports call for rescinding the p=</span><br><span>rogram=E2=80=99s unobligated balance: the FY2015 budget resolution reported b=</span><br><span>y the House Budget Committee calls for outright rescission, and an April 201=</span><br><span>4 GAO report recommends Congress consider taking the same step unless DOE ca=</span><br><span>n generate new demand for the program.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Legislative Strategy: &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Architects of the bipart=</span><br><span>isan deal put out a hotline request to see if anyone would object to a serie=</span><br><span>s of procedural moves that would split Flint aid off the energy bill (S. 201=</span><br><span>2), attach it to a House bill (H.R. 4470) sponsored by Reps. Dan Kildee and =</span><br><span>Fred Upton, allow voice votes on 30 amendments to the energy bill, and allow=</span><br><span>roll call votes on eight additional amendments. Michigan Sens. Debbie Stabe=</span><br><span>now and Gary Peters said Democrats are on board, but in order to achieve una=</span><br><span>nimous consent, Republicans need to sign on. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Will it pass? &amp;nbsp;The Flint package and the energ=</span><br><span>y bill amendments would come to a vote only after the Senate gets unanimous c=</span><br><span>onsent to some procedural maneuvers. Lee\'s hold went unnoticed earlier when G=</span><br><span>OP presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz had a hold of his own, which he has n=</span><br><span>ow lifted. The Senate had hoped to hold votes on Flint and end debate on the=</span><br><span>energy bill as early as next week. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;What=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s Next? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sen. Stabenow, a key leader on the bill, predicted=</span><br><span>that =E2=80=9Cone way or another=E2=80=9D the package would be voted on in t=</span><br><span>he Senate this week. &amp;nbsp;And while the House hasn\'t decided what it will d=</span><br><span>o if the Flint bill clears the Senate, Energy and Commerce Committee Chairma=</span><br><span>n Fred Upton said it would move quickly.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;T=</span><br><span>he Obama administration, which declared Flint a federal emergency in January=</span><br><span>freeing up much-needed funds for the distressed city, has not issued an off=</span><br><span>icial stance on the Flint deal. &amp;nbsp;Early in the year the President also m=</span><br><span>ade available to the state of Michigan $80 million from a revolving fund for=</span><br><span>infrastructure repair and improvement. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;A number of important events are scheduled for the month of March, lis=</span><br><span>ted below.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt; --&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;One week ago, the H=</span><br></blockquote><span>ouse passed a bill that could alter and perhaps ease the way state and local=</span><br><span>infrastructure is financed in the capital markets, when HR.2209, a bill to "=</span><br><span>require the appropriate Federal banking agencies to treat certain municipal o=</span><br><span>bligations as level 2A liquid assets, and for other purposes" was adopted by=</span><br><span>the House with a voice vote. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Infrast=</span><br><span>ructure is mostly funded at the state or local level through the use of muni=</span><br><span>cipal bonds. &amp;nbsp;Between 2003 and 2012, counties, states, and other locali=</span><br><span>ties invested $3.2 trillion in infrastructure through long-term tax-exempt m=</span><br><span>unicipal bonds, 2.5 times more than the federal investment. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Bill&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209=</span><br><span>requires federal banking regulators to include municipal bonds under the Li=</span><br><span>quidity Coverage Ratio (LCR). &amp;nbsp;The LCR is designed to ensure that finan=</span><br><span>cial institutions have the necessary assets available to handle a liquidity d=</span><br><span>isruption. &amp;nbsp;Local officials have said that if the new rules aren=E2=80=99=</span><br><span>t changed, it will saddle them with higher borrowing costs by eliminating in=</span><br><span>centives banks have to purchase their bonds. Without bonds, these government=</span><br><span>s will lose a significant source of their funding. &amp;nbsp;Per Indiana State T=</span><br><span>reasurer Kelly Mitchell: =E2=80=9CThis bill helps ensure cash-strapped schoo=</span><br><span>l districts and municipalities will continue to have access to bonds to fina=</span><br><span>nce projects they think are best for their communities.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Rep. Luke Messer, an Indiana Republican who wrote t=</span><br><span>he bill: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CPut simply, our bill requires the federal government=</span><br><span>to recognize the obvious, that our municipal bonds are some of the safest i=</span><br><span>nvestments in the world and that we shouldn=E2=80=99t have rules that give p=</span><br><span>referential treatment to corporate bonds or other countries=E2=80=99 bonds o=</span><br><span>ver our own.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;After passing the H=</span><br><span>ouse with unanimous bipartisan support, a companion bill is expected to be i=</span><br><span>ntroduced in the Senate this year. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>Municipal Bond Issue&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;After the crisis of=</span><br></blockquote><span>2008, federal regulators adopted international banking standards that requi=</span><br><span>re banks to have enough "High-Quality Liquid Assets" to cover their cash out=</span><br><span>flows for 30 days in case of a future financial meltdown. &amp;nbsp;Now, municip=</span><br><span>al bonds are not considered liquid assets and therefore cannot be included u=</span><br><span>nder the &amp;nbsp;LCR. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;As a result, financial institutions have bee=</span><br><span>n discouraged from holding municipal debt, which means that cash strapped mu=</span><br><span>nicipalities and school districts may eventually be forced to reduce or even=</span><br><span>stop work on projects &amp;nbsp;financed with municipal bonds. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Infrastructure Financing -- Alternative Financing&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Tax-exempt bonds: &amp;nbsp;Ex=</span><br><span>emption from federal taxes and many state and local taxes is possible throug=</span><br><span>h the use of municipal bonds. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;In recent years, with the increasi=</span><br><span>ng use of PPPs, barriers to this tax exemption have arisen. &amp;nbsp;Treasury h=</span><br><span>as reviewed relevant tax rules and based on their findings and have put fort=</span><br><span>h a proposal for an expanded and permanent America Fast Forward Bond Program=</span><br><span>as an alternative to tax-exempt bonds. &amp;nbsp;Based on the successful Build A=</span><br><span>merica Bond program, =E2=80=9Cwould provide an efficient borrowing subsidy t=</span><br><span>o state and local governments while appealing to a broader investor base tha=</span><br><span>n traditional tax-exempt bonds [and] would cover a broad range of projects f=</span><br><span>or which tax-exempt bonds can be used.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt; =E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;Obama=E2=80=99s budget proposal: &amp;nbsp;Obama has al=</span><br><span>so put forth a plan to strengthen local and state government infrastructure p=</span><br><span>rojects. His plan relies on a new Federal credit program to support public-p=</span><br><span>rivate partnerships within the Department of the Treasury. It will provide d=</span><br><span>irect loans to US infrastructure projects developed through PPPs. The Obama A=</span><br><span>dministration believes that private investment is crucial for infrastructure=</span><br><span>development moving forward, so there should be more flexibility in regards t=</span><br><span>o what PPP is subject to. In addition to that, President Obama has proposed t=</span><br><span>he taxable, direct-pay America Fast Forward bond program to help finance inf=</span><br><span>rastructure. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;State Infrastructure B=</span><br><span>anks&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Local governments receive financing i=</span><br><span>n a number of ways. &amp;nbsp;Traditional sources such as tax revenues have been=</span><br><span>dwindling and local authorities have been relying on federal government loa=</span><br><span>n programs, public-private partnerships, and State Revolving Funds (SRFs). &amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;State Infrastructure Banks (SIBs) are a subset of SRFs -- the funds act=</span><br><span>like a bank, because they don=E2=80=99t own the infrastructure asset, but a=</span><br><span>ct as a lender or guarantor to the project sponsor. Per Brookings: &amp;nbsp;=E2=</span><br><span>=80=9CSRFs rely on principal repayments, bonds, interest and fees to re-capi=</span><br><span>talize and replenish the fund as a perpetual source of debt financing.=E2=80=</span><br><span>=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/bloc=</span><br><span>kquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;SIBs generate more investment per dol=</span><br><span>lar than traditional federal and state grant programs. &amp;nbsp;They only exist=</span><br><span>in 33 states and 10 of those SIBs are currently inactive. A large problem m=</span><br><span>ay be compliance with federal regulations. &amp;nbsp;Brookings again: &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=9CWe found that many SIB officials cite com=</span><br><span>pliance with federal regulations as slowing down the investment process eith=</span><br><span>er because of environmental and contractual requirements or due to the lack o=</span><br><span>f flexibility in projects that are not Title 23 or 49 eligible. For states w=</span><br><span>ith smaller projects, this may be prohibitively costly compared to the advan=</span><br><span>tage of using the low-cost SIB financing.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Just being called a bank subjects SIBs to regulations that commer=</span><br><span>cial banks are subject to. &amp;nbsp;SIBs are non-for-profit organizations with a=</span><br><span>goal of increasing infrastructure investment, so they don=E2=80=99t quite f=</span><br><span>it into the category of the average bank. &amp;nbsp;SIBs may be more successful o=</span><br><span>utside this classification. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;For or A=</span><br><span>gainst Dodd-Frank&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Before Dodd-Frank, part=</span><br><span>icularly in the case of relatively small municipalities, many underwriters f=</span><br><span>orged long-term relationships with municipalities and would provide financia=</span><br><span>l advice before and after a bond issuance. &amp;nbsp;With Dodd-Frank, that relat=</span><br><span>ionship changed, with a new =E2=80=9Cmunicipal adviser=E2=80=9D category tha=</span><br><span>t must register with the SEC and be regulated by the Municipal Securities Ru=</span><br><span>lemaking Board (MSR). &amp;nbsp;Now, it is widely illegal to provide advice to g=</span><br><span>overnmental entities concerning the issuance of municipal bonds, the use of f=</span><br><span>inancial derivatives, and the investment of the proceeds of a bond issue to,=</span><br><span>or on behalf, of a municipal entity or an obligated person unless the advis=</span><br><span>er is registered with the SEC. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209 a=</span><br><span>ppears to address a problem within Dodd-Frank, but it is unclear if it vitia=</span><br><span>tes the law materially. &amp;nbsp;At face value, it appears to be more a technic=</span><br><span>al fix. Dodd-Frank expanded regulations for banking institutions, but the en=</span><br><span>tities that fund state and local governments are far unlike the TBTF institu=</span><br><span>tions that Dodd-Frank was meant to regulate. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote typ=</span><br><span>e=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Groups like Americans for Financial Reform oppose HR 2209: =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9CWhile we sympathize with the belief that municipal debt was incorrectl=</span><br><span>y treated under the initial LCR rule, we believe that it is inappropriate to=</span><br><span>classify such debt as a Level 2A asset. AFR therefore opposes this bill unl=</span><br><span>ess a more appropriate liquidity classification is used.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;AFR h=</span><br><span>as previously said it supports treating municipal bonds as more liquid and d=</span><br><span>oes not approve the type of classification used in HR 2209, because it goes t=</span><br><span>oo far in its treatment of municipal debt as level 2A liquid assets and spec=</span><br><span>ifically with micromanaging regulators with this kind of detail and they pre=</span><br><span>fer a Level 2B classification. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bill c=</span><br><span>ould provide relief for smaller institutions, so that they can fund infrastr=</span><br><span>ucture investment more easily. In terms of Dodd-Frank, it is yet to be decid=</span><br><span>ed if it is simply a necessary tweak or a criticism. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Looking Ahead&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209 could end up being an important issue in the national infras=</span><br><span>tructure discussion. &amp;nbsp;It brings up questions about how far a state or l=</span><br><span>ocal government can go before its activities begin to resemble an actual ban=</span><br><span>k. &amp;nbsp;With the growth of PPPs, the private sector is being even more inte=</span><br><span>grated into the process =E2=80=93 should those companies be given tax exempt=</span><br><span>ions, as well? &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Upcoming/Recent Updates&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;Derivatives Agreement w. up big banks is already a policy avenue available to regulators=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;The Federal Reserve, through the Financial Stability Oversight Counc=</span><br><span>il, can elect to take a number of actions to deal with banks that it feels a=</span><br><span>re both systemically important and organized in an unstable way. &amp;nbsp;Secti=</span><br><span>on 121 of the Dodd-Frank Act gives the Board of Governors these powers. &amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;So this first proposal =E2=80=93 break=</span><br><span>up big banks - has been covered here before but just for the sake of argume=</span><br><span>nt... which banks need to be broken up most urgently? &amp;nbsp;Few commentators=</span><br><span>believe there is an imminent threat demanding action. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/bl=</span><br><span>ockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote requirements for banks so high that they =E2=80=9Cessentially=</span><br><span>turn into public utilities.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;Kashkari never explains how exac=</span><br><span>tly high capital v=</span><br><span>oted affirmatively. &amp;nbsp;Industry groups including the National Retail Fede=</span><br><span>ration, as well as the U.S. Chamber of Commerce were supportive of the Durbin a=</span><br><span>nd Reid, who both expressed disappointment that the legislation was a =E2=80=</span><br><span>=9Cwatered down=E2=80=9D version of a bill previously passed by the Senate. &amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;=E2=80=9DI like that [Senate] version, and that strong language on curr=</span><br><span>ency manipulation,=E2=80=9D Durbin said =E2=80=93 that language required Com=</span><br><span>merce to consider =E2=80=9Cundervalued=E2=80=9D currencies to be equivalent t=</span><br><span>o countervailable subsidies. &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CThe conference report that=E2=80=</span><br><span>=99s back to us now and before the Senate at this moment is a much different=</span><br><span>bill."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Purpose and Provisions&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;House and Senate negotiators agreed on a final cust=</span><br><span>oms bill in December. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The House passed the measure 256-158 but t=</span><br><span>he legislation stalled in the Senate over a provision added in conference th=</span><br><span>at permanently extends a moratorium on Internet access taxes.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/bl=</span><br><span>ockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;That provision is perhaps the most reported on section i=</span><br><span>n the bill =E2=80=93 it=E2=80=99s almost certainly the most popular - it app=</span><br><span>lies to localities, states, and the federal government itself. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;S=</span><br><span>en. Lamar Alexander cited it though as explanation for his =E2=80=9Cnay=E2=80=</span><br><span>=9D vote: "the federal government shouldn\'t be telling the states what their=</span><br><span>tax structure should be."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Another import=</span><br><span>ant provision, known as the ENFORCE Act, would require the CBP to more aggre=</span><br><span>ssively investigate complaints that companies are evading anti-dumping or co=</span><br><span>untervailing duties on imports by mislabeling or disguising the shipments.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bill includes a new Trade Enforcement =</span><br><span>Fund to bring trade cases through the WTO, to investigate the implementation=</span><br><span>of trade requirements by other countries, and to respond to complaints of t=</span><br><span>rade violations. &amp;nbsp;It also creates a nine-member Advisory Committee on I=</span><br><span>nternational Exchange Rate Policy, whose members must be comprised of indivi=</span><br><span>duals from the private sector who are selected by both chambers of Congress a=</span><br><span>nd the President (three members each).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Cu=</span><br><span>rrency Manipulation&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Currency manipulation=</span><br><span>has been a long-standing concern of American policy-makers and a particular=</span><br><span>ly contentious issue in global trade relations; claims that China has been c=</span><br><span>hronically undervaluing its currency have made the news for a number of year=</span><br><span>s. &amp;nbsp;Advocates for stricter enforcement of currency manipulation provisi=</span><br><span>ons claim that undervalued currencies operate similarly to export subsidies =E2=</span><br><span>=80=93 a prohibited practice within the World Trade Organization.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The final bill dropped a Senate provision that woul=</span><br><span>d have required the Commerce Department to treat undervalued currency as an i=</span><br><span>llegal subsidy under U.S. countervailing duty law. &amp;nbsp;This provision woul=</span><br><span>d have opened the door for compensatory tariffs to be levied against goods w=</span><br><span>hich originate from countries which are found to purposely undervalue their c=</span><br><span>urrency in order to boost their exports. The bill does, however, include oth=</span><br><span>er measures that give the Treasury Department new tools to fight currency ma=</span><br><span>nipulation:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;creates a spe=</span><br><span>cial fund for the CBP to ensure trading partners follow the rules and to bri=</span><br><span>ng disputes before the WTO&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;increases funding to the National Intellectual Propert=</span><br><span>y Rights Coordination Center&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;establishes the Commercial Customs Operations Adviso=</span><br><span>ry Committee jointly between CBP and Treasury&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;requires CBP to investigate claims f=</span><br><span>rom other agencies of evasion of anti-dumping or countervailing duties.&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Relation to TPP&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;Sen. Majority Leader McConnell has said that the Senate will not vote o=</span><br><span>n the Trans-Pacific Partnership before the November elections, so it may com=</span><br><span>e as a surprise to see a bill which deals with enforcing trade deals like TP=</span><br><span>P pass both houses of Congress. &amp;nbsp;However this bill=E2=80=99s provisions=</span><br><span>for protecting IP rights, toughening countervailing duties, and tackling cu=</span><br><span>rrency manipulation are a necessary prerequisite for agreements like TPP (or=</span><br><span>the far more nebulous TTIP). &amp;nbsp;The new age of trade agreements &amp;nbsp;wi=</span><br><span>ll deal extensively in issues like intellectual property protection, trade i=</span><br><span>n services, and high-tech product trading; types of commerce which are far m=</span><br><span>ore difficult to regulate compared to the trade of physical goods.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;So, despite the fact that TPP won=E2=80=99t get a v=</span><br><span>ote until after November (and perhaps not in 2016 at all), and may not pass e=</span><br><span>ven then, the protections set forward in the customs bill are necessary to a=</span><br><span>llow American companies to continue to compete in the global marketplace.&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Price of Passage&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br></blockquote><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br><span>e"&gt;&lt;span&gt;In order to include the permanent extension of the Internet Tax Fre=</span><br><span>edom Act, McConnell had to promise that a vote would be held this year on th=</span><br><span>e Marketplace Fairness Act. &amp;nbsp;That legislation grants states greater aut=</span><br><span>hority to collect sales taxes from online businesses who sell products withi=</span><br><span>n their borders. &amp;nbsp;While McConnell himself opposes the bill, it was the o=</span><br><span>nly way to get the customs bill (with the tax amendment attached) unstuck.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Just because McConnell has promised it wil=</span><br><span>l be brought to a vote doesn=E2=80=99t mean it will be a smooth process - th=</span><br><span>e Senate passed the Marketplace Fairness Act in 2013 with 69 votes, and most=</span><br><span>of the lawmakers who voted for it are still in the chamber. &amp;nbsp;Some lawm=</span><br><span>akers like Kelly Ayotte, who is facing a tough reelection campaign this year=</span><br><span>, have vowed to fight tooth-and-nail against it. &amp;nbsp;Despite these detract=</span><br><span>ors in the Senate, the real battle may occur in the House, where two competi=</span><br><span>ng proposals have been brought forward. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote Co. &amp;nbsp;--&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;One thing th=</span><br><span>e two parties agree is that international tax reform is a fiscally necessary=</span><br><span>issue to take up -- that Uncle Sam is leaving hundreds of billions of dolla=</span><br><span>rs on the table overseas annually. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;But they would also generally=</span><br><span>agree that it is not going to get done this year. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Under current law, those profits are subject only to fede=</span><br><span>ral taxes if they are returned, or repatriated, to the U.S. where they face a=</span><br><span>top rate of 35 percent. &amp;nbsp;Many companies avoid U.S. taxes on those earn=</span><br><span>ings by simply leaving them overseas.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>lockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockqu=</span><br><span>ote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;T=</span><br><span>here is bipartisan activity on the issue in both houses of Congress. Obama h=</span><br><span>as a major reform proposal on the table. &amp;nbsp;So is this the year, in the y=</span><br><span>ear of surprises?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Best,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Reforms in t=</span><br><span>he area of international tax deal with both the repatriation of foreign-deri=</span><br><span>ved profits and the issue of corporate inversions. &amp;nbsp;Testifying today, T=</span><br><span>reasury Secretary Jack Lew encouraged the parties in Congress to overcome th=</span><br><span>eir differences on both, which he believes surmountable: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CI ju=</span><br><span>st want to underscore the urgency of dealing with inversions =E2=80=A6 We ca=</span><br><span>n=E2=80=99t wait a year to deal with this,=E2=80=9D Lew said during a Senate=</span><br><span>Finance hearing on the Obama administration=E2=80=99s budget. Congress coul=</span><br><span>d pass narrow legislation on inversions, he said, even if broader reform of t=</span><br><span>he international system is preferable. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>Stirrings in the Senate&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote typ=</span><br></blockquote><span>e=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockqu=</span><br><span>ote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Sen. Schumer a=</span><br><span>lso announced today that he is in contact with Speaker Ryan about coming to a=</span><br><span>n agreement on repatriating corporate profits. &amp;nbsp;They were unable to com=</span><br><span>e to an agreement last year on a similar measure put forth as part of a larg=</span><br><span>er reform effort. &amp;nbsp;Schumer said today: =E2=80=9CWe=E2=80=99re trying to=</span><br><span>bridge over, of course, the divide between existing proposals. &amp;nbsp;I rema=</span><br><span>in at the table ready to work.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/bloc=</span><br><span>kquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;One of the key differences between the parties concerns whether the m=</span><br><span>oney raised from tax reform should be turn into government revenue for more s=</span><br><span>pending, or used to pay down the debt or pass tax cuts. &amp;nbsp;After the Sena=</span><br><span>te Finance hearing yesterday, Chair Hatch said: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CI\'m actually w=</span><br><span>orking on international, but I just don\'t think it\'s going to get done this y=</span><br><span>ear, because, you know, let\'s face it, the Democrats are going to want to ra=</span><br><span>ise revenue. &amp;nbsp;They want money to spend.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;At that same hearing, Sen. Shelby pushed a corporate i=</span><br><span>ntegration plan he is developing to eliminate the double taxation of corpora=</span><br><span>te income by providing corporations a dividend deduction. &amp;nbsp;He\'s awaitin=</span><br><span>g a score by the Joint Committee on Taxation. &amp;nbsp;Dividend deductions are u=</span><br><span>sually quite expensive and regressive, so it will a feat to attract any Demo=</span><br><span>cratic support, especially for him. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote and Means C=</span><br><span>hair Kevin Brady has said that he wants a vote this year on moving the Unite=</span><br><span>d States into a territorial tax system, which would permanently exempt US-ba=</span><br><span>sed businesses from paying taxes on income earned abroad. &amp;nbsp;He also want=</span><br><span>s to lower the corporate rate to 20 percent. &amp;nbsp;In the face of these prop=</span><br><span>osals it is difficult to see what sort of compromise can be found between De=</span><br><span>mocrats and Republicans, as the former may be more preoccupied just keeping a=</span><br><span>live the idea that foreign profits should be taxed at all. =E2=80=9CThe goal=</span><br><span>of these reforms are not to generate more spending,=E2=80=9D Brady said. =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9CIt=E2=80=99s to bring back real dollars to be reinvested in the United=</span><br><span>States.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Brady has been advoca=</span><br><span>ting for international tax reform since he took over Ways and Means. &amp;nbsp;L=</span><br><span>ast month, he spoke with Sen. Hatch and they were both committed to getting s=</span><br><span>omething done. &amp;nbsp;Senior Republicans believe the country=E2=80=99s intern=</span><br><span>ational tax problems =E2=80=94 inversions and Europe going after revenues fr=</span><br><span>om U.S. companies among them =E2=80=94 are urgent. &amp;nbsp;But Brady strongly h=</span><br><span>inted that all that work would be aimed at setting things up for 2017, when R=</span><br><span>epublicans want =E2=80=9Cpro-growth tax reform under a Republican president.=</span><br><span>=E2=80=9D Perhaps that=E2=80=99s no huge shock, but it does seem to set up s=</span><br><span>omething of a disconnect, given all the talk of urgency.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockqu=</span><br><span>ote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Brady and his supporters have been pushing the idea that A=</span><br><span>merican money is either being taxed by other countries or being taken over b=</span><br><span>y foreign competitors in an inversion -- typically, when an American company=</span><br><span>incorporates abroad so its earnings are no longer subject to American taxes=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;Brady says the result is an erosion of our tax base and a lock-out e=</span><br><span>ffect of American capital being =E2=80=9Ctrapped=E2=80=9D abroad that can be=</span><br><span>solved by fixing our uncompetitive tax code.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;Presidential Proposal&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br></blockquote><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote Presid=</span><br><span>ent=E2=80=99s FY 2017 budget contains a surprising source of new revenue to p=</span><br><span>ay for its spending programs =E2=80=93 a major piece of international tax po=</span><br><span>licy reform: a six-year, $478 billion public-works program for highway, brid=</span><br><span>ge and transit upgrades, half of it to be financed with a one-time, 14 perce=</span><br><span>nt tax on U.S. companies=E2=80=99 overseas profits and a 19 percent rate the=</span><br><span>reafter. &amp;nbsp;The issue of companies holding foreign profits at locations a=</span><br><span>broad, where they are exempt from taxation until repatriated, has vexed poli=</span><br><span>cy makers on both sides for some time. &amp;nbsp;It=E2=80=99s estimated that the=</span><br><span>se profits add up to nearly $2 trillion. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;The issue of companies holding foreign profits at locations abroad, there=</span><br><span>by exempt from taxation unless those profits are brought home, has vexed pol=</span><br><span>icy makers on both sides for some time. &amp;nbsp;Microsoft Corp., Apple Inc., G=</span><br><span>oogle Inc. and five other tech firms now account for more than a fifth of th=</span><br><span>e $2.10 trillion in profits that U.S. companies are holding overseas. &amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>In keeping with the idea that Obama=E2=80=99s final budget is =E2=80=9Cmore p=</span><br><span>olitics than policy,=E2=80=9D these revenue-gaining proposals are meant to s=</span><br><span>park discussion more so than be a model for laws going forward. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"=</span><br><span>cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Basics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;The bottom line: the FOMC won=E2=80=99t rollback rates in March and it=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s not likely to raise them either. &amp;nbsp;The Fed likes what it sees in=</span><br><span>the labor market, wage growth looks strong, and emerging market missteps co=</span><br><span>ntinue to be a threat to the US economy but perhaps not an immediate one. &amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;The next rate move is almost certain to be an increase but it could wait=</span><br><span>until June or later. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;Yellen reiterated much of the FOMC statement from last month: &amp;nbsp;the l=</span><br><span>abor market remains strong, but shows some signs of remaining slack, that th=</span><br><span>e low inflation we have seen is caused by =E2=80=9Ctransitory=E2=80=9D effec=</span><br><span>ts (low energy prices), and that global market uncertainty creates some leve=</span><br><span>l of risk for slow growth at home and abroad. &amp;nbsp;Though Yellen did not ma=</span><br><span>ke a prediction on how long these transitory market effects would last, a nu=</span><br><span>mber of forecasts for oil prices show the dip lasting through 2016.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquo=</span><br><span>te type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Expanding on global growth i=</span><br><span>ssues, Yellen said "These developments, if they prove persistent, could weig=</span><br><span>h on the outlook for economic activity and the labor market, although declin=</span><br><span>es in longer-term interest rates and oil prices could provide some offset," s=</span><br><span>he added: "Foreign economic developments, in particular, pose risks to US ec=</span><br><span>onomic growth." &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>lockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Partisan Review&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br></blockquote><span>e"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The GOP is generally critical of "accommo=</span><br><span>dative" (lower) Fed rates. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;High-net-worth individuals benefit th=</span><br><span>e most from high rates through dividends and interest from savings. &amp;nbsp;Lo=</span><br><span>w rates allow more growth for the middle- and lower-classes at the risk of i=</span><br><span>nflation, tacitly supporting Democrats=E2=80=99 progressive fiscal policy go=</span><br><span>als. &amp;nbsp;Some conservative economists have gone so far as to blame low int=</span><br><span>erest rates pushed by the Fed in the 1990=E2=80=99s for the market meltdown i=</span><br><span>n 2007, claiming that cheap credit was the cause of the overheated housing m=</span><br><span>arket.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"=</span><br><span>cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Strong Labor Market&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Discussing the labor market in greater detail, Ye=</span><br><span>llen pointed to the cumulative increase in employment since 2010 of 13 milli=</span><br><span>on jobs. &amp;nbsp;The rate in January fell to 4.9 percent, 0.8 points below its=</span><br><span>level one year ago; measures of labor market conditions such as the number o=</span><br><span>f people who are working part-time but want to move to full-time positions a=</span><br><span>nd the number of individuals who want to work but haven=E2=80=99t searched r=</span><br><span>ecently are also decreasing steadily. &amp;nbsp;Regarding these broader labor ma=</span><br><span>rket indicators Yellen testified that =E2=80=9C=E2=80=A6 these measures rema=</span><br><span>in above the levels seen prior to the recession, suggesting that some slack i=</span><br><span>n labor markets remains. Thus, while labor market conditions have improved s=</span><br><span>ubstantially, there is still room for further sustainable improvement."&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br></blockquote><span>e"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Forward Guidance&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/bloc=</span><br></blockquote><span>kquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;As always, Yellen was careful not to give hints on what the Fed=</span><br><span>is planning to do in future meetings; speaking on the path forward for the =</span><br><span>Fed Funds rate Yellen said =E2=80=9COf course, monetary policy is by no mean=</span><br><span>s on a preset course. The actual path of the federal funds rate will depend o=</span><br><span>n what incoming data tell us about the economic outlook, and we will regular=</span><br><span>ly reassess what level of the federal funds rate is consistent with achievin=</span><br><span>g and maintaining maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Yellen was asked about the chances of the =</span><br><span>FOMC rolling back the rate hike it announced in December: &amp;nbsp;"I do not ex=</span><br><span>pect the FOMC is going to be soon in the situation where it\'s necessary to c=</span><br><span>ut rates If the FOMC delayed the start of policy normalization for too long,=</span><br><span>it might have to tighten policy relatively abruptly in the future to keep t=</span><br><span>he economy from overheating and inflation from significantly overshooting it=</span><br><span>s objective. Such an abrupt tightening could increase the risk of pushing th=</span><br><span>e economy into recession." &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br></blockquote><span>e"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Comment on D=</span><br><span>odd-Frank&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;During the Q&amp;amp;A portion of=</span><br><span>her testimony, Yellen was asked about financial regulation, both in terms o=</span><br><span>f breaking up the banks and enforcing the regulations brought on by Dodd-Fra=</span><br><span>nk. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;In response to being asked if th=</span><br><span>e Fed is trying to break up the banks, she responded: "We are using our powe=</span><br><span>rs to make sure that a systemically important institution could fail, and it=</span><br><span>would not have systemic consequences for the country." Her answer was inter=</span><br><span>esting, because she\'s not outright saying the banks will be broken up or red=</span><br><span>uced, just that the Fed is trying to ensure that even if they did fail, it w=</span><br><span>ouldn\'t negatively effect the economy.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>Yellen was also asked about the burden of new Dodd-Frank regulations on ban=</span><br></blockquote><span>ks. She responded: "For our part, we\'re focused on doing everything that we c=</span><br><span>onceivably can to minimize and reduce the burden on these banking organizati=</span><br><span>ons. We\'ve been conducting an EGRPRA review to identify potential burdens th=</span><br><span>at our regulations impose." An EGRPRA review is connected to the Economic Gr=</span><br><span>owth and Regulatory Paperwork Reduction Act, which requires regulations impo=</span><br><span>sed on financial institutions to be reviewed by the agencies at least once e=</span><br><span>very 10 years. The purpose is to prevent burdensome regulations that could h=</span><br><span>inder a bank\'s ability to serve its customers. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Bottom Line&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Fed watcher=</span><br><span>s make their living by trying to predict what the FOMC will or won=E2=80=99t=</span><br><span>do at their meetings, and on days when Yellen is scheduled to testify befor=</span><br><span>e Congress you can bet that they=E2=80=99re listening intently. &amp;nbsp;While Y=</span><br><span>ellen was careful not to project the Fed=E2=80=99s moves, the general sentim=</span><br><span>ent in the markets is that FOMC won=E2=80=99t be raising rates at its March m=</span><br><span>eeting. &amp;nbsp;The CME Group FedWatch tool, which estimates FOMC rate hikes b=</span><br><span>ased on its futures prices, predicts a 95% probability that the Fed will mai=</span><br><span>ntain its current rate target in March. &amp;nbsp;Some forecasters go even furth=</span><br><span>er -- expecting that the funds rate won=E2=80=99t be raised all year. &lt;/span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Traders see the ongoing economic struggles=</span><br><span>of emerging economies, particularly in China, as evidence that the Fed won=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99t continue with its scheduled 4 rate hikes this year. &amp;nbsp;Certainly,=</span><br><span>considering the testimony today that 1) continued emerging market uncertain=</span><br><span>ty can weigh down the US economy and 2) that poor performance in the US econ=</span><br><span>omy would cause the Fed to change course on its rate hike schedule, a link b=</span><br><span>etween poor emerging market performance and fewer Fed rate hikes seems plaus=</span><br><span>ible. &amp;nbsp;Certainly the trading on Fed fund futures indicates that the PM, Dana &amp;lt;&lt;a href=3D"mailto:danachas=</span><br><span><a href="mailto:in@gmail.com">in@gmail.com</a>"&gt;<a href="mailto:danachasin@gmail.com">danachasin@gmail.com</a>&lt;/a&gt;&amp;gt; type="cite"><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br></blockquote><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Mike &amp;amp; Co. --&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Today=</span><br><span>, President Obama submitted his eighth and final budget proposal to Congress=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;It tops the $4 trillion mark for the first time. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Despite=</span><br><span>the historical tendency for lame duck presidential budgets to be treated as=</span><br><span>scrap paper -- this one won\'t even be accorded the courtesy of a hearing in=</span><br><span>House Budget -- there are a few noteworthy proposals and initiatives which,=</span><br><span>if nothing else, are likely to generate discussion on the Hill and off. &amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;That=E2=80=99s the real purpose of this budget -- to=</span><br><span>help frame the debate in 2016 about where America is headed what the nation=</span><br><span>\'s priorities should be. &amp;nbsp;A number of the proposals in this budget reso=</span><br><span>nate with issues and Transportation Tax&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;A per=</span><br><span>ennial favorite of Democrats has made a return in the Obama budget: &amp;nbsp;a $=</span><br><span>10.25 per barrel tax on oil, $319 billion in revenue from which will go towa=</span><br><span>rd funding =E2=80=9Ca 21st Century Clean Transportation Plan to upgrade the n=</span><br><span>ation=E2=80=99s transportation system, improve resilience and reduce emissio=</span><br><span>ns." &amp;nbsp;The proposed tax is a simplified version of =E2=80=9Ccarbon taxat=</span><br><span>ion=E2=80=9D policies, which aim to tax energy producers and oil companies b=</span><br><span>ased on the level of pollution they produce; =E2=80=9Ccap and trade=E2=80=9D=</span><br><span>was a similar policy idea but with more complicated implementation. &amp;nbsp;&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The tax will be phased in over five years and levied agai=</span><br><span>nst oil companies, with the revenue to help fund clean energy initiatives li=</span><br><span>ke expanding high-speed rail systems and also to increase national infrastru=</span><br><span>cture spending. &amp;nbsp;The appeal of this flat-tax on oil is its simplicity =E2=</span><br><span>=80=93- there is nothing complicated about charging oil companies $10.25 per=</span><br><span>barrel of oil, meaning there=E2=80=99s no way for them to shirk the charge.=</span><br><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Supporting the tax would lend candidates some environme=</span><br><span>ntal bonafides, but might be seen as a backdoor &amp;nbsp;tax on the middle-clas=</span><br><span>s. Though paid for by oil companies, the &amp;nbsp;price is expected to be passe=</span><br><span>d along to consumers through higher prices. &amp;nbsp;The tax is expected to inc=</span><br><span>rease the price of gasoline by 25 cents per gallon.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=</span><br><span>=A2 &amp;nbsp;Funding Fin. Reg. Like it Matters &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote CFTC over ten ye=</span><br><span>ars, beginning with an 11 percent increase for SEC and 32 percent for CFTC i=</span><br><span>n 2017. &amp;nbsp;Clinton has a lot to like in this particular section
