issues with the corp=</span><br><span>orate tax system could be addressed through international tax reform, becaus=</span><br><span>e so many companies earn capital abroad. However, corporate tax reform at ho=</span><br><span>me deals with issues like taxing dividends and leveling the playing field be=</span><br><span>tween small and large businesses. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=</span><br><span>=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 International - Deals with foreign earnings of A=</span><br><span>merican firms abroad. Specifically, current international tax reform aims at=</span><br><span>preventing inversions and coming up with a more successful way to tax forei=</span><br><span>gn capital earned by American companies, as well as finding ways to encourag=</span><br><span>e companies to move profits home from abroad.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Forums for Tax Reform&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 Ways &amp;amp; Means: &amp;nbsp;Kevin Br=</span><br><span>ady became Chair of the Committee in November 2015. that Wall Street regulation=</span><br><span>will likely remain one the &amp;nbsp;campaign\'s central issues. type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;At the heart of this debate is the Dodd-Frank Act (DFA). &amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;Public opinion is still influenced in the main by memories of the 2008=</span><br><span>financial crisis and the recession that followed, so the candidates\' views o=</span><br><span>n DFA get special attention. type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Polling shows the American public believes strong financial reg=</span><br><span>ulation is critically needed (74 percent of Democrats, 56 percent Independen=</span><br><span>ts, 46 percent Republicans, 64 percent all voters). &amp;nbsp;Polling has also s=</span><br><span>hown that 66 percent of Americans are either =E2=80=9Cnot very familiar=E2=80=</span><br><span>=9D with or have =E2=80=9Cnever heard of=E2=80=9D Dodd-Frank. &amp;nbsp;It is di=</span><br><span>fficult for reasonable dialogue to be conducted in an environment made up of=</span><br><span>strong support for regulatory reform on one hand and a lack of knowledge of=</span><br><span>what is in DFA on the other.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Any public debate on DFA=</span><br><span>is hampered by the complexity of the issues involved. &amp;nbsp;Additionally, t=</span><br><span>here is a perception that it has failed in its objectives. &amp;nbsp;Beyond the f=</span><br><span>act that the law isn=E2=80=99t even fully implemented, major financial insti=</span><br><span>tutions have already begun restructuring in ways that indicate the law is wo=</span><br><span>rking properly. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;But how many voters know this?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>span&gt;Has Dodd-Frank Worked?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br></blockquote><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Great Recession and th=</span><br><span>e resulting Dodd-Frank Act changed the trajectory of the financial industry.=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;The law isn\'t perfect but it is having a stabilizing effect. &amp;nbsp;So=</span><br><span>me of the biggest firms on Wall Street -- MetLife, CitiGroup, General Electr=</span><br><span>ic -- have shrunk since the law was enacted and as a direct result of its re=</span><br><span>gulations. &amp;nbsp;Those that haven\'t shrunk are under even more pressure to b=</span><br><span>reak up or reduce their size now than they were before Dodd-Frank.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br></blockquote><span>te&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The candidates are split concerning whether or not DFA is an fu=</span><br><span>ll and sufficient model for regulating financial markets. &amp;nbsp;While HRC wa=</span><br><span>nts to preserve and protect the progress made by DFA while bolstering certai=</span><br><span>n parts of the law, while Sanders considers the law to be well intentioned y=</span><br><span>et deeply flawed. &amp;nbsp;However, questions should be raised about judging th=</span><br><span>e DFA=E2=80=99s efficacy right now - each candidate is forming an opinion on=</span><br><span>the act despite the fact that DFA hasn=E2=80=99t even reached maturity yet -=</span><br><span>only about 70 percent of DFA provisions have been implemented. &amp;nbsp;Beyond=</span><br><span>the implementation gap is the issue that the results of financial reform ca=</span><br><span>nnot be seen overnight. &amp;nbsp;A piece of legislation as large and multifacet=</span><br><span>ed as Dodd-Frank might take a decade to ripen. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Even a=</span><br><span>s the greatest effects of DFA remain to be see, recent events indicate that D=</span><br><span>FA is working as it was intended to. &amp;nbsp;Any candidate who claims that DFA=</span><br><span>is in need of major overhaul needs to answer this question: What pressing n=</span><br><span>eed is there to overturn a law that has, to this point, largely accomplished=</span><br><span>its overarching objectives? &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;2016 Candidates and Dodd=</span><br><span>-Frank&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The candidates in this year\'s primaries have gi=</span><br><span>ven voters two choices: stick with Dodd-Frank and add some tweaks or repeal i=</span><br><span>t/change it fundamentally. There is only one candidate in the former group -=</span><br><span>HRC. Every other candidate, including Bernie Sanders, intends to greatly ch=</span><br><span>ange Dodd-Frank, or get rid of it all together, if elected. With that choice=</span><br><span>in mind, it is necessary to remember how monumental Dodd-Frank was and the p=</span><br><span>olitical climate that it was passed in - one with a Democratic majority in b=</span><br><span>oth houses. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;DFA enjoyed widespread suppor=</span><br><span>t in the years immediately following its passage; Clinton needs to ring the a=</span><br><span>larm bells that her opponents intend to kill off an effective tool for regul=</span><br><span>ating Wall Street for the sake of trying out unproven strategies that are bu=</span><br><span>ilt more on ideology than policy. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br></blockquote><span>e"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Obviously, mo=</span><br><span>st Republican candidates would prefer to do away with Dodd-Frank completely a=</span><br><span>s it is greatly disliked by their biggest supporters. Bernie Sanders propose=</span><br><span>s something similar to Glass-Steagall, but also wants to create a list of th=</span><br><span>e banks that are "too-big-too-fail" and "break them up." He outlined his int=</span><br><span>entions in legislation he proposed to Congress back in May 2015. Bloomberg P=</span><br><span>olitics notes, "Similar to legislation he introduced in previous years, when=</span><br><span>Democrats controlled the U.S. Senate, the bill has little chance of advanci=</span><br><span>ng." &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;So voters can decide on strengthening a la=</span><br><span>w that is already working to reign in Wall Street\'s risks or abandoning it f=</span><br><span>or either less regulation or poorly aimed regulations. Considering the histo=</span><br><span>rical record of these other reform ideas, how can voters be expected to take=</span><br><span>those suggestions seriously?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote long-term basi=</span><br><span>s; the full ramifications of their decisions aren=E2=80=99t felt until month=</span><br><span>s or years out, so any contention that the economy is strong enough to handl=</span><br><span>e higher interest rates is essentially an endorsement of macroeconomic polic=</span><br><span>y in the last few years. its=3D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt; contractual agreements, the a=</span><br><span>rgument goes, then it creates a moral hazard f=3D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;or other compreh=</span><br><span>ensive, bipartisan, pro-growth tax reform abounded.&amp;nbsp; What=E2=80=99s hap=</span><br><span>pened since New Year=E2=80=99s Day?&amp;nbsp; A lot of interesting proposals hav=</span><br><span>e come forward to fix critical but narrow issues, and the bold talk of compr=</span><br><span>ehensive reform has remained just that =E2=80=93 talk.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span form.&amp;nbsp; More likely=</span><br><span>we=E2=80=99ll see smaller bills focused on particular issues.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p c=</span><br><span>lass=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-col=</span><br><span>or: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;b&gt;International&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b style=3D"b=</span><br><span>ackground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNorma=</span><br><span>l" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 25=</span><br><span>5, 255, 0);"&gt;President Obama, Senator Wyden, and Rep Brady, long ago hammere=</span><br><span>d home the need for international tax reform.&amp;nbsp; Their proposals include f=</span><br><span>inding a way to repatriate foreign-held profits of US-based multinationals, d=</span><br><span>ealing with corporate inversions, and setting up a new international tax cod=</span><br><span>e.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D=</span><br><span>"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The key to reaching an agreement=</span><br><span>on the proposals below likely lies in determining where revenue will go aft=</span><br><span>er foreign earning are brought back to the US.&amp;nbsp; Brady has said before t=</span><br><span>hat he wouldn=E2=80=99t support a proposal in which any tax is levied on for=</span><br><span>eign earnings, while Wyden says the opposite =E2=80=93 revenue is a requirem=</span><br><span>ent.&amp;nbsp; There is so much pressure for this to happen it=E2=80=99s hard to=</span><br><span>believe they can=E2=80=99t compromise.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-colo=</span><br><span>r: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D=</span><br><span>"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=</span><br><span>=80=A2 &amp;nbsp; taxing foreign earnings: &amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-c=</span><br><span>olor: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Competing proposals exist between parties.&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp; President Obama=E2=80=99s FY17 budget includes a 14 percent repatriation=</span><br><span>holiday with 19 percent tax thereafter on all foreign earnings.&amp;nbsp; Brady=</span><br><span>has said he=E2=80=99d rather these earnings come home with no tax attached,=</span><br><span>so that they can be used for investment.&amp;nbsp; Sen. Wyden proposes that the=</span><br><span>income be repatriated, taxed, and the revenue be used for infrastructure de=</span><br><span>velopment.&amp;nbsp; A recent bill by Schumer and Brown (below) would tax the fo=</span><br><span>reign income of any company that moves its headquarters overseas. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"bac=</span><br><span>kground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b style=3D"b=</span><br><span>ackground-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;preventing inversions:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;span st=</span><br><span>yle=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;Sen. Wyden pr=</span><br><span>oposes making the ownership minimum for a corporate inversion 50% (current l=</span><br><span>aw is 15%).&amp;nbsp; Reps Levin and Van Hollen have announced legislation to pr=</span><br><span>event =E2=80=9Cearnings stripping=E2=80=9D by reducing the tax preference fo=</span><br><span>r interest payments. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin=</span><br><span>: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Sens.=</span><br><span>Schumer and Brown have announced they will introduce two pieces of legislat=</span><br><span>ion to tackle inversions =E2=80=93 one to impose an exit tax on companies mo=</span><br><span>ving their address overseas, and another to limit earnings stripping.&amp;nbsp; T=</span><br><span>he exit tax proposal enforces the full 35 percent tax rate on all foreign ea=</span><br><span>rnings for companies that move abroad; their earnings stripping legislation l=</span><br><span>imits the tax-deducibility of interest payments to 25 oercent, down from the=</span><br><span>current 50 percent.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 2=</span><br><span>55, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt=</span><br><span>0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;territorial system:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255=</span><br><span>, 0);"&gt;&amp;nbsp;Brady has mentioned repeatedly that the US must adopt a territo=</span><br><span>rial system to remain competitive, whereby earnings from abroad are not taxe=</span><br><span>d in the US.&amp;nbsp; It=E2=80=99s been a perennial favorite of Republicans but=</span><br><span>likely will remain a non-starter for Democrats. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D=</span><br><span>"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgb=</span><br><span>a(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;b&gt;Corporate Tax Reform&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D=</span><br><span>"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgb=</span><br><span>a(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Many issues solved in international tax reform proposa=</span><br><span>ls would affect corporate tax reform efforts =E2=80=93 often the two are con=</span><br><span>sidered indelibly linked.&amp;nbsp; Prominent policymakers agree that the corpor=</span><br><span>ate rate must be lowered, but the final size of the tax and how it is aimed d=</span><br><span>iffer.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span st=</span><br><span>yle=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Republican proposals gener=</span><br><span>ally have rates between 0 and 20 percent, with Democrats above those at 24 p=</span><br><span>ercent and 28 percent for Wyden and Obama respectively.&amp;nbsp; New rules on d=</span><br><span>epreciations of assets =E2=80=93 specifically replacing the Modified Acceler=</span><br><span>ated Cost Recovery Systems with something less generous =E2=80=93 are being f=</span><br><span>loated as well.&amp;nbsp; Ending the tax-deductibility of debt is a dual-purpose=</span><br><span>proposal =E2=80=93 useful for preventing inversions (see above) as well as e=</span><br><span>ncouraging businesses to fund themselves using equity rather than credit.&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"backg=</span><br><span>round-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;u&gt;Earned Income Tax Credit&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"backgroun=</span><br></blockquote><span>d-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;A favorite of both Democrats and Republica=</span><br><span>ns =E2=80=93 and notable of Paul Ryan and President Obama.&amp;nbsp; They were r=</span><br><span>umored to discuss the issue during their first meeting, this past February, a=</span><br><span>fter Ryan=E2=80=99s ascension to Speaker.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"=</span><br><span>MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba=</span><br><span>(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;The EITC is a part of Obama=E2=80=99s budget proposal f=</span><br><span>or this year; he suggests&amp;nbsp;to expand the&amp;nbsp;EITC&amp;nbsp;for childless wo=</span><br><span>rkers and create a $500 =E2=80=9Csecond earner=E2=80=9D tax credit. The tota=</span><br><span>l cost would be $150 billion.&amp;nbsp;Ryan has proposed something that is very s=</span><br><span>imilar. In addition to that, there have been five recent congressional propo=</span><br><span>sals (introduced by Senators Sherrod Brown and Richard Durbin, by Rep. Richa=</span><br><span>rd Neal, by Rep. Charles Rangel, by Rep. Danny Davis, and by Senators Patty M=</span><br><span>urray, Jack Reed, and Sherrod Brown) that would substantially strengthen the=</span><br><span>EITC for childless workers. All of them, including Ryan=E2=80=99s and Obama=</span><br><span>=E2=80=99s, would lower the eligibility age to 21, and all would raise the m=</span><br><span>aximum credit =E2=80=94 the Obama and Ryan proposals to about $1,000 and the=</span><br><span>other proposals to somewhat higher amounts.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal=</span><br><span>" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255=</span><br><span>, 255, 0);"&gt;The recent focus on the issue makes it likely that something wil=</span><br><span>l be done on it soon. If Ryan and Obama can work together on this, it will b=</span><br><span>e a bipartisan light in the gridlocked darkness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D=</span><br><span>"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgb=</span><br><span>a(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;b&gt;Carried Interest&amp;nbsp;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p clas=</span><br><span>s=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color:=</span><br><span>rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;Senator Tammy Baldwin has released a proposal to t=</span><br><span>ax carried interest as a regular income rather than capital gains.&amp;nbsp; His=</span><br><span>torically this has been a particularly divisive issue, with lawmakers on the=</span><br><span>right refusing to entertain the idea.&amp;nbsp; However, recently Republicans h=</span><br><span>ave begun to soften on this position =E2=80=93 perhaps after seeing the popu=</span><br><span>list sentiment inspired by their presidential candidates=E2=80=99 own call t=</span><br><span>o end the loophole.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"ma=</span><br><span>rgin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;B=</span><br><span>aldwin released her proposal in conjunction with Sander Levin, who released a=</span><br><span>version of the bill in the House as well.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D=</span><br><span>"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;b style=3D"background-color: rgba(2=</span><br><span>55, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;&lt;u&gt;The Bottom Line&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p class=3D"MsoNormal" styl=</span><br><span>e=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255,=</span><br><span>0);"&gt;Any piece of tax reform legislation put forward which reduces revenues=</span><br><span>would have to find a way to offset its costs.&amp;nbsp; In light of the Obama-B=</span><br><span>oehner deal on spending limits for 2016 this may be a particularly important=</span><br><span>issue =E2=80=93 especially as GOP leaders try to keep their right flank in o=</span><br><span>rder as they tussle over the spending rules.&amp;nbsp; Conversely, any reform wh=</span><br><span>ich raises revenue will face strong calls from Republicans to fund tax cuts,=</span><br><span>and from Democrats to fund infrastructure or other initiatives.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>p class=3D"MsoNormal" style=3D"margin: 12pt 0in;"&gt;&lt;span style=3D"background-=</span><br><span>color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0);"&gt;As the year drags on the prospects for compr=</span><br><span>ehensive reform dwindle further =E2=80=93 they were never that great to begi=</span><br><span>n with, despite enthusiasm from party leaders.&amp;nbsp; Even the more modest pr=</span><br><span>oposals laid out here may be too divisive to survive, especially in a politi=</span><br><span>cal environment like this one.&amp;nbsp; Senators can=E2=80=99t be blamed for fo=</span><br><span>cusing their efforts on Supreme Court nominees, the budget, their own party c=</span><br><span>andidates, and more.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span&gt;____________________________=</span><br><span>_____&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;span style=3D"color: rgb=</span><br><span>a(0, 0, 0, 0.701961); being forced to draft =E2=80=9Cliving=</span><br><span>wills,=E2=80=9D which have already forced some to streamline or simplify so=</span><br><span>they can wind down without requiring a bailout&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>span&gt;Congressional Update&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Congress is split=</span><br><span>between those who want to reduce regulatory pressure on big banks and those=</span><br><span>who would rather see it ramped up. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Shelby, Senate Banking Chair,=</span><br><span>introduced the Financial Regulatory Improvement Act of 2015, a grab-bag of e=</span><br><span>xceptions and exemptions from regulations, mostly for banks with between $50=</span><br><span>and $500 billion in assets. &amp;nbsp;In a similar vein, Sens Warner, Portman, a=</span><br><span>nd Collins introduced the Independent Agency Regulatory Analysis Act to requ=</span><br><span>ire that regulators undertake a cost-benefit analysis of any rules they wish=</span><br><span>to implement.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;On the flip side, Sens. McCa=</span><br><span>in and Warren=E2=80=99s 21st Century Glass-Steagall Act proposes to split co=</span><br><span>mmercial and investment banks in a bid to finally kill off the TBTF problem.=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;Sens. Warren and Vitter teamed up early in 2015 to introduce a packag=</span><br><span>e of amendments to the Federal Reserve Act =E2=80=93- that bill notably woul=</span><br><span>d set forward stricter regulations when an entity is considered insolvent, a=</span><br><span>nd therefore ineligible for Federal Reserve loans, as well as require that t=</span><br><span>he Fed lend money to distressed institutions at market rates.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Regulators\' Agenda &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;=</span><br><span>Under Basel III requirements for large banks to satisfy Liquidity Coverage R=</span><br><span>atios (LCR) were adopted by a number of national regulators, including the Fe=</span><br><span>deral Reserve. &amp;nbsp;While the Fed has floated a rule change allowing some m=</span><br><span>unicipal bonds to count as High Quality Liquid Assets (HQLA), that hasn=E2=80=</span><br><span>=99t stopped Rep. Luke Messer from proposing HR 2209 to force regulators all=</span><br><span>ow a greater share of munis to count as HQLA (see Update, Feb. 18).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Fed is also working on implementing a rule on S=</span><br><span>ingle-Counterparty Credit Limits (SCCL), setting boundaries on credit exposu=</span><br><span>re between large banks or major counterparties. &amp;nbsp;The rule is meant to p=</span><br><span>revent banks from becoming overexposed to other financial institutions, prev=</span><br><span>enting them from taking overly large losses in the event that the counterpar=</span><br><span>ty fails. &amp;nbsp;Analysts suspect that firms are nearly $100 billion over the=</span><br><span>limits imposed by this rule, but Yellen says it is necessary to set a =E2=80=</span><br><span>=9Cbright line=E2=80=9D on credit exposure.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>SIFIs Moving Forward&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;There is no doubt tha=</span><br></blockquote><span>t the upcoming MetLife ruling will be a critical pivot point for how regulat=</span><br><span>ors interact with SIFIs. &amp;nbsp;If the FSOC is required to retract the firm=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s SIFI status it will open the regulator up for a whole slew of challe=</span><br><span>nges from other banks and institutions. &amp;nbsp;The fate of Congressional prop=</span><br><span>osals to restrict regulator=E2=80=99s efforts, either by determining rules f=</span><br><span>or them or by burdening them with regulations of their own, should be seen a=</span><br><span>s the start of a potential sea change in the regulatory climate. &amp;nbsp;Durin=</span><br><span>g his Monday meeting, President Obama warned of this: "If there is a signifi=</span><br><span>cant challenge in terms of regulating Wall Street and regulating our financi=</span><br><span>al sector it is primarily coming from certain members of Congress who are co=</span><br><span>nsistently pressuring independent regulators to back off.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;It is not a bad time to be a SIFI in America =E2=80=93=</span><br></blockquote><span>it=E2=80=99s certainly much better to be one now than in 2010. &amp;nbsp;While D=</span><br><span>FA has forced restructuring and streamlining to occur, events like the GE Ca=</span><br><span>pital sell-off may prove to be exceptions that prove the rule rather than th=</span><br><span>e new normal for SIFIs, especially if MetLife wins its case against regulato=</span><br><span>rs. &amp;nbsp;President Obama was right to point to Congress as the cause of reg=</span><br><span>ulatory gridlock; the political will seen after the economic collapse has Murkowski, S. 2=</span><br><span>012, which is next in line in the Senate following the opioid addiction bill=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;The energy bill will be voted on soon, providing that things moves q=</span><br><span>uickly (not a sure bet, since Dems may want to vote on certain amendments to=</span><br><span>the opioid bill). &amp;nbsp;Despite these potential hang ups, Senate leadership=</span><br><span>hopes to wrap up the energy bill by the end of the week =E2=80=93 giving th=</span><br><span>em some breathing room before the Senate adjourns for Easter recess by March=</span><br><span>21. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;While Sen. &amp;nbsp;below.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;Best,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;______________________________________&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;P=</span><br><span>uerto Rico=E2=80=99s Time Bomb&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Puerto R=</span><br><span>ican debt crisis has been an ongoing concern for both Congress, Wall Street a=</span><br><span>nd the Obama administration for some years now =E2=80=93 the territory=E2=80=</span><br><span>=99s bond ratings have been steadily dropping into the junk category and fel=</span><br><span>l from A- in 2005 to CCC+ last April. &amp;nbsp;At the heart of the matter is $7=</span><br><span>0 billion in bonds that Puerto Rico owes and says it cannot pay on. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Because Puerto Rican bonds are tax exempt in all 5=</span><br><span>0 states and the District of Columbia, making them incredibly popular invest=</span><br><span>ments for mutual funds, pensioners, and big banks. &amp;nbsp;Over 20 percent of m=</span><br><span>utual funds in the United States hold at least some Puerto Rican bonds, with=</span><br><span>$11.3 billion in portfolio, with a further $15 billion in bonds held by hed=</span><br><span>ge funds. &amp;nbsp;Now that the territory=E2=80=99s bonds are in the =E2=80=9Cj=</span><br><span>unk=E2=80=9D category, pension funds and insurance firms are unable to hold t=</span><br><span>hem any longer.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The diverse list of bond ho=</span><br><span>lders has thrown a wrench into the plans of those who would rather allow Pue=</span><br><span>rto Rico to default on its obligations =E2=80=93 something which would requi=</span><br><span>re legislative action (the territory doesn=E2=80=99t have that luxury, unlik=</span><br><span>e states). &amp;nbsp;If Puerto Rico is allowed to renege on its contractual agre=</span><br><span>ements, the argument goes, then it creates a moral hazard for other entities=</span><br><span>to do the same rather than make the tough choices necessary to honor their o=</span><br><span>bligations. &amp;nbsp;The fact that many of these bonds are essentially held by o=</span><br><span>rdinary Americans (through mutual funds and pensions) makes the argument all=</span><br><span>that stronger for many representatives. &amp;nbsp;A state hasn=E2=80=99t declar=</span><br><span>ed bankruptcy since Arkansas did so in 1933.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;Moral hazard is inherent in a debt restructuring deal; here, the path for P=</span><br><span>uerto Rico toward capital markets after anything of the sort would still be a=</span><br><span>n especially painful one (see: Argentina). &amp;nbsp;Additionally, there are few=</span><br><span>serious proposals to grant the island full Chapter 9 status. &amp;nbsp;Most opt=</span><br><span>instead for some form of negotiated haircut agreement combined with extendi=</span><br><span>ng maturities on the bonds; these proposals are likely to succeed, consideri=</span><br><span>ng Puerto Rico is almost certainly unable to maintain its bond payment sched=</span><br><span>ule without a restructuring agreement.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Admi=</span><br><span>nistration Position&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Testifying before the H=</span><br><span>ouse Committee on Natural Resources on Feb 25, Treasury official Antonio Wei=</span><br><span>ss warned lawmakers that Puerto Rico needs =E2=80=9Can immediate solution=E2=</span><br><span>=80=9D if it=E2=80=99s to survive past May 1, when a $470 million bond payme=</span><br><span>nt is due. &amp;nbsp;Soon after that, on July 1, a $1.9 billion bond payment wil=</span><br><span>l come due as well =E2=80=93 Puerto Rican representatives have already decla=</span><br><span>red they cannot meet those payments without assistance.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Weiss laid out the administration=E2=80=99s two-part plan: firs=</span><br><span>t the territory must be allowed to restructure its debt obligations, second a=</span><br><span>fiscal oversight board should be established to assist the island with mana=</span><br><span>ging its finances. &amp;nbsp;Importantly, Weiss stopped short of advocating for b=</span><br><span>ankruptcy protection for Puerto Rico and told the committee that =E2=80=9Can=</span><br><span>advisory board is not adequate to do the job=E2=80=9D alone. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;House Democrats voiced concern over the financial o=</span><br><span>versight board, Rep. Luis Guti=C3=A9rrez: =E2=80=9CThey=E2=80=99re saying th=</span><br><span>at there=E2=80=99s a joint responsibility, but it seems to me that all of th=</span><br><span>e responsibility is being weighed on the people of Puerto Rico.=E2=80=9D &amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Meanwhile Republicans claimed that any p=</span><br><span>lan to restructure Puerto Rican debt was a non-starter; a few hours after th=</span><br><span>e hearing the Republican Study Committee announced it would oppose any plan i=</span><br><span>ncluding such a provision. &amp;nbsp;"Changing the rules mid-game would be unfai=</span><br><span>r to Puerto Rico=E2=80=99s creditors who entered into these arrangements wit=</span><br><span>h agreed upon terms and would delegitimize future transactions," said RSC Ch=</span><br><span>airman Bill Flores.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Policy Options&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Until recently the two parties have maintained star=</span><br><span>kly contrasting views on how to best deal with Puerto Rico=E2=80=99s debt cr=</span><br><span>isis =E2=80=93 Democrats have pushed for a forced debt restructuring, with s=</span><br><span>ome calling for the island to be granted Chapter 9 bankruptcy protections, m=</span><br><span>eanwhile Republicans called for a financial oversight council to make the to=</span><br><span>ugh fiscal decisions necessary for Puerto Rico to maintain its debt obligati=</span><br><span>ons without reneging on its agreements.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The=</span><br><span>administration, through Weiss, has advocated a middle of the road approach.=</span><br><span>By adopting both proposals and avoiding the further edges of each (no bankr=</span><br><span>uptcy, and no unaccountable board staffed by Wall Streeters), the administra=</span><br><span>tion hopes to find compromise between each group. &amp;nbsp;And it seems like it=</span><br><span>might work.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Finding Compromise&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Recently, however, the conservative stance against deb=</span><br><span>t restructuring has lessened =E2=80=93 with some Republicans saying that the=</span><br><span>y could support a PR bill as long as it doesn=E2=80=99t include Chapter 9 ba=</span><br><span>nkruptcy. &amp;nbsp;House Natural Resources chair Bob Bishop has been working on=</span><br><span>a bill for Puerto Rico that does include some element of debt restructuring=</span><br><span>, and recently said =E2=80=9C=E2=80=9CI=E2=80=99m sure RSC will be satisfied=</span><br><span>with what we do =E2=80=A6 to say that some element of [debt restructuring] c=</span><br><span>ould be in there, yeah.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The House is still sticking to its end of March d=</span><br><span>eadline set by Speaker Ryan for putting forward a final bill on Puerto Rico o=</span><br><span>n the floor for a vote. Reg. &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 29) &amp;nbsp;Omnibus Review (Dec=</span><br><span>. 15)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Omnibus Situation &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 14)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;FY 2=</span><br><span>016 Omnibus Talks (Dec. 10)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Customs Bill &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 8)&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Tax Extender Negotiations &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 6) &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Brown o=</span><br><span>n HFT &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 4)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Shelby 2.0 Update &amp;nbsp;(Dec. 3)&lt;/span&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;________&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Mike &amp;a=</span><br><span>mp; Co. --&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;In half an hour, the BLS jobs re=</span><br><span>port for February is due to be released. &amp;nbsp;If you\'d like an update or ha=</span><br><span>ve any questions, please let me know. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Mean=</span><br><span>while, amid the most fractious campaign in recent history comes an initiativ=</span><br><span>e in Congress that sounds, well, incongruous with the cacophany. &amp;nbsp;A bro=</span><br><span>ad and bipartisan group of House members is behind the official launch of a c=</span><br><span>aucus this week dedicated to protecting and expanding the tax exemption enjo=</span><br><span>yed by municipal debt. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;You have to start s=</span><br><span>omewhere and why not with incentives to address the nation\'s long-neglected i=</span><br><span>nfrastructure with tax breaks -- about the only kind of stimulus and jobs me=</span><br><span>asure that can garner bipartisan support? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;More on the new Munici=</span><br><span>pal Finance Caucus below. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Best,&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;_________=</span><br><span>____________________________&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;A New Caucus&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;On Tuesday, Reps. Randy Hultgren and Dutch Ruppersberger anno=</span><br><span>unced that they have formed the Municipal Finance Caucus to protect the tax-=</span><br><span>exempt status of municipal debt and reexamine the way it is treated in finan=</span><br><span>cial regulations. &amp;nbsp;In 2015, Hultgren and Ruppersberger sent a letter (r=</span><br><span>eprinted below) to House leadership opposing the President=E2=80=99s propose=</span><br><span>d 28 percent cap on tax deductions for municipal bonds, signed by over 120 o=</span><br><span>f their colleagues. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Their announceme=</span><br><span>nt coincided with the National Association of State Treasurers=E2=80=99 legi=</span><br><span>slative conference in D.C. The same group drafted another letter, signed by m=</span><br><span>ore than 600 state and local officials, which urges the leaders of the House=</span><br><span>Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee to reject curbs t=</span><br><span>o the muni exemption. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Who=E2=80=99s in it?=</span><br><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Right now just the founding representative=</span><br><span>s have declared their official membership, but it=E2=80=99s foreseeable that=</span><br><span>some of the 120 representatives that signed the letter to House leadership i=</span><br><span>n 2015 will join as well. &amp;nbsp;It=E2=80=99s also seen a s likely that some S=</span><br><span>enators will want to join the caucus, but the founders haven\'t made clear if=</span><br><span>bicameral membership is a priority.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Is it B=</span><br><span>ipartisan?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Since 2013 Hultgren and Ruppersb=</span><br><span>erger have led bipartisan efforts to draft letters of support for municipal b=</span><br><span>onds. &amp;nbsp;The signatories to these letters include members from both sides=</span><br><span>of the aisle. &amp;nbsp;Rep. Ruppersberger focuses mostly on local government a=</span><br><span>nd is pretty moderate. Rep. Hultgren is a more orthodox conservative Republi=</span><br><span>can. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;What=E2=80=99s the Purpose?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Caucus plans to defend municipal bonds=E2=80=99 t=</span><br></blockquote><span>ax exempt status and advocate for regulatory changes which favor those bonds=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;Proposals to limit the tax-exempt status of these bonds have been fl=</span><br><span>oated in recent years. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;In addition to call=</span><br><span>ing for the bonds to maintain their tax preferred status, the Caucus will pu=</span><br><span>sh for the passage of HR 2209, legislation considering municipal bonds as a H=</span><br><span>igh Quality Liquid Asset (HQLA) =E2=80=93 a particularly contentious issue b=</span><br><span>ecause of the disagreement over how flexible these liquidity rules should be=</span><br><span>from a systemic risk perspective. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Positio=</span><br><span>ns Taken to Date&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Caucus founders have o=</span><br><span>pposed Obama=E2=80=99s 2015 proposal to cap municipal bond tax exemption at 2=</span><br><span>8 percent. Rep. Hultgren is also a co-sponsor of HR 2209 =E2=80=93 the bill t=</span><br><span>o set the liquidity for municipal bond assets at Level 2A (see Update, Feb. 1=</span><br><span>8). &amp;nbsp;Hultgren said the liquidity rules are an example of how regulators=</span><br><span>misunderstand municipal bonds, specifically the frequent serial structure o=</span><br><span>f the their issuances.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Many investors flock=</span><br><span>to municipal bonds for security. But some federal regulators trying to shor=</span><br><span>e up the banking system aren\'t convinced the bonds would be easy to sell in a=</span><br><span>crisis. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Division of Opinion&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Division of opinion on HR 2099 falls along unusual lines=</span><br><span>, with Wall Street, Congress and municipal officials challenging bank regula=</span><br><span>tors\' skepticism toward municipal debt. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;At issue are new rules a=</span><br><span>imed at ensuring banks can raise enough cash during a financial-market meltd=</span><br><span>own to fund their operations for 30 days. The requirements mean banks have t=</span><br><span>o hold more cash or securities that are easily sellable. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Regulators don\'t think it is the place of Congress to second g=</span><br><span>uess how they size up securities. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, at a congress=</span><br><span>ional hearing Feb. 11, said legislation would "interfere with our supervisor=</span><br><span>y judgments." &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Big banks such as Citigroup I=</span><br><span>nc. and Wells Fargo &amp;amp; Co. have sprung into action in lobbying Congress, a=</span><br><span>long with municipal leaders who fret the rules will diminish bank bond-buyin=</span><br><span>g which could raise borrowing costs on infrastructure projects.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;Hultgren also said the caucus will work to update the n=</span><br><span>umber of projects that could be financed by qualified small issue manufactur=</span><br><span>ing bonds, a type of private-activity bond whose proceeds can be used to fin=</span><br><span>ance manufacturing facilities for small- and mid-sized manufacturers. The ta=</span><br><span>x code provisions on small industrial development bonds have not been change=</span><br><span>d since the 1980s, he said. Hultgren sponsored a bill last year entitled =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9CThe Modernizing American Manufacturing Bonds Act,=E2=80=9D which was f=</span><br><span>ocused on expanding opportunities for qualified small issue manufacturing bo=</span><br><span>nds, particularly by changing the national volume cap set by Congress. &lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;What can be achieved?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;span&gt;Caucuses such as this one don\'t have the best reputation when it com=</span><br><span>es to getting things done. &amp;nbsp;But rules relating to the liquidity value o=</span><br><span>f capital is one of the few policy &amp;nbsp;areas of any kind where there is bi=</span><br><span>partisan agreement. &amp;nbsp;Municipal bonds, in particular, have a universal a=</span><br><span>ppeal because of their direct link to local and state infrastructure project=</span><br><span>s. &amp;nbsp;At the very least, the caucus will spark some discussion about the b=</span><br><span>est way to both reform existing methods for funding infrastructure investmen=</span><br><span>t and find new ways to fund it. issue in Flint and elsewhere. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Here, we look at t=</span><br><span>he bill\'s provisions, its funding steam, and its prospects. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote Prospects&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;A bipartisan deal has=</span><br><span>been reached in the Senate last week to aid the beleaguered city of Flint, M=</span><br><span>ichigan as it tries to remedy its drinking water issues. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Inhofe, t=</span><br><span>he lead GOP Senator on the bill, called it =E2=80=9Ccommon-sense," and noted=</span><br><span>that the spending is already programmed and involves no supplemental approp=</span><br><span>riation. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The bill may be ready to move forward after Sen. Cruz l=</span><br><span>ifted a hold he had placed on the bill last week. &amp;nbsp;Sen. Mike Lee is sti=</span><br><span>ll a hold-out. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The b=</span><br><span>ill provides $250 million to assist the residents of Flint, Michigan and oth=</span><br><span>er American cities experiencing critical problems with their water supplies b=</span><br><span>y increasing funding for Drinking Water Act State Revolving Funds and provid=</span><br><span>e start-up funding for the new Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation A=</span><br><span>ct. &amp;nbsp;It also provides:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$100 million for Drinking Water State Revolving=</span><br></blockquote><span>Funds (SRFs) accessible by any state with a drinking water emergency. &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;It requires states to submit plans explaining how the money will be spent t=</span><br><span>o address the emergency before funding is provided. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Funds that r=</span><br><span>emain after 18 months will be distributed to all states under the existing S=</span><br><span>RF formula. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$70 million in funding to back secured loans made under the new=</span><br><span>Water Infrastructure Finance and Innovation Act (WIFIA). &amp;nbsp;A federal in=</span><br><span>vestment of $70 million could support secured loans of up to $4.2 billion to=</span><br><span>address water and wastewater infrastructure needs across the country, accor=</span><br><span>ding to Sen. Inhofe=E2=80=99s office. &amp;nbsp;All states and all communities w=</span><br><span>ith clean water and drinking water infrastructure needs are eligible for thi=</span><br><span>s assistance. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=</span><br><span>=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;$50 million for various in authorized health programs for na=</span><br><span>tional use to address and prevent impacts from exposure to lead. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Where will the money come from?=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The package has been fully paid for -- it redirects appropriati=</span><br><span>ons by taking funds from the Advanced Technology Vehicles Manufacturing (ATV=</span><br><span>M) Fund, which offers loans for auto companies. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Does that matter? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Per Sen. Inhofe =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9C[the ATVM is] a failed program that hasn=E2=80=99t been used in more t=</span><br><span>han a year and has only issued five loans since 2008."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;More on ATVM: The ATVM program is authoriz=</span><br><span>ed to award up to $25 billion in loans; there is no deadline for completing s=</span><br><span>uch loan commitments. Congress funded the program in 2009, when it appropria=</span><br><span>ted $7.5 billion to cover the subsidy cost for the $25 billion in loans, as w=</span><br><span>ell as $10 million for program implementation. Since the start of the progra=</span><br><span>m, DOE has awarded $8.4 billion in loans to five companies. As of January 20=</span><br><span>15, ATVM has $16.6 billion in remaining loan authority. No new loans have be=</span><br><span>en made since 2011. Two companies =E2=80=94 Fisker and the Vehicle Productio=</span><br><span>n Group =E2=80=94 were unable to make payments on their loans, and DOE aucti=</span><br><span>oned the loans off in the fall of 2013. Tesla paid off all of its loan in 20=</span><br><span>13, nine years ahead of schedule. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Criticisms of ATVM: The unobligated funds remaining for the pro=</span><br><span>gram have been a point of contention in recent appropriations debates. The H=</span><br><span>ouse has voted several times to transfer some of the unused appropriation fo=</span><br><span>r the ATVM subsidy costs to other purposes. None of these transfers were ena=</span><br><span>cted. Other legislators have sought to expand the program. Two recent federa=</span><br><span>l reports call for rescinding the program=E2=80=99s unobligated balance: the=</span><br><span>FY2015 budget resolution reported by the House Budget Committee calls for o=</span><br><span>utright rescission, and an April 2014 GAO report recommends Congress conside=</span><br><span>r taking the same step unless DOE can generate new demand for the program.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Legislative Strategy: &amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Architects of the bipartisan deal put out a hotline request to se=</span><br><span>e if anyone would object to a series of procedural moves that would split Fl=</span><br><span>int aid off the energy bill (S. 2012), attach it to a House bill (H.R. 4470)=</span><br><span>sponsored by Reps. Dan Kildee and Fred Upton, allow voice votes on 30 amend=</span><br><span>ments to the energy bill, and allow roll call votes on eight additional amen=</span><br><span>dments. Michigan Sens. Debbie Stabenow and Gary Peters said Democrats are on=</span><br><span>board, but in order to achieve unanimous consent, Republicans need to sign o=</span><br><span>n. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Will it pass? &amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;The Flint package and the energy bill amendments would come to a vote onl=</span><br><span>y after the Senate gets unanimous consent to some procedural maneuvers. Lee\'=</span><br><span>s hold went unnoticed earlier when GOP presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz h=</span><br><span>ad a hold of his own, which he has now lifted. The Senate had hoped to hold v=</span><br><span>otes on Flint and end debate on the energy bill as early as next week. &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;What=E2=80=99s Next? &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sen. Stabenow,=</span><br><span>a key leader on the bill, predicted that =E2=80=9Cone way or another=E2=80=9D=</span><br><span>the package would be voted on in the Senate this week. &amp;nbsp;And while the H=</span><br><span>ouse hasn\'t decided what it will do if the Flint bill clears the Senate, Ene=</span><br><span>rgy and Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton said it would move quickly.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Obama administration, which declared Fl=</span><br><span>int a federal emergency in January freeing up much-needed funds for the dist=</span><br><span>ressed city, has not issued an official stance on the Flint deal. &amp;nbsp;Earl=</span><br><span>y in the year the President also made available to the state of Michigan $80=</span><br><span>million from a revolving fund for infrastructure repair and improvement. &amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;A number of important events are sch=</span><br><span>eduled for the month of March, listed below.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan&gt; type=3D"cit=</span><br><span>e"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Bill&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209 requires federal banking regulators=</span><br></blockquote><span>to include municipal bonds under the Liquidity Coverage Ratio (LCR). &amp;nbsp;=</span><br><span>The LCR is designed to ensure that financial institutions have the necessary=</span><br><span>assets available to handle a liquidity disruption. &amp;nbsp;Local officials ha=</span><br><span>ve said that if the new rules aren=E2=80=99t changed, it will saddle them wi=</span><br><span>th higher borrowing costs by eliminating incentives banks have to purchase t=</span><br><span>heir bonds. Without bonds, these governments will lose a significant source o=</span><br><span>f their funding. &amp;nbsp;Per Indiana State Treasurer Kelly Mitchell: =E2=80=9C=</span><br><span>This bill helps ensure cash-strapped school districts and municipalities wil=</span><br><span>l continue to have access to bonds to finance projects they think are best f=</span><br><span>or their communities.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"c=</span><br><span>ite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Rep. Luke=</span><br><span>Messer, an Indiana Republican who wrote the bill: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CPut simply=</span><br><span>, our bill requires the federal government to recognize the obvious, that ou=</span><br><span>r municipal bonds are some of the safest investments in the world and that w=</span><br><span>e shouldn=E2=80=99t have rules that give preferential treatment to corporate=</span><br><span>bonds or other countries=E2=80=99 bonds over our own.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;After passing the House with unanimous bipartisan su=</span><br><span>pport, a companion bill is expected to be introduced in the Senate this year=</span><br><span>. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Municipal Bond Issue&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;After the crisis of 2008, federal regulators adopted=</span><br><span>international banking standards that require banks to have enough "High-Qua=</span><br><span>lity Liquid Assets" to cover their cash outflows for 30 days in case of a fu=</span><br><span>ture financial meltdown. &amp;nbsp;Now, municipal bonds are not considered liqui=</span><br><span>d assets and therefore cannot be included under the &amp;nbsp;LCR. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;A=</span><br><span>s a result, financial institutions have been discouraged from holding munici=</span><br><span>pal debt, which means that cash strapped municipalities and school districts=</span><br><span>may eventually be forced to reduce or even stop work on projects &amp;nbsp;fina=</span><br><span>nced with municipal bonds. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Infrastructur=</span><br></blockquote><span>e Financing -- Alternative Financing&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=</span><br><span>=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=</span><br><span>=A2 &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Tax-exempt bonds: &amp;nbsp;Exemption from federal taxes and man=</span><br><span>y state and local taxes is possible through the use of municipal bonds. &amp;nbs=</span><br><span>p;&amp;nbsp;In recent years, with the increasing use of PPPs, barriers to this t=</span><br><span>ax exemption have arisen. &amp;nbsp;Treasury has reviewed relevant tax rules and=</span><br><span>based on their findings and have put forth a proposal for an expanded and p=</span><br><span>ermanent America Fast Forward Bond Program as an alternative to tax-exempt b=</span><br><span>onds. &amp;nbsp;Based on the successful Build America Bond program, =E2=80=9Cwou=</span><br><span>ld provide an efficient borrowing subsidy to state and local governments whi=</span><br><span>le appealing to a broader investor base than traditional tax-exempt bonds [a=</span><br><span>nd] would cover a broad range of projects for which tax-exempt bonds can be u=</span><br><span>sed.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;Obama=E2=80=</span><br></blockquote><span>=99s budget proposal: &amp;nbsp;Obama has also put forth a plan to strengthen lo=</span><br><span>cal and state government infrastructure projects. His plan relies on a new Fe=</span><br><span>deral credit program to support public-private partnerships within the Depar=</span><br><span>tment of the Treasury. It will provide direct loans to US infrastructure pro=</span><br><span>jects developed through PPPs. The Obama Administration believes that private=</span><br><span>investment is crucial for infrastructure development moving forward, so the=</span><br><span>re should be more flexibility in regards to what PPP is subject to. In addit=</span><br><span>ion to that, President Obama has proposed the taxable, direct-pay America Fa=</span><br><span>st Forward bond program to help finance infrastructure. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;State Infrastructure Banks&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Local governments receive financing in a number of ways. &amp;nbsp;Tradi=</span><br><span>tional sources such as tax revenues have been dwindling and local authoritie=</span><br><span>s have been relying on federal government loan programs, public-private part=</span><br><span>nerships, and State Revolving Funds (SRFs). &amp;nbsp;State Infrastructure Banks=</span><br><span>(SIBs) are a subset of SRFs -- the funds act like a bank, because they don=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99t own the infrastructure asset, but act as a lender or guarantor to th=</span><br><span>e project sponsor. Per Brookings: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CSRFs rely on principal repa=</span><br><span>yments, bonds, interest and fees to re-capitalize and replenish the fund as a=</span><br><span>perpetual source of debt financing.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>span&gt;SIBs generate more investment per dollar than traditional federal and s=</span><br><span>tate grant programs. &amp;nbsp;They only exist in 33 states and 10 of those SIBs=</span><br><span>are currently inactive. A large problem may be compliance with federal regu=</span><br><span>lations. &amp;nbsp;Brookings again: &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"=</span><br><span>cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=9C=</span><br><span>We found that many SIB officials cite compliance with federal regulations as=</span><br><span>slowing down the investment process either because of environmental and con=</span><br><span>tractual requirements or due to the lack of flexibility in projects that are=</span><br><span>not Title 23 or 49 eligible. For states with smaller projects, this may be p=</span><br><span>rohibitively costly compared to the advantage of using the low-cost SIB fina=</span><br><span>ncing.=E2=80=9D &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Just being called a bank=</span><br><span>subjects SIBs to regulations that commercial banks are subject to. &amp;nbsp;SI=</span><br><span>Bs are non-for-profit organizations with a goal of increasing infrastructure=</span><br><span>investment, so they don=E2=80=99t quite fit into the category of the averag=</span><br><span>e bank. &amp;nbsp;SIBs may be more successful outside this classification. &amp;nbsp=</span><br><span>;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;For or Against Dodd-Frank&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Before Dodd-Frank, particularly in the case of relativ=</span><br><span>ely small municipalities, many underwriters forged long-term relationships w=</span><br><span>ith municipalities and would provide financial advice before and after a bon=</span><br><span>d issuance. &amp;nbsp;With Dodd-Frank, that relationship changed, with a new =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9Cmunicipal adviser=E2=80=9D category that must register with the SEC an=</span><br><span>d be regulated by the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board (MSR). &amp;nbsp;Now=</span><br><span>, it is widely illegal to provide advice to governmental entities concerning=</span><br><span>the issuance of municipal bonds, the use of financial derivatives, and the i=</span><br><span>nvestment of the proceeds of a bond issue to, or on behalf, of a municipal e=</span><br><span>ntity or an obligated person unless the adviser is registered with the SEC. &lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquo=</span><br><span>te&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209 appears to address a problem with=</span><br><span>in Dodd-Frank, but it is unclear if it vitiates the law materially. &amp;nbsp;At=</span><br><span>face value, it appears to be more a technical fix. Dodd-Frank expanded regu=</span><br><span>lations for banking institutions, but the entities that fund state and local=</span><br><span>governments are far unlike the TBTF institutions that Dodd-Frank was meant t=</span><br><span>o regulate. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Groups like Amer=</span><br><span>icans for Financial Reform oppose HR 2209: =E2=80=9CWhile we sympathize with=</span><br><span>the belief that municipal debt was incorrectly treated under the initial LC=</span><br><span>R rule, we believe that it is inappropriate to classify such debt as a Level=</span><br><span>2A asset. AFR therefore opposes this bill unless a more appropriate liquidi=</span><br><span>ty classification is used.=E2=80=9D &amp;nbsp;AFR has previously said it support=</span><br><span>s treating municipal bonds as more liquid and does not approve the type of c=</span><br><span>lassification used in HR 2209, because it goes too far in its treatment of m=</span><br><span>unicipal debt as level 2A liquid assets and specifically with micromanaging r=</span><br><span>egulators with this kind of detail and they prefer a Level 2B classification=</span><br><span>. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bill could provide relief for smal=</span><br><span>ler institutions, so that they can fund infrastructure investment more easil=</span><br><span>y. In terms of Dodd-Frank, it is yet to be decided if it is simply a necessa=</span><br><span>ry tweak or a criticism. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;=</span><br><span>nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;span&gt;Looking Ahead&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=</span><br></blockquote><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;HR 2209 could end up=</span><br><span>being an important issue in the national infrastructure discussion. &amp;nbsp;I=</span><br><span>t brings up questions about how far a state or local government can go befor=</span><br><span>e its activities begin to resemble an actual bank. &amp;nbsp;With the growth of P=</span><br><span>PPs, the private sector is being even more integrated into the process =E2=80=</span><br><span>=93 should those companies be given tax exemptions, as well?
