legisla=</span><br><span>tion. &amp;nbsp;National Association of Manufacturers=E2=80=99 president Jay Tim=</span><br><span>mons said =E2=80=9Cif senators want to grow manufacturing in the United Stat=</span><br><span>es, then they should pass this bill immediately.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote typ=</span><br><span>e=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Notable =E2=80=9CNay=E2=80=9D votes include Sens. Durbin an=</span><br><span>d Reid, who both expressed disappointment that the legislation was a =E2=80=9C=</span><br><span>watered down=E2=80=9D version of a bill previously passed by the Senate. &amp;nb=</span><br><span>sp;=E2=80=9DI like that [Senate] version, and that strong language on curren=</span><br><span>cy manipulation,=E2=80=9D Durbin said =E2=80=93 that language required Comme=</span><br><span>rce to consider =E2=80=9Cundervalued=E2=80=9D currencies to be equivalent to=</span><br><span>countervailable subsidies. &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CThe conference report that=E2=80=99=</span><br><span>s back to us now and before the Senate at this moment is a much different bi=</span><br><span>ll."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Purpose and Provisions&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;House and Senate negotiators agreed on a final customs=</span><br><span>bill in December. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The House passed the measure 256-158 but the l=</span><br><span>egislation stalled in the Senate over a provision added in conference that p=</span><br><span>ermanently extends a moratorium on Internet access taxes.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote typ=</span><br><span>e=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;That provision is perhaps the most reported on section in t=</span><br><span>he bill =E2=80=93 it=E2=80=99s almost certainly the most popular - it applie=</span><br><span>s to localities, states, and the federal government itself. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Sen.=</span><br><span>Lamar Alexander cited it though as explanation for his =E2=80=9Cnay=E2=80=9D=</span><br><span>vote: "the federal government shouldn\'t be telling the states what their ta=</span><br><span>x structure should be."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Another important=</span><br><span>provision, known as the ENFORCE Act, would require the CBP to more aggressi=</span><br><span>vely investigate complaints that companies are evading anti-dumping or count=</span><br><span>ervailing duties on imports by mislabeling or disguising the shipments.&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bill includes a new Trade Enforcement Fun=</span><br><span>d to bring trade cases through the WTO, to investigate the implementation of=</span><br><span>trade requirements by other countries, and to respond to complaints of trad=</span><br><span>e violations. &amp;nbsp;It also creates a nine-member Advisory Committee on Inte=</span><br><span>rnational Exchange Rate Policy, whose members must be comprised of individua=</span><br><span>ls from the private sector who are selected by both chambers of Congress and=</span><br><span>the President (three members each).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=</span><br><span>=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Curr=</span><br><span>ency Manipulation&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Currency manipulation h=</span><br><span>as been a long-standing concern of American policy-makers and a particularly=</span><br><span>contentious issue in global trade relations; claims that China has been chr=</span><br><span>onically undervaluing its currency have made the news for a number of years.=</span><br><span>&amp;nbsp;Advocates for stricter enforcement of currency manipulation provision=</span><br><span>s claim that undervalued currencies operate similarly to export subsidies =E2=</span><br><span>=80=93 a prohibited practice within the World Trade Organization.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The final bill dropped a Senate provision that woul=</span><br><span>d have required the Commerce Department to treat undervalued currency as an i=</span><br><span>llegal subsidy under U.S. countervailing duty law. &amp;nbsp;This provision woul=</span><br><span>d have opened the door for compensatory tariffs to be levied against goods w=</span><br><span>hich originate from countries which are found to purposely undervalue their c=</span><br><span>urrency in order to boost their exports. The bill does, however, include oth=</span><br><span>er measures that give the Treasury Department new tools to fight currency ma=</span><br><span>nipulation:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>r&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;creates a spe=</span><br><span>cial fund for the CBP to ensure trading partners follow the rules and to bri=</span><br><span>ng disputes before the WTO&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;increases funding to the National Intellectual Propert=</span><br><span>y Rights Coordination Center&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;establishes the Commercial Customs Operations Adviso=</span><br><span>ry Committee jointly between CBP and Treasury&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=E2=80=A2 &amp;nbsp;requires CBP to investigate claims f=</span><br><span>rom other agencies of evasion of anti-dumping or countervailing duties.&lt;/spa=</span><br><span>n&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Relation to TPP&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;span&gt;Sen. Majority Leader McConnell has said that the Senate will not vote o=</span><br><span>n the Trans-Pacific Partnership before the November elections, so it may com=</span><br><span>e as a surprise to see a bill which deals with enforcing trade deals like TP=</span><br><span>P pass both houses of Congress. &amp;nbsp;However this bill=E2=80=99s provisions=</span><br><span>for protecting IP rights, toughening countervailing duties, and tackling cu=</span><br><span>rrency manipulation are a necessary prerequisite for agreements like TPP (or=</span><br><span>the far more nebulous TTIP). &amp;nbsp;The new age of trade agreements &amp;nbsp;wi=</span><br><span>ll deal extensively in issues like intellectual property protection, trade i=</span><br><span>n services, and high-tech product trading; types of commerce which are far m=</span><br><span>ore difficult to regulate compared to the trade of physical goods.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br></blockquote><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;So, despite the fact that TPP won=E2=80=99t get a v=</span><br><span>ote until after November (and perhaps not in 2016 at all), and may not pass e=</span><br><span>ven then, the protections set forward in the customs bill are necessary to a=</span><br><span>llow American companies to continue to compete in the global marketplace.&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Price of Passage&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br></blockquote><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cit=</span><br><span>e"&gt;&lt;span&gt;In order to include the permanent extension of the Internet Tax Fre=</span><br><span>edom Act, McConnell had to promise that a vote would be held this year on th=</span><br><span>e Marketplace Fairness Act. &amp;nbsp;That legislation grants states greater aut=</span><br><span>hority to collect sales taxes from online businesses who sell products withi=</span><br><span>n their borders. &amp;nbsp;While McConnell himself opposes the bill, it was the o=</span><br><span>nly way to get the customs bill (with the tax amendment attached) unstuck.&lt;/=</span><br><span>span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Just because McConnell has promised it wil=</span><br><span>l be brought to a vote doesn=E2=80=99t mean it will be a smooth process - th=</span><br><span>e Senate passed the Marketplace Fairness Act in 2013 with 69 votes, and most=</span><br><span>of the lawmakers who voted for it are still in the chamber. &amp;nbsp;Some lawm=</span><br><span>akers like Kelly Ayotte, who is facing a tough reelection campaign this year=</span><br><span>, have vowed to fight tooth-and-nail against it. &amp;nbsp;Despite these detract=</span><br><span>ors in the Senate, the real battle may occur in the House, where two competi=</span><br><span>ng proposals have been brought forward. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote Co. &amp;nbsp;--&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;One thing th=</span><br><span>e two parties agree is that international tax reform is a fiscally necessary=</span><br><span>issue to take up -- that Uncle Sam is leaving hundreds of billions of dolla=</span><br><span>rs on the table overseas annually. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;But they would also generally=</span><br><span>agree that it is not going to get done this year. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Under current law, those profits are subject only to fede=</span><br><span>ral taxes if they are returned, or repatriated, to the U.S. where they face a=</span><br><span>top rate of 35 percent. &amp;nbsp;Many companies avoid U.S. taxes on those earn=</span><br><span>ings by simply leaving them overseas.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>lockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockqu=</span><br><span>ote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;T=</span><br><span>here is bipartisan activity on the issue in both houses of Congress. Obama h=</span><br><span>as a major reform proposal on the table. &amp;nbsp;So is this the year, in the y=</span><br><span>ear of surprises?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Best,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blo=</span><br><span>ckquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquot=</span><br><span>e type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Dana&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Reforms in t=</span><br><span>he area of international tax deal with both the repatriation of foreign-deri=</span><br><span>ved profits and the issue of corporate inversions. &amp;nbsp;Testifying today, T=</span><br><span>reasury Secretary Jack Lew encouraged the parties in Congress to overcome th=</span><br><span>eir differences on both, which he believes surmountable: &amp;nbsp;=E2=80=9CI ju=</span><br><span>st want to underscore the urgency of dealing with inversions =E2=80=A6 We ca=</span><br><span>n=E2=80=99t wait a year to deal with this,=E2=80=9D Lew said during a Senate=</span><br><span>Finance hearing on the Obama administration=E2=80=99s budget. US-ba=</span><br><span>sed businesses from paying taxes on income earned abroad. &amp;nbsp;He also want=</span><br><span>s to lower the corporate rate to 20 percent. &amp;nbsp;In the face of these of bi-annual checkup. No news was made, n=</span><br><span>o fireworks went off and no market mood swings occurred. &amp;nbsp;As for the Fe=</span><br><span>d\'s next move, it\'s wait-and-see a little while longer. type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Fed Chair Yellen testi=</span><br><span>fied before House Financial Services this morning for the Federal Reserve=E2=</span><br><span>=80=99s bi-annual Monetary Policy Report. &amp;nbsp;These appearances allow Yell=</span><br><span>en to explain the Fed=E2=80=99s, actually the Federal Open Market Committee (=</span><br><span>FOMC)=E2=80=99s, analysis and projections regarding America\'s economic perfo=</span><br><span>rmance as well as to signal the factors underlying its actions in the months=</span><br><span>ahead. &amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The r=</span><br><span>ate change in December 2015 was the first time the Fed raised rates since 20=</span><br><span>06 -- some worry that even a modest increase in rates at this juncture would=</span><br><span>further slow already limited economic growth after years of uncertainty.&lt;/s=</span><br><span>pan&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;bl=</span><br><span>ockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Basics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The bottom line: the FOMC won=</span><br><span>=E2=80=99t rollback rates in March and it=E2=80=99s not likely to raise them=</span><br><span>either. &amp;nbsp;The Fed likes what it sees in the labor market, wage growth l=</span><br><span>ooks strong, and emerging market missteps continue to be a threat to the US e=</span><br><span>conomy but perhaps not an immediate one. &amp;nbsp;The next rate move is almost c=</span><br><span>ertain to be an increase but it could wait until June or later. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Yellen reiterated much of the FO=</span><br><span>MC statement from last month: &amp;nbsp;the labor market remains strong, but sho=</span><br><span>ws some signs of remaining slack, that the low inflation we have seen is cau=</span><br><span>sed by =E2=80=9Ctransitory=E2=80=9D effects (low energy prices), and that gl=</span><br><span>obal market uncertainty creates some level of risk for slow growth at home a=</span><br><span>nd abroad. &amp;nbsp;Though Yellen did not make a prediction on how long these t=</span><br><span>ransitory market effects would last, a number of forecasts for oil prices sh=</span><br><span>ow the dip lasting through 2016.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Expanding on global growth issues, Yellen said "These developme=</span><br><span>nts, if they prove persistent, could weigh on the outlook for economic activ=</span><br><span>ity and the labor market, although declines in longer-term interest rates an=</span><br><span>d oil prices could provide some offset," she added: "Foreign economic develo=</span><br><span>pments, in particular, pose risks to US economic growth." &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/block=</span><br><span>quote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Partisan Review&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;=</span><br><span>The GOP is generally critical of "accommodative" (lower) Fed rates. &amp;nbsp;&amp;n=</span><br><span>bsp;High-net-worth individuals benefit the most from high rates through divi=</span><br><span>dends and interest from savings. &amp;nbsp;Low rates allow more growth for the m=</span><br><span>iddle- and lower-classes at the risk of inflation, tacitly supporting Democr=</span><br><span>ats=E2=80=99 progressive fiscal policy goals. &amp;nbsp;Some conservative econom=</span><br><span>ists have gone so far as to blame low interest rates pushed by the Fed in th=</span><br><span>e 1990=E2=80=99s for the market meltdown in 2007, claiming that cheap credit=</span><br><span>was the cause of the overheated housing market.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/bl=</span><br><span>ockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;b=</span><br><span>lockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockqu=</span><br><span>ote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"=</span><br><span>cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Strong Labor Market&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote t=</span><br><span>ype=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Discu=</span><br><span>ssing the labor market in greater detail, Yellen pointed to the cumulative i=</span><br><span>ncrease in employment since 2010 of 13 million jobs. &amp;nbsp;The rate in Janua=</span><br><span>ry fell to 4.9 percent, 0.8 points below its level one year ago; measures of=</span><br><span>labor market conditions such as the number of people who are working part-t=</span><br><span>ime but want to move to full-time positions and the number of individuals wh=</span><br><span>o want to work but haven=E2=80=99t searched recently are also decreasing ste=</span><br><span>adily. &amp;nbsp;Regarding these broader labor market indicators Yellen testifie=</span><br><span>d that =E2=80=9C=E2=80=A6 these measures remain above the levels seen prior t=</span><br><span>o the recession, suggesting that some slack in labor markets remains. Thus, w=</span><br><span>hile labor market conditions have improved substantially, there is still roo=</span><br><span>m for further sustainable improvement."&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;Forward Guidance&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockq=</span><br><span>uote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span=</span><br><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"=</span><br></blockquote><blockquote type="cite"><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;As always, Yellen=</span><br></blockquote><span>was careful not to give hints on what the Fed is planning to do in future m=</span><br><span>eetings; speaking on the path forward for the Fed Funds rate Yellen said =E2=</span><br><span>=80=9COf course, monetary policy is by no means on a preset course. The actu=</span><br><span>al path of the federal funds rate will depend on what incoming data tell us a=</span><br><span>bout the economic outlook, and we will regularly reassess what level of the f=</span><br><span>ederal funds rate is consistent with achieving and maintaining maximum emplo=</span><br><span>yment and 2 percent inflation.=E2=80=9D&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;bloc=</span><br><span>kquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;Yellen was asked about the chances of the FOMC rolling back the rate hike=</span><br><span>it announced in December: &amp;nbsp;"I do not expect the FOMC is going to be so=</span><br><span>on in the situation where it\'s necessary to cut rates If the FOMC delayed th=</span><br><span>e start of policy normalization for too long, it might have to tighten polic=</span><br><span>y relatively abruptly in the future to keep the economy from overheating and=</span><br><span>inflation from significantly overshooting its objective. Such an abrupt tig=</span><br><span>htening could increase the risk of pushing the economy into recession." &lt;/sp=</span><br><span>an&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blo=</span><br><span>ckquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Comment on Dodd-Frank&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote=</span><br><span>type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;During the Q&amp;amp;A portion of her testimony, Yellen was=</span><br><span>asked about financial regulation, both in terms of breaking up the banks an=</span><br><span>d enforcing the regulations brought on by Dodd-Frank. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquot=</span><br><span>e&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/b=</span><br><span>lockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote ty=</span><br><span>pe=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;In response to being asked if the Fed is trying to break u=</span><br><span>p the banks, she responded: "We are using our powers to make sure that a sys=</span><br><span>temically important institution could fail, and it would not have systemic c=</span><br><span>onsequences for the country." Her answer was interesting, because she\'s not o=</span><br><span>utright saying the banks will be broken up or reduced, just that the Fed is t=</span><br><span>rying to ensure that even if they did fail, it wouldn\'t negatively effect th=</span><br><span>e economy.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=</span><br><span>=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;=</span><br><span>br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockqu=</span><br><span>ote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Yellen was also asked abou=</span><br><span>t the burden of new Dodd-Frank regulations on banks. She responded: "For our=</span><br><span>part, we\'re focused on doing everything that we conceivably can to minimize=</span><br><span>and reduce the burden on these banking organizations. We\'ve been conducting=</span><br><span>an EGRPRA review to identify potential burdens that our regulations impose.=</span><br><span>" An EGRPRA review is connected to the Economic Growth and Regulatory Paperw=</span><br><span>ork Reduction Act, which requires regulations imposed on financial instituti=</span><br><span>ons to be reviewed by the agencies at least once every 10 years. The purpose=</span><br><span>is to prevent burdensome regulations that could hinder a bank\'s ability to s=</span><br><span>erve its customers. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;The Bottom Line&lt;=</span><br><span>/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D=</span><br><span>"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Fed watchers make their living by try=</span><br><span>ing to predict what the FOMC will or won=E2=80=99t do at their meetings, and=</span><br><span>on days when Yellen is scheduled to testify before Congress you can bet tha=</span><br><span>t they=E2=80=99re listening intently. &amp;nbsp;While Yellen was careful not to p=</span><br><span>roject the Fed=E2=80=99s moves, the general sentiment in the markets is that=</span><br><span>FOMC won=E2=80=99t be raising rates at its March meeting. &amp;nbsp;The CME Gro=</span><br><span>up FedWatch tool, which estimates FOMC rate hikes based on its futures price=</span><br><span>s, predicts a 95% probability that the Fed will maintain its current rate ta=</span><br><span>rget in March. &amp;nbsp;Some forecasters go even further -- expecting that the f=</span><br><span>unds rate won=E2=80=99t be raised all year. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockq=</span><br><span>uote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;block=</span><br><span>quote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;=</span><br><span>&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite"&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"cite=</span><br><span>"&gt;&lt;span&gt;Traders see the ongoing economic struggles of emerging economies, pa=</span><br><span>rticularly in China, as evidence that the Fed won=E2=80=99t continue with it=</span><br><span>s scheduled 4 rate hikes this year. &amp;nbsp;Certainly, considering the testimo=</span><br><span>ny today that 1) continued emerging market uncertainty can weigh down the US=</span><br><span>economy and 2) that poor performance in the US economy would cause the Fed t=</span><br><span>o change course on its rate hike schedule, a link between poor emerging mark=</span><br><span>et performance and fewer Fed rate hikes seems plausible. &amp;nbsp;Certainly the=</span><br><span>trading on Fed fund futures indicates that the markets believe this is the c=</span><br><span>ase.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;blockquote type=3D"ci=</span><br><span>te"&gt;&lt;blockquote
